I would therefore ask you always to take the voting card with you.  If you want to register for catch-the-eye, I invite you to do so now, without waiting for the end of the debate.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, allow me to present my last report from the European Council. Let us focus on three matters. Firstly, the European Council condemned Turkey’s unilateral military action in North East Syria. No one is fooled by the so‑called ceasefire. Turkey needs to end its military action permanently, withdraw its forces and respect international humanitarian law. Any other course means unacceptable human suffering, a victory for Daesh and a serious threat to European security. The European Council also reconfirmed its full solidarity with Cyprus, faced with Turkey’s illegal drillings off its coast. When it comes to Brexit, the European Council endorsed the deal reached by our negotiator and Prime Minister Johnson’s Government. As you know, it is based on the deal that we agreed with the previous Government. The changes concern the Protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland, formerly known as the backstop. Prime Minister Johnson’s acceptance to have customs checks at the points of entry into Northern Ireland will allow us to avoid border checks between Ireland and Northern Ireland, and will ensure the integrity of the single market. The revised deal was possible and acceptable to the EU because: firstly, it had the support of Ireland; secondly, it had the support of the Commission, ensuring that all our negotiating objectives were met; and, thirdly, because it avoids a chaotic no-deal Brexit. On the Council side, we have just finalised the necessary steps for the EU’s approval, and the legal texts are now with you. The European Parliament has a role to play, and it is an important one. The situation is quite complex following events over the weekend in the UK and the British request for an extension of the Article 50 process. I am consulting the leaders on how to react, and will decide in the coming days. It is obvious that the result of these consultations will very much depend on what the British Parliament decides, or doesn’t decide. We should be ready for every scenario. But one thing must be clear: as I said to Prime Minister Johnson on Saturday, a no-deal Brexit will never be our decision. (Applause) Finally, the leaders held a difficult debate on enlargement. Following the clear recommendation by the Commission, an overwhelming majority of Member States wanted to open accession talks with North Macedonia and Albania. Despite this, the required unanimity was not possible last week. In my opinion, this was a mistake, as I have said to the leaders ...  (Applause) and I was a bit more direct then. Now I can only hope that the leaders draw the right conclusions when they discuss the accession process before the Zagreb summit in May 2020. Together with Commission President-elect von der Leyen, the leaders also discussed the future of the European Union in terms of its strategic agenda, the future EU budget and the incoming Commission’s priorities. We are determined that the EU leads the way in fighting the climate crisis. A socially just transition to a green economy is not only a necessity but also an opportunity to improve our environment, while creating jobs. As this is my last appearance here with Jean-Claude Juncker, I would like to express my greatest appreciation of him and his work. These were a difficult five years for the Union, but we have always cooperated in good faith. Our respective roles and different perspectives sometimes meant political disagreements. But I can say without hesitation that Jean-Claude has always been devoted to Europe and served Europe well. And I am honoured to call you my friend, Jean-Claude. Thank you. (Applause) I also want to thank the European Parliament for five years of good cooperation. That does not mean that we have always agreed. Quite the contrary. But I have always respected you, honourable Members, knowing that we share the same goal: to protect our Union and our people. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, it was an emotional moment for me last week when I attended my last European Council together with my good friend Donald Tusk. We are today debating the 147th European Council of my political career – the147th or 148th, I don’t know exactly. Today is the 105th time that I have addressed you in this plenary, the beating heart of European democracy. In many of these 105 debates, I have had to discuss the UK’s departure from the European Union with you. In truth, it has pained me to spend so much of this term of office dealing with Brexit, when I have been thinking of nothing else than how this Union could do better for its citizens. A waste of time and a waste of energy! The Commission has worked tirelessly to negotiate and renegotiate an agreement with the United Kingdom to respect the UK’s decision to leave the European Union. We now have a new agreement, which again creates the legal certainty for an orderly withdrawal of the UK from the European Union. It took a huge amount of work to arrive at this point. I listened to Prime Minister Johnson in the same way as I listened to Prime Minister May. Our negotiators, mainly Michel Barnier, have once again worked around the clock and once again they have shown creativity and determination. The agreement we have reached with the United Kingdom Government addresses this Parliament’s demands – all Parliament’s demands. I will always regret the United Kingdom’s decision to leave the Union, but at least we can look ourselves in the eye and say that we have done all in our power to make sure that this departure is orderly. In this same spirit, we have done everything in our power to prepare the European Union for all eventualities, irrespective of what is happening on the other side of the channel. We need now to watch events in Westminster very closely, but it’s not possible – not imaginable – that this Parliament would ratify the agreement before Westminster has ratified it. First London, then Brussels and Strasbourg. (Applause) Wir haben uns, Herr Präsident, anlässlich des Europäischen Rates auch ausführlich mit dem finanziellen Rahmen für die nächste Siebenjahresperiode beschäftigt. Ich möchte hier noch einmal zu Protokoll geben, dass ich der Auffassung bin, dass die Zeit abläuft, die gebraucht werden wird, um zu einer Einigung im Rat und später anderswo zu kommen. Wenn wir weiter Zeit verlieren, werden wir in den ersten zwei Jahren des finanziellen Rahmens in finanzielle Engpässe kommen. Wichtig ist aber, dass die Mitgliedstaaten und andere Akteure wissen, welcher Finanzrahmen für die nächste Siebenjahresperiode gilt. Das brauchen junge Erasmus-Studenten, das brauchen Forscher, das brauchen viele andere, und wir haben eigentlich nicht das Recht, diese für das Gelingen des europäischen Projekts wichtigen Partner vor den Kopf zu stoßen, nur weil wir unfähig sind, uns zu einigen. Aber ich möchte ganz klar sagen: Das von der Kommission vorgeschlagene Haushaltsvolumen ist ein Minimum – ein Minimum! Die Vorschläge, die jetzt auf dem Tisch liegen – auch die jüngsten Vorschläge des finnischen Ratsvorsitzes –, sind nicht akzeptabel! Man kann Europa und seine Zukunft nicht mit einem Prozent des Bruttosozialprodukts gestalten. Dies wird nicht möglich sein. (Beifall) Et puis, Monsieur le président, nous avons parlé de l’élargissement.  Je suis très déçu de la décision ou de la non-décision du Conseil européen. La Macédoine du Nord et l’Albanie étaient en droit d’attendre qu’on ouvre les négociations avec ces pays qui ont fait de grands efforts. C’est une lourde erreur de ne pas avoir ouvert les négociations avec ces deux pays. C’est une lourde erreur parce qu’elle frappe deux pays au cœur. C’est une lourde erreur parce que, si l’Union européenne donne l’impression de faire des promesses et de ne pas les respecter, personne ne nous respectera à travers le monde.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to begin by thanking Donald Tusk for his five years of work for the common House of Europe. It has held together the difficult European Council, has contributed to the progress made at this difficult level as well. You pointed out that we all stand for the common idea. I think it can be said that it is easier here in this House to defend this common idea than in your body, in the European Council. Therefore, thank you for your work, also on behalf of the entire Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. Unfortunately, the last European Council did not take the decisions we wanted on Turkey. We are dealing with an incursion into Syria that is contrary to international law. The Kurds were our partners in the fight against Islamist terror. More than 11,000 Kurds have been killed in the fighting. There are 12,000 IS fighters in the camps there, which we do not now know whether or not they will be released. That is why it is a pity that the European Council has not been able to get its way to take further measures. The list of events in Turkey is now long. We have the illegal drilling in Cyprus, we have the restriction of the freedom of the press, the threats against refugees and now the invasion of Syria, which is contrary to international law. That is why many people are already asking themselves the question: where is Europe's clear signal? Where is this signal that we condemn this accordingly? We are talking – and this was also the case in the Council – of concern, we are concerned – but that is not enough in these times. There would be plenty of possibilities. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats believe that as long as Turkey is behaving aggressively, we must also talk about consequences, including economic consequences. It is not acceptable for Turkey to benefit permanently from the customs union, from economic access to the European internal market and, on the other hand, to behave aggressively. The second thing that moves us, of course, is the MFF – the financial issues. The Finnish proposal is simply a provocation to the European Parliament. Jean-Claude Juncker has said that this is not enough to answer the issues of the future. And I would like to make it clear that the European Parliament also has a role to play in the MFF in the end. The Council should not risk the proposals for the future failing in the European Parliament at the end. That is why I am campaigning for the European Union to be properly equipped. New tasks also mean new funds that need to be made available. And the 2020 budget, which will be on the table in a few days' time, is a prelude to this. It is not acceptable for us to cut back on the future, in research, in the case of young people, in Erasmus. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will not support this. And then, ladies and gentlemen, we have the historic mistake of the Council last week: Northern Macedonia and Albania are denied the prospect of accession. We are faced with the question of whether we are exporting stability to the Balkans or whether we are importing instability from the Balkans to Europe. That is the question we are facing. In this respect, there was a serious failure by the European Council on this historic issue last week. We have demanded a great deal from the countries: Northern Macedonia even had to change the name of the country in order to get a prospect of accession. They have tried, they have made an effort, and now the door is being slammed shut. It is a serious loss of credibility that we are witnessing and which the Heads of State or Government are responsible for. (Applause) I am very much in favour of us examining structures. It is now being discussed whether we will manage enlargement processes differently in the future. This can be heard mainly from Paris. I am very much in favour of that. But has Northern Macedonia been said before, has Albania been said before? No, they didn't say it. And that is why we must not confuse issues that were not directly linked. I would like to comment on a partisan political aspect. The EPP representatives in the European Council have all united in their support for the accession prospects of Northern Macedonia and Albania. It was mainly two Renew representatives, Emmanuel Macron and Mark Rutte, who have strongly opposed the two countries. I am campaigning for us, as parties, to be able to give these countries a perspective. A last word on Brexit for this week. We can simply say: let's wait and let's have a cup of coffee for what will happen in the next hours in London – a coffee, yes, a tea, you're right. Sorry for this. It was a more European perspective. It is positive that we have a compromise – that Michel and the negotiator in London, and finally, Johnson and Jean-Claude Juncker, found a compromise: no hard border, but on the other hand, no backstop. So I think for both sides it's a good compromise. Now the procedure is in our hands. The House of Commons, the upper house (the Lords) will decide, and then we have finally to see the outcome – whether the amendments will be accepted or not. So we are still in the hands of London. We are waiting for London, and for us as the European Parliament, I would say we have the same right to do a proper assessment about the text which is on our table. There is no need to rush. There is no need to hurry up. We have the same rights to discuss it at the level of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO), and then finally here in the plenary, after the discussions at group level. But that's why I see no chance that this week we will have any kind of decision. So the European Parliament is the last (let me say) institution who has to make the final assessment, and that is not only a technical assessment – we do a political assessment on the Treaty. But the last days gave us the opportunity that we finally managed a good development on Brexit in this negative case of Brexit, and a good chance that we keep friendship between Europe and Great Britain, to look for a good development so in the future. (Applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr Tusk, I would also like to take advantage of this debate to send you a message of recognition on behalf of my group. It is true that there have been many moments of uncovering between the Council and this European Parliament, but it is also important to recognise the effort that you have often put into working on at the personal level to ensure that there are common objectives to work for.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European Council has, on the other hand, special relevance at the time when we are: on the one hand, pending Brexit and, on the other hand, the beginning of the legislature, which will be crucial and for which we do not yet have a budget. Brexit is being a difficult and painful process for everyone. The Social Democrats have always wanted the UK to remain in the Union, and in this process every step is important. So was the step taken by the UK Parliament on Saturday, adopting an amendment that avoids the precipice of an un agreed Brexit. It is now up to the House of Commons to continue the proceedings and to rule on the agreement. Only then, as soon as we know what That Parliament's decision is, will this - the European Parliament - take responsibility and act accordingly.  From here I want to thank Michel Barnier for the work and efforts and unity shown by the Twenty-Seven, because we know that union makes strength. This same determination and coherence, which the Council has been able to maintain during the Brexit negotiations, we should now show it to set the course we need in the European Union for the next five years. If we want to be credible, it's time to move from words to action.  In recent elections, citizens have asked us for a new, greener, stronger Europe in defending the rule of law, more committed to social rights and equality, and more transparent in its decision-making. That is why we hope that the European Council will show more leadership and commitment to the challenges they face right now.  In the spring, the European Commission bet on a climate-neutral Europe in 2050. Unfortunately, this proposal does not yet have the unanimous support of the heads of government and yet the Social Democrats have made the so-called 'New Green Deal' an absolute priority for the future Commission. But it will only succeed if we put all the necessary resources. We will not accept that it is workers, small businesses or families who pay the green transition bill. We must agree on an investment plan that finances this transition fairly, and we can only achieve this with an ambitious financial framework.  The European Parliament set its targets for the budget in November 2018, and we have been waiting for the Council ever since. Our position remains strong: we will only support a budget with new own resources that reflect the Union's priorities and thus we will be able to promote new instruments, without reducing the financing of policies that are fundamental to the European Union: agriculture, cohesion, fisheries... We must ensure sufficient resources to address new challenges, such as migration, external action and defence, and we also need to respond to the economic difficulties faced by many citizens. We have succeeded in including European unemployment insurance, measures to combat child poverty and the Youth Guarantee as priorities of the next Commission. In short, we will only support an ambitious budget for Europe to grow. That is the goal: for Europe to grow. For that reason, we will not accept anything below 1.3% of gross national income. Without adequate funding, which European Government will assume its responsibility when the Commission is unable to comply with its programme?  The European Union also loses credibility when it calls for reforms from its neighbours and then leaves them waiting at the door once they have complied. We will therefore continue to support the start of accession negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania. Of course much remains to be done and negotiations are a long way off, but their completion must be completed as a lifeguard for the European Union.  Completing the accession of the Western Balkans not only contributes to the stability of the region, but also ensures the security of the whole Union.  And we also expect more ambition in the international sphere. We support the Council's condemnation of Turkey for its military intervention, although we regret the lack of concrete measures. And at this point I do not want to miss the opportunity to send a message of solidarity and support to Cyprus: we will not allow Turkey to continue its illegal drilling in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus and we call for its sovereignty to be respected. Colleagues, there's a lot of work to be done. Ambition is necessary and the commitment to work shared by all is essential. This European Parliament will live up to the circumstances. I hope that the Council will also be aware of the great responsibility it currently has in its hands.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, first of all, I will address Donald: you are nearing the end of your mandate, I have had the opportunity to work with you, on the Commission's side, on the Council side and now on the side of Parliament. I would like to tell you that I have always appreciated your righteousness, your sense of Europe and your contribution to European unity, as the first President of the Council from Eastern Europe. So I thank you for what you have done for Europe.  With regard to the Council's conclusions on Brexit, we are now getting used to it: we think we have seen the end of the tunnel and then, finally, systematically, our British friends are showing a lot of imagination to prolong and delay a final decision. British newspapers have always criticised our European institutions for their excessive creativity. We now see that they are capable of doing the same. But good if it's for a good cause.  In any case, on the part of Parliament, we welcome the fact that we now have an agreement. I would like to thank Michel Barnier and his team once again for their work. It was essential for us that the UK's exit be done with an agreement. We are now waiting for the British Parliament to do its job to the end and, quite clearly, we cannot take a decision in the European Parliament until we have a final decision, a final ratification of this agreement in the British Parliament. We will assume our responsibilities but, as Manfred said, it is not the European Parliament that should be in a hurry to do its job. That probably won't happen this week.  With regard to the other points raised in the Council, I will focus on two points, namely the budget and the enlargement process. As far as the budget is concerned, our group has been involved in drafting Parliament's resolution which clearly calls for the ambition for Europe to be reflected in the budget. Parliament will assume its responsibility not only to demand a strong budget, but also to show that Europe is not only built with negotiations of figures, but also with ambition. The budget cannot be limited to the sharing of financial contributions from Member States. If we have a genuine European ambition, we must now work seriously on own resources and show that Europe can build a truly European budget.  With regard to the question of enlargement, I will tell you, as a Romanian citizen, and therefore from a country which has enjoyed so many benefits from this enlargement process, that I am deeply convinced that enlargement policy must remain at the heart of European policy. We cannot imagine a strong Europe without remaining open to our neighbours, and in particular those who still believe in Europe, perhaps even stronger than some countries that are within the European Union. Therefore, the doors of the European Union must remain open and Europe must always remain an extraordinary engine for democratic reforms. These countries cannot be asked to carry out reforms without giving them a clear ambition and a clear idea of a European perspective.  I also fully understand the concerns and the will to deepen the European project within its current scope, to reform the European institutions, and that is why we strongly support the conference for the future of Europe, but this must not affect the European ambition to continue the enlargement process. So our doors must remain clearly open.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/ALE Group. Mr President, this gives me a feeling of déjà vu. Even the Brits use French to describe this situation. We've been here before. That was in November 2018. We had a European Council celebrating an agreement with the then British Prime Minister. We know what the British Parliament failed to do with that Agreement.  So we are back in the same place with a variant of that Agreement. Now everything is in the hands of the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The British Parliament must make up its mind. Either it ratifies - and I insist it ratifies, not express broad agreement - this Agreement and then indeed our Parliament will do its job. I cannot imagine, Mr President of the Council, that the Council will not allow this Parliament to have the time needed to complete the ratification. I know that the Heads of State and Government have a lot of respect for this Parliament. Even if we have frictions sometimes, I know that there's mutual respect and I want to keep it that way.  (Applause) Now, it can also be that the British Parliament refuses to ratify this Agreement, and in that case I would just say one thing: If you are unable or unwilling to do it, dear colleagues of the British Parliament, then you must have the guts to put either this Agreement or the Agreement concluded between the European Union and Theresa May to a popular vote and let the people decide. (Applause) And I would say that actually this is the only certain way to get to a decision because we know that, either way, we will have a British choice, and we will respect this choice. We will fight for the United Kingdom to remain, but if a majority accepts the Agreement, we will respect that and part ways in a friendly way. I would like to say a few words on the issue of enlargement. For us, it is absolutely clear that the Western Balkans are destined to join the European Union. I do not think it is in the interest of anyone, the citizens of these countries, or the citizens of the European Union, to leave these countries in limbo, which we know are the best way for these countries to fall outside the zone of democracy and the rule of law. Their vocation to join the European Union is indisputable to us.  The decision taken by the Council - and, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, I am pleased to have heard you say this - the refusal to honour our commitments, because it was a matter of respecting our commitments by opening negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania, is a reseed, is a fault. This is a serious fault on the part of the European Council, which obviously needed unanimity. I know that the majority of the members of the Council wanted to move forward, but indeed, and Manfred Weber was right to say, it was in particular two heads of state or government who made the decision to block this.  I stress that it was a matter of opening negotiations, not concluding negotiations. The whole argument that the Union must be deepened first is obviously completely misleading, since we know that these accession negotiations will last a long time and leave us plenty of time to deepen the Union, provided of course that there is the political will to do so.  Remember, when Emmanuel Macron was elected, we were celebrating the great European. Perhaps, over the years, the passing of time makes us realize that it may not be that big and not so European.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Turkey has largely occupied the debates at the last Council meeting. For the past 45 years, it has occupied a part of Cyprus, a Member State which is not defended in the face of the permanent aggression it is subjected to by Turkey, which is increasing illegal drilling in Cypriot territorial waters.  Turkey has carried out illegal military action in recent weeks, in violation of all the rules of international law, in northern Syria. This military action obviously leads to the strengthening of jihadist groups, whether Daesh or Al-Nusra. Yet the European Union has paid out 5.6 billion euros in recent years for migration policy, even as Turkey is mishandled in this control of migration flows and Mr Erdogan is escalating his blackmail by constantly threatening European countries to dump migrant flows.  We have paid out almost EUR 9 billion in the pre-accession funds and today, instead of issuing a few protests, instead of temporarily suspending the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, it is time, it is urgent to put a definitive end to this accession process. Turkey is not European by its history, culture or geography, and today it demonstrates that it defends interests that are at odds with all our interests of European nations.  The debate in the Council also, of course, focused on the multi-year financial framework. We talked about own resources and obviously talked about taxes as solutions to their own resources: carbon tax, plastic tax. Today, taxation is always heavier with the same pretext: the ecological pretext. But what is the coherence, on the one hand, in having trade agreements lowering tariffs, in multiplying free trade agreements with the whole world with countries that do not meet any of our environmental standards and, at the same time, in adding an extra layer on the tax millefeuille, which will undermine both the global competitiveness of our European companies and deal a severe blow to the purchasing power of our compatriots?  With regard to the European Union budget, we could sum it up this way: to pay more and more to get less and less. My country, France, has contributed almost 100 billion euros over the last twenty years, and for what result today? A reduction in CAP allocations, which will complete or, in any case, seriously weaken French agriculture. A French farmer commits suicide every other day.  Of course, we need to change course, we need cheaper cooperation, protections - they are indispensable - rather than going further and further, both in forced integration and in globalised free trade.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we called for the EU to show goodwill and flexibility in its approach to Brexit. We’ve now seen this in the most recent negotiations and at the European Council. What a change in atmosphere. My thanks to Michel Barnier. My thanks to Donald Tusk. My thanks to Jean-Claude Juncker. I hope there will be some proper reflection in due course on why the British people chose to leave the European Union and I hope that before December 2020 there will be technical alternatives acceptable, technical alternatives to customs checks.  The Presidents and Prime Ministers of the Member States in the Council have now agreed a deal and want to get on with it. They want the urgent consent of this House, and we should deliver this with all speed. After all, the departure date of 31 October was set, not by the British government, but by the European Council back in April. There is no appetite for extension. Some colleagues say they want to see how the British Parliament is responding, but I would say our task is separate. We should not be distracted. I am sure no one here, not even Mr Verhofstadt, wishes to take on a role as the Bercow of Brussels. In any case, the Withdrawal Agreement is being put to the House of Commons today. When it passes, I trust this will provide the signal that some here are looking for. Some shenanigans may follow, but it’s not our task to join in. This is our moment to rise above the squabbling, all the alternative political agendas and show that the European Parliament can be decisive when it matters. The EU must not make another sequencing mistake. Let’s get Brexit done without delay.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The results of the Council last week not only leave many questions unanswered, but also have obviously failed to solve some problems and, quite the contrary, have even worsened the status quo ante on some issues. The discussion on the accession of Northern Macedonia and Albania to the European Union triggered a state and government crisis in northern Macedonia in the Council. In the debate on the multiannual financial framework, figures are being pushed back and forth, and some of the Heads of State or Government obviously do not know how to achieve the ambitious climate targets themselves. However, I am glad that the Council has accepted my group's political assessment and now shares this position that Turkey's military intervention in northern Syria and the war against the Kurds are not covered by international law and are therefore contrary to international law. But if the Council and the Commission already have the same analysis, then I wonder: why do they stop there, why do they not also accept our political demands? Some of them have actually already been mentioned from a political spectrum on which I would not have expected it. We are committed to an immediate halt to arms exports to Turkey and, more importantly, to the recognition of Kurdish self-government! This economic and political pressure on Turkey will protect not only the democratic opposition, but also the Kurds.  And now to Brexit: my group has made a constructive contribution in recent years to finding a solution to this crisis. We will continue to do so. Our priority has always been to secure the peace process in Northern Ireland and protect the social rights of the millions of people affected, and yes, there is now a new deal that is obviously having its difficulties in passing through the House of Commons at the moment. We are waiting for the final negotiation and ratified text from London, and with that, if it comes at all, we will deal thoroughly with the time we need and the time it takes to do so. I can assure you of that on behalf of my group. And if there is no text coming from London, and that could happen in the next few days, I would like to give them the following advice for the decision of the Heads of State and Government on an extension, which is likely to be forthcoming: if you agree to the extension, allow the British people to make another decision. Some problems are solved in this way by themselves. Finally, A personal word, Mr Tusk: despite all the differences in content, I would like to thank you for the work that has been done and wish you all the best for everything that awaits you!

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would just like to confine my brief intervention to the subject of Brexit, something which we have been trying to come to terms with for the last three years since we knew the result of the referendum. Let’s be clear: the result must be respected, regardless of the small margin. The UK must leave and bear all the consequences of its decision. I think Mr Juncker was correct when he said that no extension should be granted. Regardless of whether there is an agreement or no agreement, the UK should leave, and I also think that it is in the best interest of Europe to let the UK go. The decision that the British people made three years ago was not an enormous surprise. British Euroscepticism has a very long tradition. Since Henry VIII, I think, this has been at the heart of British geopolitical thinking and, since this is a 500—year tradition, I respect it. But Europe and the European Union must also be very clear about the challenges it is facing and must be very clear about its priorities. Europe must face migration, wage inequalities, economic disparities and climate change, and it must come up with a solution. If Europe wants to be successful, it has to get rid of all the obstacles and the post—Brexit fatigue, be very clear about terms and conditions when it comes to new candidate Member States, and it must also be very clear with internal or external saboteurs who are trying to slow the process. So, as far as the UK is concerned, the decision to divorce was taken. It is time to move on for all.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – President Tusk, President Juncker, dear Jean-Claude, thank you indeed for your commitment to Europe, and especially for your comments regarding enlargement today. I will speak on Brexit and during the coming days the task of our House will be to evaluate the Withdrawal Agreement and work on our consent to it. We will have to cope with unpredictable outcomes of the complex process of voting in the British parliament, but it is clear that we will only give consent once the process of ratification in the UK has been finalised. This all has indeed a sense of déjà vu as we do not know today what majorities will emerge during various votes in the House of Commons, and what final result they might produce, and in particular it is difficult to judge today what can come out of the vote on the timetable motion.  It is regrettable indeed that once again we have to cope with a huge dose of uncertainty at this stage of this long journey. My hope is that, unlike the two extensions, the second of which is now coming to an end, the transition period which an orderly withdrawal will offer will be efficiently used to give us, as future close partners, the best possible agreement on unprecedented close future relationship.  Let me finish by underlining that negative coverage of EU citizens’ rights in media, confusing announcements on freedom of movement, use of a secondary level legislation, also what we learned during our hearings with citizens, all that signals the risk that those rights might not be respected in the future. We should remember therefore that EU citizens’ rights in the UK are set out in their Withdrawal Agreement which would be subject to the formal ratification.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Council reached a new Withdrawal Agreement with the UK Government and that is in itself a good thing. It proves beyond any reasonable doubt that the EU is not here to make life difficult for the UK. In fact, we were able to negotiate Agreements with three different prime ministers in the UK: Mr Cameron, Mrs May and now Mr Boris Johnson. And of course, an agreement will allow us to promote an orderly Brexit and avoid the risk of a catastrophic no—deal. But we also know that, until today, the UK Parliament has not taken any decision whatsoever on this proposed deal. Now, the position of this Parliament and the position of our group is completely clear: we will not proceed with any consent vote until the UK Parliament has approved the Agreement. Now let me be completely clear: first, any consent vote means not only the final consent by the plenary but also any consent vote in our Committee on Constitutional Affairs. And when we say, approval by the UK Parliament, we mean the UK Parliament with two Chambers: the House of Commons and the House of Lords. And when we say the Agreement has to be approved, we mean the final ratification in the UK Parliament after all amendments have been considered, including the one that is asking for a final say of the people in a second referendum. The European Parliament will be ready as soon as the UK Parliament is ready. And, if an extension becomes needed, the position of this Parliament was already stated and it’s clear: we will support such an extension and we do support the most important political statement made here today by President Tusk, that our decision will never be no—deal. If so, the Council will have for sure the support of our political group but also indeed the support of this Parliament.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I want to say to Mr Van Orden that I am honoured that you compared me with Mr Bercow. It’s in any way better than to be compared with Mr Rees-Mogg, because Mr Bercow’s ties are more colourful. I like them more than those of Mr Rees-Mogg.  I want to thank the Conference of Presidents that they have confirmed that the consent procedure in this House will only start after the full ratification by the side of the United Kingdom and that’s important, that was in our resolutions. I think we need to use the time between now and the consent vote to solve the last problems that still exist today which are the rights of the EU citizens that are living in the UK. There are still a number of problems to be solved. There is the vulnerable citizens – 200 000 of them who are in need of assistance. There is those who will miss the deadline, and there one of the members of the UK government has said, oh, we’re going to do deportation. Well, I can tell you this problem needs to be solved in all clarity before, that there is no deportation of these people. There is the difference between a settled status and pre-settled status. What is, in my opinion, not always clear why people are in pre-settled stages are not in settled status with full rights. And there is the Independent Monitoring Authority. It’s not clear in the withdrawal bill how independent the Independent Monitoring Authority will be and we have to be sure that it is a real Independent Monitoring Authority. So, before the House will give consent, I want to see this problem solved. We don’t want that the EU citizens become victims in another Windrush scandal in Britain. That cannot happen.  Finally, I want to use this intervention also to say some positive things about Jean-Claude Juncker, but already he is not there and especially to Donald Tusk, I want thank him for the cooperation. We never had words with each other during these five years in the debates and I wanted to wish him all the luck in his upcoming challenges, somewhere in a big country in the East of Europe. Good luck Donald.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I will also limit my remarks to Brexit, unsurprisingly. President Tusk, from Scotland, I would very warmly thank you and praise you for your conduct in office and for your efforts to keep the door open to us. It has been appreciated in Scotland and it has been appreciated across the UK as well. You’ve been a true friend to the United Kingdom. Thank you.  The last time we met to discuss this, I alleged bad faith on the part of those close to the UK Government – not their front spokespeople or apologists, but their tormentors, people of bad faith who around this UK Government are looking to trash whatever deal you have agreed in good faith. I didn’t expect to be proven right as quickly as I have been. Even overnight we saw very worrying moves that a delegated legislation committee stuffed with Government MPs has approved ending the rights of residents of EU nationals in the UK – self-employed and business owners. EU nationals were told in advance of the referendum that nothing would change. It’s changing now before the text has even been ratified.  So, what to do? You must deal with the interlocutors you’re dealt. I respect that. But I tell you frankly, it may not have escaped your notice but the UK is in chaos right now. Mr Johnson’s Government hangs by a thread and its word cannot be trusted even if there was good faith and an intent to implement it. Also the UK is not Westminster. I would refer you to a letter from the Joint First Ministers of Scotland and of Wales. The Scottish and Welsh Parliaments must also consent to this. We have not consented to this. Let’s be real, colleagues. There is no possible way that Westminster can conclude proper ratification of this deal this week. We should not lend the credibility of this Parliament or the Council to collude in that shabby deception. The only answer is more time. Time is the great healer. An extension has been requested, albeit through gritted teeth by a Prime Minister who is desperate to pretend he hasn’t, but an extension has been requested. Grant it. Grant it now. Grant it for a year, longer. Mr Johnson and his fellow travellers may have wasted the time. We will not. We are trying to find solutions. We need more time to do that.

name: Jörg Meuthen (ID).
text: Madam President, President Tusk, President Juncker, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work. We are witnessing a farce in never-ending acts: the British voted by a majority to leave – a referendum, a majority, a clear decision – but to date there is no result, no exit. Who among you dares to explain to the people how the ratification of the Withdrawal Treaty is being evaded and blocked? After all, they have been very successful in making the Withdrawal Treaty as unattractive as possible and making the withdrawal as unlikely as possible. Contrary to expectations, Boris Johnson now has a majority in favour of ratification. Now, here in the European Parliament, you are postponing ratification, and the EU's aide in the House of Commons, John Bercow, is doing his best by delaying a Commons vote on the Withdrawal Treaty. Everyone is sitting in the brake house, everyone in their place. It's a bizarre spectacle. I watch the sad spectacle with a laughing and a crying eye. Weeping because we are historical witnesses of how democratic processes are perverted here, and laughing because I know that the esteemed boys and girls of the Brexit Party are here and, as the voice of freedom, will enrich this House even longer and thus get you on your collectivist nerves. That, after all, is pleasing.

name: Derk Jan Eppink (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European Council did not agree on the accession negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania, and I would say: thank goodness. Especially thanks to France. There is no need for further enlargement of the European Union. Moreover, the idea of "the British out and the Balkans in it" is not a good transaction. And certainly not Albania, which is rife with corruption and is on the same level as Colombia. Northern Macedonia on the same level as Panama! So that's not good. Look at Romania in 2007. Everyone thought Romania was ready to join. Corruption was a big problem. Romania joined. The money flowed to Romania and the corruption got worse. One political crisis after another!  Turkey is a bridge too far. Since 2004, the European Commission has fed a sample in Turkey. His name, Mr Juncker: Erdogan. The Netherlands showed weak knees and was before the accession of Macedonia. France blocked it all and I do not often agree with Mr Macron, but in this case I say: la France, merci!

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, so we hope we have avoided a No—Deal. But it is still Brexit for the North of Ireland. It’s a messy and an ugly compromise, and if the British mess further and ultimately give a Unionist consent veto, there will never, ever again, be a Stormont Assembly. This deal as agreed mitigates the worst damage of Brexit. It avoids a harder border in Ireland. It avoids customs posts and we have a common EU VAT regime, a special status of sorts, now that’s important. But cows and sheep get EU standards, whereas people get potentially lower British standards – on workers’ rights, consumer rights, environmental protection – no level playing field. Now that’s damaging. We’re allowed to hang around the EU house, but it’s still only a half-way house. People want the real thing. Irish unity is the agreed way forward for the people back into the EU. This House should recognise that. This House should act to facilitate that, and this House should plan and prepare for Irish Unity and not be asleep at the wheel.

name: Lucy Elizabeth Harris (NI).
text: – Madam President, MPs in my parliament are stopping a deal which is mandated by the people. A ‘no deal’ which is mandated by the people and a general election. Parliament does not have a democratic mandate for a second referendum or cancelling Brexit, and yet they are amending their way to it. Control has been stolen from my people. But we do not give up. Despite it all, the majority of Brits still wouldn’t want to change the Brexit result. So I would like to celebrate millions of voters who stood up for what they believed in in 2016 and still have the courage not to give up. They show the best of British through their perseverance in the face of adversity. You may have tried to wear us down, dampened our spirits through the emotional rollercoaster of our negotiations, but my belief in them is unwavering and resolute. They will be heard. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, in your speech you used information, perhaps explain it to us. You said that the majority of UK citizens do not want to change the outcome of the referendum. Where do you own this data? We have been informed here that there is a petition, signed by millions of Britons, that there are protests. Where do you get the information? You have an obligation, as an MEP, to be rigorous when giving information.

name: Lucy Elizabeth Harris (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – I would like to mention the 54% ComRes poll that was released last week. I’d also like to mention the 17.4 million people, who shall not be forgotten in their vote in 2016, that still remain a majority. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Caroline Voaden (Renew)
text: blue-card question. – I’d just like to remind you that your slogan in 2016 was ‘Take back control’ – and that’s what our parliament’s doing. Isn’t that what you wanted?

name: Lucy Elizabeth Harris (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – In my country the people are sovereign. I’m not sure too much about this Parliament, but in my country people make the laws. I want the people to decide. And our slogan didn’t exist in 2016. The Brexit Party is very new.

name: Enikő Győri (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Unfortunately, some national leaders lacked the courage, wisdom and long-term ability to think at last week's EU summit. For this reason, no decision has been taken for the Union to finally start accession negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania. As the Heads of Government of the Visegrad Four put it before the summit, "the decision will affect our credibility in the region and will have serious and long-term consequences for our own stability and security. It's time to act in a geopolitical sense.""  Well, that's not going to happen. We have failed to act in our own well-understood interest to keep these two countries on our side, to acknowledge their work and to keep our word. We're not even going to tell them what else they're going to have to do, we're just going to move the finish line again, who knows how many inches. We deceived them, discredited them. Let us not be under any illusions: we will have others, strong, long-term competitors, who will want to push into the space left empty by the Union. They're there anyway, but they can't be seen by anyone who doesn't want to.  Finally, one more thing: it is more than strange how so-called Europeanism is measured in the Union. When something happens in a remote country on a distant continent and the Union manifests itself, it is not a European who does not support the common position. And now, when we have disappointed the citizens of two European countries, I have not heard any comments that blockers are not real Europeans. It would be nice if everyone thought about it.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Last week, the European Council approved both the revised Withdrawal Agreement and the Political Declaration. The EU has now really done everything it can to get a deal and avoid a crash, a no-deal Brexit. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, for a very good job, which has managed to maintain unity and been sensitive to Parliament's wishes.  The ball is now on the British side. The fact that Britain is leaving the EU makes me concerned. Even with great respect for the will of the British people, I understand today those Britons who are now fighting for another referendum. It is the case that a heavy responsibility now rests with Britain, on Boris Johnson. But I also expect the British Parliament to find a way forward.

name: Luisa Porritt (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I want to thank our European friends for their continued patience on Brexit, but let’s not be fooled: this deal is a ticking time bomb. If it passes both the UK and European Parliaments, in little over a year from now, we may be looking at a situation akin to no deal. There is a risk of divergence on everything from workers’ rights to environmental standards, to taxation, due to the decision to scrap the level playing field from the Withdrawal Agreement and place that in the political declaration. The EU would walk away from free-trade negotiations if there is too much divergence, and it is unrealistic to think that such negotiations could conclude in only a year. This is a task set up to fail by a British Prime Minister who won’t need to clear up the mess because he’ll probably be removed from power in a general election soon. His self-imposed deadline should not dictate the futures and freedoms of young people, our fellow Europeans in the UK, and Brits living elsewhere in the EU. President Tusk has acknowledged receipt of the letter requesting an extension. We need that extension to be granted. We must have a people’s vote.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, on Saturday I marched with a million others in London calling for a people’s vote. I marched because leaving the EU through the British Government’s rotten deal poses a threat to our country. It weakens workers’ rights, it slashes and burns environmental rules, and it will hold back people whose communities have already suffered generations of governments abandoning them. This deal will harm every part of the UK, but it won’t hit us all evenly. Women will suffer first. People of colour will endure the worst consequences, and those with the least now will have even less. That’s why we need a people’s vote so that people can have a final choice between this specific deal and Remain. Democracy did not die on 23 June 2016 and there is no majority in our country for a dangerous deal. So, while all eyes in the UK are currently on Westminster, I want to say something loud and clear here in Strasbourg: I will not give up on workers, on our environment, or on those likely to be worst affected by this dangerous deal. I will not give up on Britain remaining in the EU. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Ben Habib (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Phillips describes the reduction in standards which would ensue in the event of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union. Does she have no belief, no self-confidence and no understanding of the great British values that we have instilled across the globe for the betterment of mankind, and indeed the freedom of the continent in which we now sit?

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I do not understand why those people there are so afraid of democracy and putting back to the people something specific that they can vote on, which will not affect just their futures but the whole of a continent. (The speaker declined a blue-card question from Lance Forman)

name: Marco Campomenosi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, someone has said that this is a debate that we have already seen, it is true, because if we have lost two years for Brexit to finally be implemented, it is partly the fault of what has happened in Britain, but above all the fault of those in Brussels who thought it was a joke that the British did not really want to leave this crazy European Union. The truth is the opposite.  The truth is the opposite and so we finally have an agreement, we will see if it will be satisfactory or not. We will see how much and what it will bring. But this is a European Union which, compared to what is happening in the rest of the world, let us say, if it does fall on it, is not a protagonist. But then he uses international crises just for his own interest. For example, it has used the Scottish issue to destabilise the UK and totally ignores the Catalan issue. Here are some examples of cases like Brexit, which I believe will follow further in the coming years.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The situation in Turkey is totally unacceptable. The country is becoming increasingly authoritarian and undemocratic. The EU should suspend all forms of financial assistance to that country, and all forms of talks on possible future membership must cease immediately. The signal must be clear: you have disqualified yourselves from future cooperation in Turkey.  When it comes to the budget, it must be reduced, of course, after the UK has left. Seriously, what makes you think in this house that, for example, my country, Sweden, would be interested in paying an additional SEK 15 billion to the EU? We have always been one of the biggest net contributors. That's enough, not another cent you're going to have. Instead, we should start the discussion on how to get back what Europe was originally about, which you have forgotten in this House: peacekeeping and trade promotion cooperation instead of empire building.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the border in Ireland is already too hard. It has frustrated the economic, social and political development in our country and resulted in a conflict for which too many paid too high a price. The Good Friday Agreement and our shared membership of the EU have together been the instruments that have allowed us to undo some of the damages of partition over the past two decades. That is why Brexit has been such a dangerous development. It has risked our peace process and our all Ireland economy. Even the deal that was negotiated last week will create new problems for and relating to the border in Ireland. We support it because it is better than the alternative, but the deal cannot be further diluted. There can be no veto, no opportunity for any one party to hold every business, every farm, every worker, every community across the island of Ireland to ransom. To suggest that such a veto would represent consent is absurd and is a ludicrous misreading of the Good Friday Agreement. Of course, the best way to protect our country from the dangers of Brexit is through a united Ireland. The EU can play a role in supporting the peaceful democratic pathway to that objective, and I hope that this House is ready and willing to be part of the big constitutional conversation that’s coming our way.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, it is dangerous for the people to have Council decisions which reflect great contradictions within the European Union, in the territory of its fierce rivalries with the United States and Russia, over which groups will benefit in Syria and the Balkans. The recognition of Turkey as an essential partner, a NATO ally with so-called sanctions on future equipment, while it invades Syria, says it all. Similar sanctions are provided for Turkish violations in the Aegean and for drilling in the Cypriot EEZ. The blocking of accession processes and negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania shows, among other things, the pursuit of France's bourgeoisie to buy time to upgrade its own role in the Balkans, always in the context of the agreement of the Prespas detrimental to the peoples of the region. The complacency and embellishment of imperialist alliances and agreements by the Government of the New Republic and by SYRIZA are unfounded, they are dangerous for our people, who must be vigilant in their fight against imperialist plans.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Jean-Claude, I have looked back and in these five years we have had at least fifteen very serious crises: the refugee migration crisis; the euro crisis; the Greek crisis or Grexit; Russian invasion of Ukraine; fake news; the diesel crisis; the climate crisis and the Paris Summit; terrorist attacks; the rise of populism; the crisis of the rule of law in some countries of the European Union; the crisis of the legitimacy of the institutions with the failure of the Spitzenkandidat; demographic crisis; the trade war between the United States and China; Brexit—Brexit is the worst of national-political decisions, because no one is more lost than the one who does not know where he is going; the attempted coup d'coup in Spain - populism is trying to break Europe too, starting with my country.  It's been Jean-Claude for five very difficult years, but despite all twenty-seven, we're closer and stronger. Europe remains the best political invention in human history.  Thank you, Jean-Claude, and thank you to your Commission. I'm seeing Miguel. I'm seeing Johannes. I'm seeing Michel. I believe that from now on, however difficult the times may be, we will have an example of what it is to work rigorously, seriously and with love for the European project. Jean-Claude, you get a Latino like me to feel politically a Luxembourger. That's Europe.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, indeed, good point. The British Government is trying to force through the deal in the House of Commons in three days’ time, to hold three readings and the committee stage. A new 110-page long bill that has not been published before, a 600-page Agreement that has recently been changed, no impact assessments have been published on this. There is no certainty that this ruse will work, or that this deal will be approved at least in its current form. There will be amendments tabled, however short the period. Some amendments to try and have a softer Brexit because, make no mistake, this is a hard Brexit that takes Britain away from Europe, outside the customs union, outside the single market, it will be damaging for Britain’s economy, damaging for the European economy. It’s a bad deal for Britain and a bad deal for Europe.  But there will also be amendments to say that any Brexit outcome, any deal, must go back to the public for a final decision and that is only right because Brexit is turning out to be so completely different from what was promised by those leave campaigners three and half  years ago. It is leave voters who are entitled to say, that’s not what I was told, this is not what I voted for. I want to have a say again and that is the mood of British public opinion as demonstrated on Saturday in London. That is what opinion polls – most opinion polls – tell us, the British public want and deserve a right to reconsider this disastrous decision for our country. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Martin Edward Daubney (NI)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask Mr Corbett: what would he say to 5 million Labour voters in 60% of Labour seats who voted to leave the European Union? How could you explain to them that you have not betrayed their vote by your party demanding they are forced to vote again in a second referendum? You should be ashamed of your party.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Most Labour voters, even in leave seats, voted remain at the time of the referendum. That is now even more the case, because Labour leave voters have now seen that Brexit is a right-wing, neoliberal project, driven by the right wing of the Tory party, that will harm workplace rights, that will harm their economy, that will cost jobs, that will do no good whatsoever to Britain. And that’s why the Labour Party has rightly taken the position that any Brexit outcome now should go back to the public to decide.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, just to say at the outset, I again accept the fact that the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union. But in that context, I think it’s important that those that were supporting the UK leaving will acknowledge that by leaving without a deal, it will have profound implications on the island of Ireland and it will have profound implications for the peace process. The fact of the matter is that this particular issue was not debated during the referendum itself and it has now become a key issue in the context of the Withdrawal Agreement and the discussions between the European Union and the UK. But let us be very clear, it is not the European Union that is stalling the UK leaving the European Union, it is the UK parliament itself, and they are involved in a process, and whatever comes from that process it has to be close to the Withdrawal Agreement that has been agreed, to ensure there’s no diminution of the impact on the island of Ireland that this particular Agreement is there to protect. So I would say that we need to ensure that we have proper democratic scrutiny in the House of Commons and for that to come to a conclusion, and here in the European Parliament.  And finally, may I say there can be no diminution of European citizens’ rights in Northern Ireland, people from the European Union that have made Northern Ireland their home. It will be a shameful process if we have deportation of European citizens from the island of Ireland.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, there is currently a tale being told in the UK and, to be honest, some of the statements of people also here in this room haven’t really helped it. And this tale is that the EU is tired of us, they want to get rid of us and they want to mind their own business. And we have to make absolutely clear: this Parliament is still also the parliament of the British citizens. The EU is not tired of the UK. The EU is not tired of British people, and also the EU is not tired of having sensible and constructive negotiations. This project is built on multilateralism, so we love negotiating and finding common solutions. But what we are tired of is prime ministers that are giving promises that they cannot live up to. What we are tired of are prime ministers that are using divisive language at a time, especially, like this. What we are tired of are prime ministers who don’t understand that if they do not get this deal through the House of Commons, they will have to put it back to the people, so that the British people can decide on this finally.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: – Madam President, first of all congratulations to the Brexit Party because probably for the next month you’re not here anymore, and that’s a good thing because there are not many things where I can agree with Mr Juncker, but as he said five days ago, there is no argument for further delay, so Brexit has to be done. For the dear colleagues from the left side who are saying about democracy that somebody’s afraid of a new referendum, I would like to say that I’m pretty sure that in the UK there are millions of voters who are not satisfied that you are here in the European Parliament. What should we do? Should we make new elections for the European Parliament because they are not satisfied with the results of the elections? Of course not. After five years. Same thing with a new referendum. Maybe in 10 years, or in 20 years you can organise a new referendum to join the EU, but I’m pretty sure that it will not happen, because the Conservatives, or the Brexit Party, or the right Conservatives will win anyway the next elections, because they have done the Brexit. Thank you and good luck.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, what really grates here is not the dishonesty of our MPs, but the credit that they’re giving to our intelligence. They could have just rejected Brexit, they could have just refused to implement Article 50, but instead they have again and again lied and concealed their true motives. They thought that, if they could string things out beyond last week, people would blame Boris rather than the people doing the stringing out. They think that if they keep calling for an election but voting against it, we somehow won’t notice. They think that if they amend a bill to death with the intention of stopping it, again we’re going to fall for it. They seem to have believed their own propaganda about all Leave voters being stupid. And every time they have miscalculated. The reality is that the Conservative Party has been ahead for the last 40 opinion polls, generally in double digits. The only options we have are either to take this deal now and become good neighbours, rather than grudging tenants, or there will be an outright victory for the Conservatives at the next election and tougher terms. Those are the only two options now left. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful to Mr Hannan for giving way and I warmly endorse his criticism of dishonest politicians. In exactly that vein, would he like to apologise for his oft-repeated quote that ‘nobody is talking about leaving the single market’, which he said repeatedly during the Leave campaign, and indeed his subsequent conversion to the view that EU citizens’ rights are not going to be the same? Would he like to apologise for his previous positions and set the record straight?

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – It’s simply not the case that I repeatedly said that during the election campaign. You’ll hear a quote from a 2015 interview, before the campaign began, in which I made very clear – and I’ve stuck to that position all the way through – that I thought the best outcome for us would be a Swiss-type outcome. That’s a position that I took before, during and since the campaign. I have not changed my position. I wonder whether you, Mr Smith, who have made your entire career about demanding a referendum on independence for one part of the UK, might consider the hypocrisy of refusing to accept the verdict when the UK as a whole votes for independence.

name: Nigel Farage (NI).
text: – Madam President, well after three agonising years of negotiations, Michel Barnier gets Boris Johnson to sign us up to a brand new treaty, which guarantees three more years of agonising negotiations – and frankly reduces the United Kingdom to the status of a colony of the European Union. And why is Boris doing it? He’s doing it because he doesn’t want an extension. He’s doing it because he knows that an extension damages the Conservative Party in the polls, so he wants to bounce us into this new treaty before we wake up. It’s the same story every time. It’s about the Tory Party, not about the country. And what we need is to build a ‘Leave alliance’, of people across the political spectrum, to fight and win the next general election. The only way we can leave this place is with a clean-break Brexit. I would like to think, like Mr Juncker, that this is my last speech here in 20 years, but somehow, I’ve got the feeling … I’m sorry! I’m sorry! (Interruption by the President following noise in the Chamber) I’d love it to be. You’d love it to be! But I have a feeling we’ll be back in November.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Madam President, dear Donald, dear Jean-Claude, I share your indignation at an outcome that has not been in the Council, a result of attention to the Balkans.  Turkey, China, Russia and Saudi Arabia are investing energy and resources in the Balkans, and we are taking steps backwards by not facilitating the stability of that region, which is fundamental to the stability of the whole of Europe. We don't give positive messages but we give negative messages.  It was a resounding mistake, condemning Europe to progressive political irrelevance in that area, but we made the same mistakes by not making bold choices in the Middle East. We have not been able to tell Turkey clearly that that part of Syria was not being invading, because terrorists are not being sought in Syria, Kurdish terrorists are in Turkey and they must be arrested. But to strike at all the Kurdish people is a resounding mistake. We are also wiing out a part of Christian minorities in that part of Syria and we are still making mistakes, because Europe, through the selfishness of individual countries, is failing to play a leading role in the world. We did not have the courage to tell Turkey or to turn to the World Trade Organisation, for example, to denounce state aid to the Turkish steel industry by the military, which in fact competes unfairly with the European steel industry.  Europe, if it wants to count, must abandon national nostalgia, but have a strategy to count on the international stage. And the conference on the future of Europe must focus only on reform: a return to politics. If Europe does not return to politics, it will be irrelevance in the coming decades.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by leaving a word to Mr Juncker here because he has respected the principle of respect for diversity throughout his mandate. And maybe one day we can understand the importance of this principle. The Conclusions of the European Council on the multiannual financial framework do not reflect the divergences of the 27 Member States on the Finnish Presidency proposal. We know that the very majority of Member States are at odds with the Presidency. It does not take into account parliament's position recently validated by this House, it does not take into account the recommendations of the European Commission, it does not consider the political commitments of Mrs von der Leyen. We therefore fear that negotiating box's proposal is in the slights of what institutions, politicians and leaders should do in the next seven years. But Parliament will not fail to exercise its powers and will negotiate a robust budget. We want a budget on 1 January 2021, but we are not ready to compromise the budget by the timetable. I would like to remind you that the European Parliament has been ready to negotiate since November last year.

name: Fabienne Keller (Renew).
text: Mr Presidents, Commissioners, dear President Donald Tusk, you have reached an agreement with the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, whom I welcome, an agreement respecting European rules, also respecting the sovereign choice of the British people - and I want to denounce here the attitude of Mr Nigel Farage. Twenty years of fighting against Europe, twenty years during which he was fed by Europe... What is important today is the future relationship, and I would like to commend michel Barnier's work, his action for the cohesion of the 27 Member States with Johannes Hahn and Miguel Caete, whom I salute, behind him, to maintain a vision and carry a project together for the future of Europe.  A further postponement may be necessary, but I hope that it will only be accepted if there is a new element, if there is a reason. In any case, I would like to welcome your action to ensure that a European project for the future is carried forward.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, although Johnson is trying to bounce the Westminster Parliament into rubber-stamping the Brexit deal, our Parliament should do its job properly. We need to accord this treaty, which is so crucial to the interests of the EU and the UK, sufficient scrutiny. Since Brexit was clearly intended as an attack on European standards and on the integrity of the single market, we must not allow Brexit fatigue to weaken our resolve. We must defend those standards. We welcomed Mr Barnier’s idea of the level playing field, preventing the UK from undercutting the single market and its standards on environment, workers’ rights and tax. But in this deal, Johnson has moved those restrictions from the Withdrawal Agreement to the Political Declaration, which will not be legally binding. This is a clear signal that they are preparing the UK to become Singapore—on—Thames and is a threat to the integrity of the single market. Our European Parliament has already agreed that we will not agree the deal before the Westminster Parliament does, and we must stick to that, in spite of any pressure that might come from the Council to make hasty and risky decisions. Our job is to ensure that we protect the European project and the interests of present and future EU citizens.

name: Alessandro Panza (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's conclusions on climate change leave much to be desired.  As always, ideological approaches have been used which do not solve any kind of problem. We are seeing it in these hours in the provinces of Verbania in northern Piedmont, in the province of Alessandria in the center of Piedmont, where there are deaths, where there are flooding, landslides, landslides and closed roads. It is not by putting taxes that the problem of climate change is solved, but by allowing, for example, local administrators to intervene without being put in prison or without being accused of disfiguring the territory.  One final point: let us prevent the Solidarity Fund, as proposed by the Commission and the Council, from being used for what it is not intended for, namely for any hypothetical phantasmagorical damage caused by a Brexit. Let us leave the Solidarity Fund for natural disasters, which unfortunately continue to happen and will continue to occur more and more often.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr Juncker, Mr. Tusk, you have shed tears for Britain here, you are surprised that the problems with the negotiations with Macedonia, with Albania are now. I will tell you what the problem is in Croatia, why Croats are so disappointed in Europe. Because they expected, and this, after all, was promised to them, by your friend Plenković and the political establishment, that one minute when we enter Europe, that the judiciary will be solved, that the fight against corruption will be solved. That didn't happen. That's why there was this disappointment.  Croatia is, I can safely say, the most corrupt in Europe, every now and then such reports come out. And such, the most corrupt country in Europe, you have chosen to believe. In Croatia already for 10 000 euros and according to more, you can buy the result of a police investigation, a court verdict, a decision of prosecutors. In Croatia, institutions function by asking a thief if he is a thief, in the first step. In the second step he says he is not a thief and in step three they conclude that there are no elements of the offences. And that's how it's been going for decades.  The Croatian people expected that you would change it, that you would introduce high European standards to Croatia, but the opposite happened. This was evident in the election of the Commission, that you accepted the opinion of the Croatian judiciary, say about the assets of Dubravka Šuica or anyone. Croatia entered Europe with corruption, instead of a Europe with high standards entering Croatia. (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Sinčić, this is not the first time you have lied, deceived and supported your own country in this high house, so I ask you: Why are you doing this? Why did you do everything you could to keep your colleague Suica from being elected and when you were the only one who created this problem while the Legal Affairs Committee here said everything was fine? So, because of internal political problems in Croatia, you have made a problem for your own country. You're showing it, you're deceiving. Please don't do this and explain to me why you are doing this, why are you harming the Croatian state?

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. Falcon, I hope you know full well that Article 339 of the United State of The United State does not have the right to vote. The Croatian Penal Code talks about bribing deputies.  Please enter into a process that I have discussed a lot these days in the Croatian public, examining Ms. Šuica's assets, and you will see that Europe trusted Croatian institutions. The most corrupt country in Europe, their institutions are trusted without any verification. According to the Croatian archin, not the Finnish aršin. Here, there is, say, Mr. Kolakušić, he was a judge for 20 years. Do you think he happened to have been chosen here? Not. He was elected to a wave of dissatisfaction with the Croatian judiciary created by your establishment.
