name: Tomas Tobé (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As far as Brexit is concerned, it is now crucial that Europe continues to keep its cool. We should not let Boris Johnson's domestic political agenda, a noisy Brexit party or, for that matter, a French Macron who does not have enough patience, steer this process. We must stand ready in Europe to give further time for extension or, for that matter, if the British Parliament decides on another referendum, be ready for this.  For me, cohesion in Europe is what is supposed to guide this process. The most dangerous thing for both The United Kingdom and Europe would be a no-deal exit. For me, it would be best if the British remained in the European Union. But if it lands in an exit, we'll make sure we keep good relations. That is how we keep Europe together.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the disappointing conclusions of the Council demonstrate the need to equip the European Union once and for all with the means to govern transformations in the world around us.  I find it very serious that the leaders have not been able to make progress on the multiannual financial framework; They disagree on practically everything: national contributions, cuts in cohesion, own resources. Delaying the road map means jeopasing the funding of European programmes that are essential for the territories and for the citizens.  On the situation in Syria, on the other hand, the European Union is responsible for Erdogan's military attack, leaving too much alone the Kurdish people, our ally in the defeat of Daesh. The European Union immediately calls for an intervention force, a no-fly zone and economic and trade sanctions to strike at the specific interests of the Turkish Government. It is time for Parliament to demonstrate on these issues and on the others at the centre of the Council's debate that it has the strength to break the long inertia in which the Union still finds itself today.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, I just want to make an announcement on blue cards. We will close that now because we have 22 colleagues also on catch-the-eye, so I am closing both lists. So it’s going to be difficult to facilitate everybody.

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, while Brexit is the talk of the day, I would like to voice my regret about the Council conclusions on enlargement. North Macedonia and Albania have done everything we have asked of them. They have made important changes at real political costs. Yet what kind of message are we sending to them today? For those who oppose negotiations, they must make clear what further actions are needed, and moreover, they must help North Macedonia and Albania to complete these actions through financial and political measures. We cannot leave these countries without a clear path forward.  North Macedonia and Albania are European states, and therefore it is our duty to them and ourselves to start the enlargement process.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Madam President, with each new international crisis, it is clear that Europe stands out for its impotence. While all European states have condemned with one voice the military invasion of Syria by Turkey, strong acts against Sultan Erdogan could be expected. We were only able to reprimand.  Is ending the licensing of arms exports to Turkey all we are capable of? Let us use Article 29 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to impose an embargo on all military sales to Turkey, impose customs barriers on Turkish exports to the European market and put Erdogan at the foot of the negotiating wall. Yesterday, Russia did not receive the same leniency, since it was subject to economic sanctions on your part and by the European Union.  In the 19th century, the Ottoman Empire was said to be the sick man of Europe, but today it is we Europeans who are sick. We are sick of a masochism that makes us pay billions of euros to a state that threatens us with migration chaos and which you still consider an official candidate for enlargement. Between humiliation and honour, it is time to choose, or history will do it for us.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, so another European Council, another deal and an even bigger capitulation by Boris Johnson. The Prime Minister, who on 2 October said that the UK should leave the European Union, whole and entire, has signed up to a deal where Northern Ireland would apply the European Union Customs Code and Northern Ireland businesses would pay EU tariffs on goods used in the manufacturing process. And just yesterday, after checking what on earth he had negotiated, the Brexit Secretary confirmed that goods coming from Northern Ireland to GB will be subject to customs paperwork – an estimated cost of up to GBP 65 per declaration. Given that 70% of all of Northern Ireland’s trade is within the United Kingdom, this is a huge barrier to the Northern Ireland economy – a separation of Northern Ireland in customs and regulation from its own internal market. If all this was done for an independent trade policy, one prominent Northern Ireland economist has already declared that Northern Ireland would become a spectator in any UK trade deals. A shameful position. As Boris Johnston used to say: ‘No British Prime Minister could ever sign up to it’.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, please let me not speak about Brexit, I want to speak about the European Council. At the beginning, let me thank Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker for the dedication and effort that they have shown in the previous Council, but even years before. But we can see that sometimes dedication and effort is not enough. So I have one quite pressing issue, the question if the Council is the place of cooperation, mutual respect and responsibility, where good common solutions are found for the future or if it’s the place for political games, disagreement, and sometimes even inconsistent decisions. It seems to me that in the last Council the second prevailed over the first.  I hope it is the exception, otherwise we are heading towards problems.

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Brexit is becoming more and more a never-ending story. It is already the third British Prime Minister to deal with this issue, and it has gotten worse and worse. The Brexit failure – to be clear – is the result of the divided Tories, it is the result of the political selfishness of British Prime Minister Johnson, and it is a selfish game on the backs of the people and citizens, especially in the United Kingdom. If Brexit is needed, then a sensible deal is needed, but one thing must also be clear to us: no matter what form, Brexit means less and less social rights, less consumer protection, less money for the health system in the UK, and is therefore a bad idea.  We cannot stop the UK Government from making a mistake. However, we must not make a mistake ourselves, and it is therefore clear that I believe that this European Parliament cannot decide on the deal until the British Parliament and all its chambers have taken this decision. Only then will it be our turn.

name: Илхан Кючюк (Renew).
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, the past European Council has been of utmost importance: efforts to effectively address the severe humanitarian crisis in north-east Syria and the ongoing discussions to reach a compromise on the multiannual financial framework. A second important topic – Britain and Brexit. Britain is still on the verge of leaving the European Union, and despite Prime Minister Johnson's persistence to do so on October 28, it is now clear to everyone that he has no purpose, no plan and no direction. We must support the postponement of Brexit because the voice of all those people we saw on the streets of London on Saturday must finally be heard. At the same time, however, we cannot help but note with frustration the historical mistake that Europe is about to make with regard to North Macedonia and Albania. Any postponement to start a negotiation process harms the credibility of the European Union in the Balkans. The enlargement process is the best opportunity to ensure stability in the region and should not fall victim to political sentiment.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to welcome the really very important decisions of the European Council to take measures against Turkey's aggressive expansionary activity in the Cyprus exclusive economic zone, which violates the sovereign rights of a Member State of the European Union. At the same time, I must thank President Donald Tusk for his presence at the European Council over the past five years, together with the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, and the European Commission, who have upgraded the prestige and credibility of the European Union with their work and mission.  Turkey invaded Syria in the same way, undisturbed, as it invaded our Cyprus 45 years ago and left behind havoc and destruction. From this step, I have warned many times that we must halt Turkey's expansionist and aggressive policy here and now before it is too late. I believe that we must, before it is too late, adopt the proposal of the dear friend leader of the European People's Party, Manfred Weber, who has clearly said that Turkey cannot continue to enjoy the customs union, the internal market and be supported by the European Union when it invades countries such as Syria and when it violates principles and rights.  We must all, at this time, put forward and adopt Manfred Weber's proposal in order to have economic consequences for Turkey. Only in this way will Turkey understand and understand that the European Union is a Union of principles and values, which it must recognise and respect. At the same time, the jokes must end, because that is the only way the European Union will finally prove itself to be a leading force and respected by enemies and friends.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, last week's Council meeting was really not 'business as usual'. Several important topics have fallen undeservedly into the shadow of Brexit, best confirmed by the insufficiently substantial conclusion on the situation in Syria and only a brief reference to the multiannual budgetary framework. I am sorry that the unity and agreement reached on the upgraded Brexit deal has not continued with the agreement to open pre-accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. Both topics affect the credibility of the Union, our ability to act as a global actor in increasingly turbulent foreign policy opportunities. As we face an increasingly complex geopolitical situation, we must strengthen the influence of the European Union in our immediate neighbourhood. Our support to avoid a no-deal exit by the United Kingdom and protect the rights of our citizens is beyond question. However, this depends mostly on partners in London. By contrast, enlargement policy or support for governments proven to be committed to demanding reforms depends solely on us. I hope this unnecessary mistake by the Council will be corrected at the first possible opportunity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first, I'd like to say that we cannot imagine European politics in the last decades without President Juncker. And I would like to praise you, not for your political activity, but because you are a true European and a true humanist. And I would dedicate to you a quote of Montesquieu that can summarise your thought: 'If I knew something useful to my fatherland which were harmful to Europe, or something which were useful to Europe and harmful to mankind, I would consider it a crime'. This is a good summary of your thought and of your action. And now I just wanted to give two notes on the European Council. The first, to say that I fully follow the positions taken on the negotiation with the United Kingdom and on Brexit and that I think we have to continue to show ourselves very open to the whole British people, but clearly maintaining the defence of the European vision. Defending Europe is also defending the United Kingdom. And finally, a word from someone who comes from the farwest of Europe for the decision made about the Balkans. It is a shame that we are not in a position to open the negotiation process with Northern Macedonia and Albania. They need us, like us, the farwest countries of Europe, we have needed Europe in the past.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Madame la Présidente, cher Jean-Claude, cher Michel, je n'ai qu'une minute, mais je ne peux pas laisser passer cette occasion de vous remercier pour votre travail et votre vocation européenne. The construction européenne vous doit beaucoup. Brexit keeps us in total confusion. After the European summit and the vote in the House of Commons, chaos continues to reign and British politicians must be cleared up. In any case, it is preferable to postpone the output, than a hard Brexit.  But this debate cannot distract us from other priorities. We need an ambitious multiannual financial framework that goes well beyond one per cent of gross national income, as some heads of state and government have pointed out at the summit, including mine. We need to address the challenges associated with migration, climate change and the Digital Agenda. We also need resources to combat youth unemployment, long-term unemployment and the implementation of the gender strategy.  Above all, we must strengthen traditional European policies such as the CAP and social and territorial cohesion. We cannot allow our fields and rural areas to continue to empty and for the gap between regions to continue to grow.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, 31 October is a little over a week away and, of course, that brings to mind Halloween – pumpkins, ghosts and all things spooky – and some people might get carried away and want to ‘die in a ditch’ in the spirit of Halloween. But that wouldn’t apply to most of us, so for that reason, in terms of the Withdrawal Agreement, I think it’s important that we take our time and get it right. We have waited three years. If we have to wait another three weeks or three months, it’s better to take our time and get it right than to rush and get it wrong. Having said that, the updated Withdrawal Agreement is something better than a disorderly exit and, definitely, Prime Minister Johnson, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Michel Barnier deserve credit for the speed at which they worked to get this in order. However, as I said, we must take our time and get it right. Finally, I would also like to be associated with Mr González Pons’ and Mr Rangel’s and other people’s comments in relation to President Juncker. You’ve had a fantastic five years, Mr Juncker. You’ve shown great leadership and enjoyed great success, and Europe will always be grateful to you.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Madam President, I am concerned that there is a cacophony between Merkel and Macron, between France and Germany. On many issues they are opposed, from eurozone financing, from enlargement in the Western Balkans and from tackling the Turkish threat to the relationship with Russia. I would therefore like to overcome this cacophony, because I believe that with better Franco-German cooperation we will gain much more opportunities.  I would also like to thank President Juncker for what he has done for my country, Greece, we all thank him in Greece, regardless of political position, because Juncker loves the Greeks, loves us all, with our known weaknesses and shortcomings. After all, that's the real concept of love being selfless. We thank him very much for what he's done.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Council are playing games with all of us. They were quite happy to go along with Boris Johnson's timeline for Brexit but not to follow the long held EU line encouraging North Macedonia and Albania to join our European project.  The Council were willing to accept the promises of a liar Prime Minister in the UK but not willing to keep their word when it comes to good neighbours in the Balkans. We have made a promise to North Macedonia and Albania and not honouring that promise could be a historic mistake. Regarding the UK, what kind of international treaty should be rushed through without proper process or scrutiny? The Council has tried to bounce this issue back onto the European Parliament without allowing sufficient time for consideration and reflection before rejection or ratification. Brexit will not magically go away.  If the deal passes, this is just the end of the beginning, rather than the beginning of the end. Now begins the hard part.

name: Andrus Ansip (Renew).
text: – Madam President, dear Jean-Claude, dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to thank Jean-Claude for this really good leadership. But now about Brexit.  After the Brexit referendum we got strong statements from London. Brexit means Brexit. Out means out. ‘No deal’ is better than a bad deal.  During the last five years as Commission Vice-President responsible for the digital single market, I used to deal with very practical issues. We were able to abolish roaming surcharges in the European Union, but what will happen with those roaming surcharges after Brexit? It will depend on negotiations between EU 27 and the United Kingdom. We were able to agree on the General Data Protection Regulation to protect the privacy of our people and we were able to agree in free data flows to support our industries, and we all know UK is really good as cloud service provider, but what will happen with data flows after Brexit? It will depend on the deal. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I thank all colleagues for their patience with the nightmare of Brexit so far. I, too, deeply regret this. I, too, believe it’s been a waste of time and energy, and I agree with so many of you that things should not be artificially rushed now.  On Saturday, I marched with hundreds of thousands of people through my capital city, London, to call for a people’s vote on any final deal. You will have seen the pictures, a sea of pro-European sentiment on the streets of London. That is the will of the people. It has changed since 2016; 74 out of 75 polls in the last year show a majority for Remain, so please, friends, be in no doubt about the strength of pro-European feeling in the UK. And yet here we are, our new Prime Minister who has lost every single vote in the House of Commons so far – an historically unprecedented record of failure – is asking the EU to help dig him out of his own ditch. He wants the Council and this House to increase the pressure in Westminster but the deal raises very serious questions. We know the aim of the Brexiteers is to undermine social and environmental standards, so hard won, not to increase them. We know Johnson cannot be trusted. That’s why this deal needs thorough scrutiny here and in Westminster.

name: James Wells (NI).
text: – Madam President, the United Kingdom has been a good customer and friend of the European Union and its Member States. In the 20 years to 2018, the EU enjoyed a total trade surplus of nearly 750 billion with the UK. The UK has also contributed a net figure of 120 billion to the EU project over the same period, and the UK is one of only six Member States that meet NATO defence spending commitments that provide security to everybody in this place. Given this, I would like to know why Messrs Juncker, Tusk and Barnier feel that it’s okay to meet UK opposition leaders and the likes of Tony Blair in a blatant attempt to interfere in British politics. It seems Martin Selmayr hinted at the EU intent when he was overheard saying that Northern Ireland would be the price that Britain would pay for Brexit. Is it not the truth that the British people have been treated in contempt by the EU in these negotiations?

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Honourable President, i would like to thank you sincerely, Mr Tusk, for your voice of reason, which you have represented over the last five years. Thank you to Mr Juncker for his pro-European stance and Mr Barnier for his strong work on Brexit. I want to talk about a subject that, I come from Slovenia, has affected us very much. This is because the Council has rejected the accession negotiations for North Macedonia and albania. We come from an area where we know that peace is not only so artificial in itself, we come from an area and these countries have much to do in the area of the rule of law, on reforms within countries and such signals, the kind of frivolity shown by the Council is just frightening and therefore those of us who go to this part of Europe with a view to approaching it to the European Union are in big trouble. My sincere thanks to Mr Hahn for the great work he has done in the Balkans, but I fear that, following such decisions in the Balkans, the balance will shift in the other direction and the Balkans will decide the Balkans by others, not the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, President Tusk, President Juncker, I join the recognition, if only because under your mandate the European Union has been in the worst crisis in its history, of which Brexit is the most emblematic episode and the most emblematic break.  Mr Barnier, the only good news has been the maintenance of the negotiating unit of the European Union and reciprocity, which is never underlined enough. That is to say, the guarantee that the European Union will treat the British in the European Union in the way that the Uk treats European citizens on its territory. But the hourglass has become a time bomb. The succession of postponements of the final decision abysms us to Brexit without agreement and its economic and social and, above all, political effects. There is a political battle against reactionary nationalism based on bulos, misinformation and poisoning, which seeks to make local and regional identities incompatible with state ones and that national identities are incompatible with European ones.  Europe has to give that battle, but that takes resources, and with a budget of 1% of GDP it will not succeed. There is something worse than the contradiction between what is said and what is done and is not being willing to put the energy and resources necessary so that there is no contradiction between what is promised and what is fulfilled.

name: Michel Barnier
text: Chief Negotiator. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with your permission, Mr President and with That of President Juncker, I would like to say a word to all those, many of whom have spoken on this difficult issue of Brexit, and thank in particular for their confidence President Weber but also Mrs Garcia Pérez, Dacian Ciolos , Philippe Lamberts and Martin Schirdewan for their support and confidence throughout the last months and years. We have, as President Tusk and President Juncker have said, a great deal of respect for your Parliament. This Parliament must be respected in the serious and important moment we are at in the Brexit process. We have always respected it and it is your Parliament that will have the final say. It is therefore normal for the British Parliament to now take its responsibilities and commit itself first on the basis of the agreement we have negotiated with the British Government and not against it or without it to get what we all want, if it is Brexit, an orderly withdrawal. I repeat and repeat that if the United Kingdom wants an orderly withdrawal that is much better than a disorderly withdrawal, then that agreement is the only way. We think it is legitimate for your Parliament, when it gives its consent, to know unequivocally what the United Kingdom wants, what it wants, what it decides for its own future. We are at a serious and important phase, I repeat, of this long process. Since I have the opportunity, I would like to say to President Donald Tusk but also to his team, to President Jean-Claude Juncker, to all the Commissioners and to President Verhofstadt, to the members of Brexit, my thanks for their confidence.  The mission that Jean-Claude Juncker gave me at the very beginning was to work on a treaty organising the orderly withdrawal, and not anything else. That is what we have accomplished. But this difficult, complex mission - I was not surprised by its complexity - remains a mission for a negotiation that is negative. Brexit is lose-lose. No one, not even Mr Farage, has been able to prove to me or give me any proof of the added value of Brexit. We therefore conducted this negative negotiation by taking it very seriously to respect the British vote, even though we regretted it.  Throughout these three years, we have worked objectively, patiently seeking operational, legally valid solutions to each of the problems posed by Brexit everywhere and for many people.  We have worked with respect for our British partners because, ladies and gentlemen, we have respect and even admiration for the United Kingdom.  We have also worked without being influenced by the turbulence and internal political discussions in the United Kingdom. I have always said that we work without emotion, without passion on this issue, from the facts, the legal bases and the problems created by Brexit to find solutions.  Finally, we have worked with this negotiation in perspective. Brexit is not the end of the story. It is not a destination. We have therefore put this negotiation into perspective, first of all taking into account the peace in Ireland. Every day, every day, we had this demand to do everything to preserve the fragile peace on the island of Ireland. Then we also put into perspective what we were doing in relation to what is our foundation, our foundation, namely the internal market, which is much more than a free trade area, which is an economic and social living space in common and which must be consolidated and strengthened.  We have put this negotiation into perspective, taking into account what has always been the european Parliament's priority and our priority, the security of citizens' rights. Four and a half million people, including one and a half million British citizens living here and at least three and a half million EU citizens living and working in the UK. Mr Verhofstadt, Mrs Hunner, Mrs Fritzson and many others, I have heard your concern. I would remind you that if this agreement is voted on by the British Parliament and by you, the four and a half million people I am talking about will see their rights secure in a sustainable way for themselves and their families. This is the best guarantee for citizens. The United Kingdom is committed to implementing this agreement in a practical way and we must ensure that this will be the case. That is why the concerns you are expressing are important, and there is a need to keep up the pressure with the Member States to ensure that COMMITMENTs made by the United Kingdom are being met.  Then we have always put this negotiation in perspective - since Brexit is not the end of the story - of what we need to rebuild with the United Kingdom. Here we unravel 44 years of integration and cooperation. The British will leave more than 600 international agreements. We are not going to stop there. The United Kingdom remains where it is, our friend, our ally, our partner and therefore we must rebuild.  Mr Farage is no longer here, unfortunately, but I was surprised by what he said earlier, explaining that this agreement paved the way for three more years of negotiations. But, of course, we're going to have to negotiate! Beyond Brexit and separation or divorce, we will have to renegotiate for a year, two years, three years, maybe more, in some areas, to rebuild everything that has been decoupled by the will of those who supported Brexit. We will have to rebuild a balanced trade agreement with so-called rules of the game to avoid the risks that exist from tax, social, environmental or consumer dumping. We will have to rebuild a relationship in terms of university cooperation, Erasmus, research, police and judicial cooperation, security, defence, foreign policy, all these areas where we need to work with the United Kingdom in a new context and in a new political framework.  This is what lies ahead and what the European Commission, as President Juncker and The President-elect, Mrs von der Leyen, intended, is preparing by organising its own services. I would like to conclude with a note earlier from Mr van Orden, who said: 'There are the lessons of Brexit'. Of course, here we are talking about the consequences of Brexit. They are innumerable, they have often been underestimated, particularly in the United Kingdom, and we are dealing with them. But there are the lessons of Brexit. Why did 52% of Britons vote against Europe? I have always recommended, as a politician, that we take some time to think about this issue because it concerns us in the 27 countries of the European Union. In these lessons, there is a lesson that Mr. Farage and his friends have sometimes forgotten. It is that we must tell the truth to the citizens before they vote. It is our responsibility to tell the truth to the citizens.  (Applause) But behind the Brexit vote, there is also a social anger that has been expressed, the feeling sometimes that Europe is not sufficiently protecting the rejection of this deindustrialization, the need for protection and reform. This is the positive agenda, which is far more important than Brexit. What I am saying, because I can testify to this, is that it is exactly the wish and commitment of Mrs von der Leyen and her new team to focus now on this new positive agenda.  But I also mean - having had the privilege and honour of being by his side during these three years and of remaining naturally his friend for a long time - that this is the commitment of President Juncker and his team of Commissioners. Today, when I say goodbye, I must say that for me it has been and remains a great privilege to have been by his side, and I want to say my thanks for his trust. I know that he and his team have begun to focus on what is more important than anything, beyond Brexit, which is to commit to a positive agenda for Europe and for European citizens. (Applause)

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, thank you for all your warm words about me. It was worth waiting five years for such a moment! I would also like to thank the House for its responsible position on Brexit and the extension. Through this, you have shown common sense and a sense of dignity. After what I have heard today in this Chamber, I have no doubt that we should treat the British request for an extension in all seriousness. Thank you. Goodbye. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr President, I too would like to join my colleagues in thanking you for your willingness to hold debates with Parliament over all these years, and I would of course like to thank you for your efforts. The debate is closed. Now we stop for a very short break and then resume. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Milan Brglez (S&D)
text: Writing. – With regard to the conclusions of the European Council, I regret that the leaders and, consequently, the public have once again dealt with the issue of the UK's withdrawal from the EU.  Although this is a subject that we need to focus on from the point of view of securing people's rights, the disproportionate focus (of decisions) on the exit deal has completely neglected the negotiations on the financial perspective for 2021-2027. The conclusions call on the Presidency to submit a more concrete framework for negotiations only for the December Council, which, together with the postponement of a British exit, means that there is a strong likelihood that the new financial framework will not be adopted before the expiry of the existing one. This is a very bad sign for the future of the EU, because the promises and plans made by the President-elect of the Commission are impossible to deliver without adequate financial resources.  In the Member States, the planning of projects from the Cohesion Fund, which represents indispensable or only development funding for many parts of the EU, is impossible. The more the adoption of the MFF Regulation is romless, the more likely it is that, in time to reach a compromise, funds earmarked for cohesion and other development funds that are not strictly necessary for the day-to-day functioning of the (EU institutions) will be sacrificed.  The bad thing about the future of the EU is that EU enlargement will no longer be on the leaders' agenda before May 2020.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The second agreement approved by the European Council for the UK's withdrawal from the EU essentially corresponds to the agreement reached in 2018, and aspects related to customs controls, tax and movement and control issues relating to Northern Ireland have been amended.  In a still uncertain picture as to the outcome of the process, we reaffirm four central premises of our analysis and positioning.  More than three years since the referendum that dictated the sovereign decision of the British people to leave the EU, this is yet to be realised. The fundamental question is respect for the will of the British people.  The UK's withdrawal from the EU should not be used to, on behalf of so-called future 'adjustments' or 'impacts', to call into question labour and social rights, whether in the UK or in the EU Member States.  The rights of migrant workers, who are not guaranteed by the mere application of the EU acquis (as demonstrated by the agreement reached with David Cameron in 2016), must be firmly defended and secured, including through negotiations on a bilateral relationship plan between states.  Measures should be taken to develop a framework of mutually beneficial bilateral relations with the United Kingdom, respectful of the sovereignty of states and the rights of peoples.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Here we are at a final report from the Council and the Commission. I must say that, although I have been critical many times of the two leaders, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, looking ahead, I must thank them. I also thank them for their frankness in today's speech: Mr Tusk is talking about the mistake in the Council: two states that, through their leaders - France and the Netherlands - have blocked the enlargement decision. Two countries, France and the Netherlands, who pose in pro-European but are harming Europe's future by blocking the Council.  Mr Juncker has told us that the EU is making promises that it does not keep. That's exactly what I've been saying for five years in Parliament. But what awaits us? I am afraid to come to the sad conclusion that changing bosses is not always a joy. We do not yet have a European Commission, we do not yet have the final form of budget and the MFF and we are faced with the hubris of Mr Macron and Rutte. Elected President Ursula von der Leyen extends the formation of the team without any explanation! What can be the future of the EU? It is a natural question after the Council's decisions to block the accession of Northern Macedonia and Albania and after the unjustified delay in the completion of the new European Commission team.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D)
text: in writing. Madam President, we are knocking on the door of hell. Too much is at stake in Europe and the UK. It is now clear that people in the UK have been deceived by this simplistic slogan of "taking our destiny back into our hands". The authors of the slogan had nothing to propose, and the only thing they left was a pile of problems. For our part, Europe has united on Brexit, even if it is too late. Let's stick together in the difficult times to come. Let us take this example and unite where we lacked unity: in the future of Europe and the euro, in the ambition of the new budget and in the new priorities, in migration, in enlargement. Let us respond to the outcry of European citizens in the last elections: let us unite for more Europe.

name: Marco Zanni (ID)
text: in writing. At the last European Council, discussions were discussed on turkey, Brexit, EU enlargement and its future. Condemning Erdogan and stopping arms sales is not enough; With regard to the Brexit agreement, we must not forget how - during the long and complex negotiations - the EU has demonstrated its usual aversion to democracy. On enlargement to other countries in the Western Balkans, I believe that postponing the decision on the entry of Albania and North Macedonia is good news as the cultural and economic differences of the two countries would make integration difficult. Finally, on the future of the EU, the proposals to raise taxes for the umpteenth time in the name of combating the climate crisis are worrying. Furthermore, the possible cut in cap funds will have the effect of harming our farmers, who have already been affected by the crisis. Let us remember that Italy is one of the main net contributors to the EU budget and that our citizens must not bear any additional taxes and sacrifices.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is in times of turbulence, with many fronts of debate and difficult decision-making, that leaders assert themselves and significant qualitative leaps can be made in the European project. The European institutions have done a good job of the Brexit process. I welcome in particular the excellent work done by Michel Barnier. Today we have seen a strong majority convergence in this House on the European Union's negotiating strategy with the United Kingdom. This convergence creates positive expectations for European citizens. They hope that the spirit that animates it will be disseminated and to contaminate other key options for the Union. They expect less tactics and indecision and more courage and ambition in the management of the other dossiers that were also addressed at the European Council. This is the moment when deciding on the future relevance or irrelevance of the European Union on a global scale. Therefore, while staying strong and strong in the management of Brexit, we must be ambitious and swift in defining the next Multiannual Funding Framework and have the courage to continue to dialogue constructively with those who want to join the European project.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the President of the Commission on the review of the Juncker Commission (2019/2831(RSP)). Dear Mr Juncker, today we are here for your Commission's budget. I would like to thank the Commissioners who are here. Before I give you the floor, I wanted to thank you for your commitment to the service of Europe. A commitment which did not begin when he was elected President of the European Commission as spitzenkandidat, but which has accompanied you throughout your political life. During your presidency you have shown that Europe should not isolate, but unite: in the Brexit negotiations with the UK; through the search for a European response in the context of migration policy and the reception of refugees; in the fight against populism; on the Juncker plan and on deepening economic and monetary union and keeping Greece in the euro area. The challenges have been great and, despite our differences of opinion, the controversies and debates, which are also a sign of the vitality of democracy, have always been able to count on the European Parliament for a fairer, more united, more sustainable Europe that is closer to its citizens. Thank you also for the cooperation and attention you have always shown for our Parliament.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen, it is exactly five years to the day that your Parliament has placed its trust in my Commission, and you have never denied it. We have had, it is true, difficult relations, sometimes, but always polite, tumultuous but orderly. I wanted to thank you whole and heart out because having the confidence of this House, being able to rely on the confidence of European elected representatives reflecting European democracy, is an honour for everyone that lasts. I see here many well-known faces, many have become friends, not only from an inter-institutional point of view, but also for life, and so I wanted to thank you whole entirely, just as I would like to thank President Tusk. We were twin brothers. Even twin brothers may sometimes disagree, but we had the intelligence to hide it. And so, for you, it's probably a surprise to hear that we've had disagreements. So I wanted to thank Donald for his unwavering complicity, for a friendship that will remain and that honors me. Friendships - this word is used wrongly and through - are rare in politics, and even more so within the same political family. Without Donald, I would not have been able to do what I have managed to do, and I would also like, since I am speaking for the last time to this Chamber, to wish Mrs von der Leyen good luck. He is the person we need at the head of the Commission and she needs our encouragement and our wishes. Good wind, Ursula! And I also wanted to thank my commissioners because, without them, I would not have been able to do anything. They are men and women who, individually and collectively, have served Europe well. I want to thank them for that. Muchas gracias, obrigado, thank you, vielen dank! When I took office in 2014, Europe was in fact weakened. There were many cracks and ruptures of solidarity. Europe in 2014 was unloved, which led me to talk about the Last Chance Commission. But I did not want to talk about the Commission, but about a Commission serving Europe that was failing, since in 2014 we were entering a crucial moment in the future of Europe and therefore we were all in charge of giving life to the last chance that presented itself at the gates of Europe. I had chosen with my colleagues to set up a political commission. I wanted the commissioners to be elected officials. Apart from the British Commissioner - I had two British Commissioners, one more excellent than the other - all the Commissioners were elected, either at the national level or at the European level. I wanted the Commissioners to be well-known faces, in their country or in Europe. I had invited them not to lock themselves in Brussels, not to wall up in the Berlaymont, but to circulate, to explain, to dialogue with other elected officials and with public opinion and therefore citizens. Over the course of these five years, we have organized 1,815 citizen dialogues. And the commissioners attended and visited national parliaments and regional parliaments 911 times. At the beginning of my mandate, I promised you that the Commission would focus on the essentials, 'to be big on big', and I wanted, we wanted, to put an end to the legislative inflation which, until then, characterized the Commission's action. We did so because we introduced 84% fewer legislative initiatives than previous Commissions. We withdrew 142 legislative proposals and modernized 162 existing laws. Who's doing better? We have done everything we can to achieve what we promised, but that does not prevent everyone from continuing the game of blaming the Commission for being too sprawling, taking care of everything. Prejudice has a tenacious life in Europe. Everything has changed, but we act as if nothing has changed. When I appeared before you, I had three watchwords which I wanted them to dictate the commission's conduct: growth, employment and investment. We are experiencing the 25th consecutive quarter of growth. We have had seven years of growth in the European Union. We have created 14 million jobs. Unemployment is the lowest since 2,000. 241 million Europeans are at work, representing an employment rate of 73.9%.  The Juncker plan has generated investments of around 432 billion euros. At first, when it was thought that this plan would remain a failure, there was some talk in the air about the Juncker plan. Now that it is a success, we are talking about the European Strategic Investment Fund. So goes the story! One million jobs have been created as a result of this plan. In addition, we gave another reading grid stability and growth pact by flexibilizing some of its provisions. We have done so against the will of many Member States, which have never formally approved the lines of flexibility from which we have enriched the Stability Pact. However, the result is there: deficits have increased from 6.6% to 0.7%. This wise, thoughtful and intelligent flexibilization of the Stability Pact allowed us to respond when Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece called for us to act on their behalf. I have experienced disappointments and successes in my mandate, my dear friends. Disappointments because, despite our efforts, we have failed to move the issue of Cypriot reunification forward. Again, time has been wasted. We have not been able to conclude a treaty with Switzerland, despite our efforts, which were numerous and intense. We have not been able to perfect the banking union. Not for lack of proposals from the Commission, but thanks to or because of the non-effort of the Member States. However, if we do not complete the banking union properly, by making the Economic and Monetary Union a banking union that characterizes monetary unions all over the world, we will not be prepared to react to the next shock, whether internal or from outside. One of the things that needs to be done is our strong obligation to put in place a deposit guarantee system. Without a deposit guarantee, no banking union and no perfect banking union, no more economic and monetary union. You have to be able to respond to these challenges. But we have also had success, despite the polycrise we have had over the past five years. I do not dare to say successes because I would not want to be complacent, although I do want to. But we have had successes. First, I want to mention the social dimension of the European Union. As an unloved child over the past decades, we have been able to adopt the European Social Rights Foundation. I remember that when I first appeared before this Parliament, as a young labour minister, during a Luxembourg presidency of the Council of the Union, this speech was already my speech at the time. Even before we approved the European Social Rights Foundation, we had put the Detachment of Workers Directive back on the job. And contrary to expectations, we have managed to bring Parliament and Council to an agreement. It seems to me, however, a success of this Commission in establishing in principle the fact that, for the same job and for the same job, one should have the same salary. The dignity of the workers was at that price. Moreover, if we think we can build Europe, make it prosper, without the assent of those who work, we are seriously mistaken. Europe must also be that of the workers. Another success, it seems to me: Greece. I talk about it because it has been very busy and concerned about me. We have restored Greece's dignity. Too often and too long the dignity of the Greek people has been trampled upon and I have wanted to restore order by giving back to this people all the titles of nobility they deserve. The wanted to prevent the Commission from acting on Greece's behalf. I remember the long nights with the Samaras, Tsipras and now Mitsotakis governments - he was not yet in business - where we tried to solve the Greek problem. Many governments did not want the Commission to deal with it. I will always remember the phone calls from several prime ministers who said, "Take care of your business. It is the business of the states to deal with the Greek problem." I had this naïve, but fair, view that we should respect the treaty. And the treaty says that the Commission is in charge of the general interest of Europe. It was in the public interest to avoid the decomposition of the eurozone and so we were right to do what we did. Africa, yes. As Europeans, we cannot forget our first neighbours: they are African. It is a continent that needs our solidarity. But not just our charity. Charity is an ancient reflex of Europeans, whereas today it is a question of establishing a true partnership of equals between Africa and Europe. Investing in Africa, creating jobs in Africa, must be the "leitmotif" of our action, and we must not see Africa through the prism of the refugee crisis alone. It is to hurt Africans in their honour to consider relations with Africa only with refugees in mind. But let's do what we need to do on the spot so that the unfortunate don't throw themselves into the oceans. Refugees, yes - success or not? The balance sheet is better than we would think, but it could be even better if the Council, as Parliament has done, had followed all the proposals that the Commission had submitted to the co-legislator's meditation. A first part on relocation in March 2015 and another in April 2016 on the reform of the Dublin system. But let us not forget that, thanks to Europe, we have been able to save 760,000 lives in the Mediterranean. 760,000 fewer deaths as a result of the action that was that of Europe. I said in March 2015 what we were going to do about refugees. And Parliament applauded me standing up. I said at the time: today you applaud me, are you sure that in two years you will always applaud me? The applause was thinner years later, because in many countries domestic politics took over the elemental solidarity that should have been ours. I was very busy, whereas I didn't think about it when I became head of the Commission, international trade. A difficult subject, highly controversial in all our countries, with often good arguments against hasted trade agreements. But we have changed that. We have 15 international trade agreements. We now have trade agreements with 60 countries, which reflects 40% of the total wealth. Trade agreements help us to be present on the international stage at a time when the United States is turning its back on multilateralism and thus organized solidarity with others. Wir messen auch 'ber die Rolle Europas in der Welt reden. Der grete europeische Erfolg, die grete Leistung bleibt die Tatsache, dass wir den Frieden in Europa erhalten konnten. Das klingt alles so selbstverst-ndlich, ist es aber nicht. Es gibt heute, ich ich yesterday spreche, 60 Kriege weltweit. Kein einziger Konflikt kriegerischer Natur findet auf dem Territorium der European Union statt, dem Territorium, das der Schauplatz der blutigsten kriegerischen Auseinandersetzungen in den vergangenen Jahrhunderten, sogar noch im letzten Jahrhundert war. Frieden ist nicht selbstverst-ndlich, und wir sollten stolz darauf sein! (Beifall) Nun ist mir bewusst, dass man junge Menschen nicht mit dem Thema begeistern kann, dass Europa den Frieden erh-lt - denken wir. Aber man muss, wenn man mit jungen Leuten redet, auch 'ber dieses ewige europeische kontinentale Dilemma zwischen Krieg und Frieden reden. Man braucht nur in die direkte Nachbarschaft der European Union zu blicken, um zu sehen, wie gef-hrlich die international Lage ist, und damit auch, wie fragil die Lage der European Union ist. Jungen Menschen muss man von Krieg und Frieden erz-hlen. In 20 Jahren wird es keine Europàer mehr geben, deren Groevàter oder Urgroevàter den Krieg gekannt haben. Also muss man dar-ber reden, sonst geret in Vergessenheit, was Krieg bedeutet. Und deshalb rede ich auch mit jungen Menschen immer wieder über das Thema Krieg und Frieden. Aber es reicht nicht als Erklurung. Jungen Menschen muss man Europa auch perspektivisch, von der Zukunft her erklàren. Was ist denn die Zukunft Europas? Wir sind der kleinste Kontinent. Die meisten Europeer wissen das berhaupt nicht. Wir sind sehr klein als Europeischer Kontinent. Politik - das ist der Stoff, mit dem Demografie und Geografie zusammengebracht werden messen. Es gibt keine Politik, die Geografie und Demografie nicht in den Blick nimmt. Wir sterben aus, wir werden nicht verschwinden, aber wir werden immer weniger. Am Anfang of 20. Jahrhunderts waren 20% der Weltbev-lkerung Europàer, am Ende dieses Jahrhunderts wird es nur 4% European von zehn Milliarden Menschen geben. Wir werden wirtschaftlich an Kraft einbàen, massiv an Kraft einbàen. In einigen Jahren wird kein einziger EU-Mitgliedstaat noch Mitglied der G7-Gruppe sein, die sowieso verschwinden sollte, weil G20 wichtiger als G7 ist. Wer angesichts dieser nicht umkehrbaren Entwicklung noch denkt, jetzt wre der Moment gekommen, um weniger Europa auf die Tagesordnung zu setzen, um uns wieder in national Einzelteile zur-ckzuverlegen, der irrt sich fundamental. Europa bedeutet Frieden, Europa bedeutet aber auch Scharke angesichts des sinkenden Einflusses, den wir in der Welt haben. Deshalb messen wir auch in Fragen der Auenpolitik zu belastbareren Regelungen und Entscheidungsfindungswegen kommen. Ich plediere noch einmal dafar, dass wir auch in Fragen der Auenpolitik mit qualifizierter Mehrheit im Rat entscheiden - nicht in allen Fragen, aber doch sleeps, wo es darauf ankommt, dass Europa Farbe bekennt. (Beifall) Ich habe ein Erlebnis der besonderen Art in Washington gehabt. Ich war am 25. Juli letzten Jahres bei President Trump, um 'ber die Vermeidung des sich anbahnenden Handelskrieges zu reden, was uns auch gelungen ist. Wieso ist uns das gelungen? Trump hat mir in einer langen Einf-hrung - das mag er - geschildert, wer alles schon in diesem saa und was er denen gesagt hat: Kanzler - es gibt mehrere davon, Premierminister, Presidenten, und er hat gesagt, dass er denen doch schon alles erklart habe. Ich sage, das reiche nicht, er msse Europa das auch erklàren. Und dann sagt er: Wieso? Ich wise: weil die Kommission allein zust-ndig ist fer Handelsfragen. Alles, was die anderen sagen, so tàchtig sie auch sein màgen, zàhlt nicht. Es zehlt yesterday, was der President der Kommission im Namen der European Union vorbringt. Das hat ihn sehr beeindruckt und mich noch mehr. Denn wenn man als Luxemburger in Washington sitzt und sagt: "I am the man" - it's unheard of. Schlussfolgerung: Ich scheide aus dem Amt - nicht betr-bt, auch nicht 'berm-ig gl'cklich, aber in dem Gef-hl, mich redlich bem-ht zu haben. Und wenn sich alle redlich bem-hen wurden, wre einiges besser. Ich war stolz darauf, w-hrend langer Zeit, vor allem in den letzten fenf Jahren, ein kleines Teilchen eines gràeren Ganzen zu sein, das wichtiger ist als wir. Take care of Europe and fight with all your might stupid and narrow-minded nationalisms. Long live Europe! (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Juncker, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Politics thrives on change, democracy thrives on change. Today is the time to say goodbye. A great European will leave the European stage in the coming weeks. It is Jean-Claude Juncker. We, as Christian Democrats, bow. We would like to thank you, dear Jean-Claude, for your life achievement. And when I talk about life achievement, it's not just these five years. As a 36-year-old finance minister, you had already discussed the fundamentals of monetary union. You had negotiated the Dublin compromise between Germany and France. I do not know how many times you, as a Luxembourger, have had to negotiate compromises between Germany and France, and you were the one who brought the Treaty of Lisbon to life, especially the democratisation of Europe. Whatever the way forward with democratic Europe, together with Martin Schulz, you remain the founder of this democratic Europe. You can be proud of that. Your central talent is finding compromise. In your political career, you have settled thousands of disputes and reconciled countless people with each other. And you described it: Even Donald Trump couldn't escape your way of compromise. You called your commission "the Commission of last chance." Five years ago, you faced many crises, and during your tenure, unfortunately, God's more were added: Brexit, the migration crisis – you have touched some. Unfortunately, we cannot choose the tasks we have to perform ourselves, we can only tackle them with courage. And you, together with the entire quorum, seized and seized the opportunity. Your Commission was faced with tasks that could well have been completed five terms, and you answered them together. The 'Commission of Last Chance' has seized this opportunity. Europe is doing better today than it was five years ago: twelve million unemployed, trade agreements, we have achieved a great deal in the fight against terror, we have made significant progress in the migration crisis, we have stretched out Africa's hand, we have now put Brexit on the right track. Thanks to you, Europe is a safer, more prosperous and fairer continent than it was five years ago. Personally, I would like to single out three points that have remained in my mind: firstly, texts, laws are one thing, and people's lives and reality are the other. For example, when we talk about the application of the Stability Pact – you referred to Greece, you referred to Italy and other states: here in recent years we have been able to learn with your way of applying the texts that behind every text there are people, life achievement. To respect that, to take that seriously, to take that up, you have set in motion. (Applause) The second thing that remains in my mind is that many people still describe Europe today as the Europe of money, of the euro, of the market and so on. You have always pointed out that we Europeans do not stand for the market, but for the social market economy. You are the child of a miner. You can probably sing the Steigerlied just as easily as you can talk to business bosses about the future in Davos, and bringing that together is your success. You have put social issues on the agenda for the last five years. Thank you very much for that. Thirdly, you have not compromised on the fundamental values of Europe. Europe, the continent of democracy, of the rule of law. Europe, the continent of equality between men and women, of the protection of minorities – simply a Europe of freedom. You fought for this Europe, you stood up, and you made no compromises both internally and externally. Thank you also for this accent. You have given the idea of Europe a new lease of life, and you have resolutely opposed the populists from left and right. The enormous increase in voter turnout and the growing enthusiasm for Europe in Europe is also your merit. The 'Last Chance Commission' has taken advantage of it, the whole College has taken advantage of it, and we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats would like to say thank you for that. Last but not least, Dear Jean-Claude, your Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is proud of your term of office. You saved Europe from great damage in stormy times and made our continent a better place. We are happy to know you in our ranks. The great Christian Democrats such as Helmut Kohl and Wilfried Martens have valued you enormously. They knew that you were standing with Alcide de Gasperi, Robert Schuman, Konrad Adenauer in the line of the very great Christian Democrats who shaped Europe. In many of your speeches you used to say: Europe is a love affair, so you had described it. I would like to go a step further: it is not just a love affair, because an affair is only very short, meanwhile a real covenant for life has grown between you and Europe. You have a significant part to play in the success of the European Union, in the success of the idea you are fighting for and for which you are burning. As a Christian Democrat, I would like to express my sincere thanks on behalf of your group. (Applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to know where we want to go it is important to know where we are and how we have come here. It hasn't been an easy road and you know it well, Mr Juncker. Five years ago, you proposed to us a new agenda: it was called 'A New Beginning for Europe', but that 'new beginning' was halfway there. We are aware that you have tried, you tried to distance yourself from the policy of austerity and rigour imposed on us by Mr Barroso, and that attempt has always had the support of our political family.  The effects of the crisis have weighed heavily and today we have to recognize that we have not been able to make the radical decisions we needed to set a new course. I hope that now, before the new legislature, we will be able to do so.  When you arrived at the Commission, you proposed a battery of measures. It managed to file more than 90% of them, but only half have been approved. The others have stayed in the inkwell and some were fundamental. In many cases, failure is not due to the Commission, but to the lack of cooperation and ambition of governments in the Council.  He promised us a new agenda to create jobs, growth, equality, social justice. It is true that the task was ambitious and not easy. You inherited the effects of Europe's most severe economic crisis since the post-war period, and to that we add an unprecedented migration crisis, which the Member States have managed with a profound lack of solidarity. And the unpleasant surprise of the Brexit... It's not much.  But now the important thing is to know what has failed not to make the same mistakes. You will recognise that you have always kept us by the side in defending the values and interests of the Union. The Social Democrats have acted with responsibility, defending at all times the European project, democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Frans Timmermans' tireless work for common values and principles, his fight against populism and extremism have certainly contributed to the strength of this Commission, and we will continue to demand the same commitment for the next one.  He has also kept us by his side in seeking a solution to the serious migration crisis. We thank you for your efforts to find a proposal based on solidarity and the responsibility of the Member States. It is a pity that we have not succeeded in getting the Council to move a token, but we will continue to work to unlock the Dublin Regulation.  We have been at your side to resist the envites of multilateralism, to defend greater international cooperation, to fairer trade, and to make Europe speak with one voice. You have also had an extraordinary ally on the international stage, with High Representative Federica Mogherini. Not only has it cemented a much-needed new partnership between Africa and the European Union, but it has also delved into a historic agreement with Iran.  What we have not made enough progress on is the reform of the euro area and the economic transformation of the Union. As we demanded five years ago, you launched the European investment plan which has been the seed of the European Green Deal and the sustainable investment plan to be implemented by the next Commission. And in this we strive, if possible, with more energy.  Pierre Moscovici's work has been instrumental in introducing flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact, in response to irrational austerity and absolute rigidity imposed by the right. Mr Moscovici, thank you for your efforts to combat tax evasion and money laundering. It is unacceptable that the Council has rejected so many proposals to improve tax justice, so that large companies pay their taxes, and not just families, workers and small businesses.  Your Commission, Mr Juncker, responded to our demands for a European social pillar, but this is only a starting point: we want this pillar to translate into concrete measures. We want universal access to social protection, strengthen collective bargaining, living wages, eradicate child poverty and reconcile personal and work life.  It is true that improvements have been achieved in equality and today, following the announcement that your Commission has achieved the goal of reaching 40% of women in management positions within the European Commission, which is excellent news, I believe that your Commission could not say goodbye in a better way, because Europe will not be if it is not with its women , with equal opportunities between men and women. This is a very important issue for our political group, and for me personally, and we have to acknowledge and thank the work that has been done on this.  Unfortunately, the conservative forces of the Parliament and the Council have blocked further progress. We don't blame you, Mr Juncker; we praise your European enthusiasm, we thank you for your dedication and your good humour. And I keep the last sentence you have given in this speech: Europe must fight nationalism, because Europe is a project of coexistence, Europe is a project of peace. And today we have to thank him for his efforts; you have our total respect and admiration.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President of the Commission, dear Jean-Claude, I would like to take this important opportunity to thank you, not only for your work at the head of the Commission, but also for your career as a convinced European. You have given many lessons about what it means to be a true European and I want to thank you for that. Under your mandate, we had to turn the page on the financial crisis, deal with Brexit and the migrant crisis. You have kept European unity and I believe that everyone here, unanimously, thanks you because this unity is the most precious common good. Some had called your Commission the Last Chance Commission. Another Commission is now in place and the anti-Europeans have not achieved the score they had hoped for. The desire to build a Europe that is useful to our citizens remains at the heart of this Parliament.  I hope that we will now have a New Chance Commission. No doubt, not everything has been successful, but much has been accomplished in the years in which you have been head of the Commission. I could cite many concrete examples, but I will focus, in particular, on the Juncker plan, which I do not think we have talked about enough. Initially, it was decried and criticised and yet it made a concrete impact and it showed many small and medium-sized enterprises the face of useful Europe and an efficient Europe, which makes innovative projects possible. You also want a more political Commission, as you said in your speech. I believe that you have paved the way for the following, which will have to be even more political, because it is through politics that we will find European solutions to the concrete problems of Europeans.  We must continue on this path of a strengthened dialogue between the institutions and between the pro-European forces to build step by step this Europe which is at the heart of your commitment. Thank you, dear Jean-Claude Juncker, thank you to the whole of your Commission for showing and proving what It means to Europe and to work for Europe.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, dear Jean-Claude, it is up to me, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, to do you justice here after five years in office. Five years ago, like a number of my colleagues, I voted for you as President of the European Commission. I did so when you were the one under whose aegis your country, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, had become an opaque financial centre and a tax haven. Perhaps, I thought to myself, that in fact, it is poachers who are made the best gamekeepers.  Between the hard work of Margrethe Vestager and Pierre Moscovici - and let us not forget the hard work and pressure of our Parliament - we can recognise that, during your Parliament, the cause of tax justice has advanced, but it has remained confronted with a major obstacle: the stubbornness of the Member States to refuse any tax harmonisation. You could have circumvented that obstacle by using Article 116 of the treaty, but you did not have that audacity. To be frank, your concern for social justice has often led me to see you as a social democrat who is lost in the EPP group. In this respect, between the revision of the directive on seconded workers, the establishment of a European labour authority or the adoption - although, at this stage, essentially declaratory - of a European base of social rights, all this has been undeniable successes to be put on your own and that of your Commission. Similarly, as colleagues have said, you have adopted a less ideologically narrow application of European rules of economic governance, thus mitigating, somewhat, an austerity that has become deaf and blind to the demand for human dignity. It is undoubtedly this same demand for human dignity that has led your Commission to spare no effort for Europeans to provide a collective and united response to the challenges of asylum and migration, but, in this respect, the Council has blocked any progress - and I regret Mr Tusk's absence - bowing to his obsessive bias of a fortress Europe.  But if your social fibre is undeniable, your environmental conscience still seems to me to be largely built. Our common house is burning. It is burning with a dying climate, collapsing biodiversity and depleted resources. At the heart of this fire, a globalization whose free trade treaties, in their current form, are the driving force behind, treaties that favour capital holders, often improperly called investors, and reduce democratic social, environmental and fiscal norms to the status of decorative accessories, of course non-binding. You would have liked to have concluded such a treaty with the United States, and you said it yourself, you have concluded about 15 with others. Similarly, you have defended a common agricultural policy that is essentially productive, against any climate ambition or for biodiversity.  Contrary to your promises, and here we very much regret it, because you made this promise when you came before our group five years ago, you blocked all progress towards the ban on endocrine disruptors and you did not democratize the authorization of GMOs.  Too often, your Commission has refused to oppose big business in front of it. This is evidenced, for example, by your eagerness to protect trade secrets and, by comparison, your shyness in protecting whistleblowers or confronting the automotive industry, not only with its responsibilities but with its cheating.  We therefore keep a mixed memory of your five years, that of a transitional European Commission which, in the final analysis, has probably failed to fully measure the existential challenges we face.  You told us you were taking over the last chance commission. The result of the European elections in May has fortunately denied you. Your work has contributed to this, but I also believe that the Greens/European Free Alliance have contributed their full part to this. The logic of national preference did not prevail. And, like you, we fight it. That said, the danger is not ruled out. It will be up to the woman who succeeds you, both the President and the new Commission that will succeed you, to take a decidedly different course if, as you want and we want, we want to reconcile all Europeans with the idea of European integration, which is, I recall, the world's first experience of transnational democracy.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, five years ago, when you came to this House, I expressed strong doubts as to whether you might be the right person for this European renaissance, but we left you with the benefit of the doubt.  After five years we can say that this doubt has become a certainty. You are handing us back a Europe worse than the one you took over five years ago. A divided Europe, a weak Europe, a sick Europe that is unable to respond to the modern challenges and the three main problems that european citizens had asked you to solve: the problem of managing migratory flows, the problem of economic growth and the problem of internal security.  Your Commission and your mandate in these five years have failed on all these three objectives and the causes are not to be found outside these institutions. The causes are internal. The causes are the wrong policies that you have pursued, repeating mistakes also made by the previous Commission.  You spoke of your Commission's supposed successes. He spoke of growth, but growth is asphyxiated and Europe is losing ground to the other great powers outside our borders. He didn't talk about deindustrialization. Today, large European companies have gone bankrupt, or no longer operating, and he spoke of his investment plan. He said – assuming they are true – that he has brought 140 billion more investments. It is a pity that you promised this institution 315. I don't know if 50% of what he promised can be considered a success.  Well, I believe that there are millions of European citizens who are happy that you will be able to enjoy your good pension because your Commission has indeed been the worst Commission in recent years and in the history of the European Union, however, Sisoli, because I believe that your successor will obviously be able to do worse.  This is not good news for the citizens of Europe. And we will endeavour to ensure that the serious mistakes you have made in recent years are not repeated.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, President Juncker, let me start by acknowledging your commitment to public service. There are a lot of good things that you should be commended for, and the work of your team, too, should be appreciated, like making efforts to strengthen the Single Market, increasing the security of our energy supplies, leveraging investment into our economies, and good plans to strengthen small and medium farms, and a couple more points. These initiatives should not go unnoticed.  However, your tenure has been marked by many disappointments, and losing one of our biggest Member States, one of the most influential states internally and externally – in the world – is a disappointment of historic proportions. And don’t tell us you won’t take any responsibility for it because you should. What worries me, also, is that the UK’s departure did not, as it should have done, trigger any period of reflection, of looking for the deep causes of what happened. Mr Barnier was talking about reflection earlier this morning, but I expected that to have happened before Brexit, not after Brexit. Instead, we had a politics that deepened the divisions and aggravated the problems. The outgoing Commission – your Commission, President Juncker – has embarked on the most sustained pursuit of democratically elected EU governments we have ever seen, and this was a policy of abysmal arrogance and arbitrariness which obviously must have resulted in shocking double standards. You were preaching the importance of rules to some countries, and you were turning a blind eye when others were breaking rule after rule. We had a country that was allowed to flout the established migration rules, and then there was a divisive policy that was imposed on Member States and voters, who never wanted any part of it.  The EU, as I see it, was always supposed to be about bringing peoples and countries closer together, not pushing them further apart. The outgoing Commission, I’m sorry to say, Mr Juncker, is the first that did more to push peoples and countries apart than to bring them together.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, how can we not start this review without listing the endless list of tax evasion scandals that have engulfed in recent years: the Paradise Papers, the Panama Papers and, of course, the LuxLeaks, of which you have been one of the architects in your own country, Luxembourg, which is still not a tax haven in the eyes of the European Union. For us, fighting tax evasion with you at the head of the European Commission and despite the efforts of some Commissioners, who should be welcomed here for this mandate, was a bit like asking Monsanto to put an end to pesticides. Your social record, Mr Juncker, which you have talked about a lot, remains a failure. What happened to the European minimum wage, which you had promised us so much? Your climate record, Mr Juncker, is a real denial. You did not make a commitment on this five years ago, and since then the free trade treaties, which you still boast today, have been shovelled. Your record, Mr Juncker, it is not these lives saved, I am thinking first of all of those 16,000 dead in the Mediterranean Sea that are putting the seal of shame on a Europe that has been transformed into a fortress. Your record, Mr Juncker, is finally a democratic lockdown of Europe, still no right of initiative for Parliament, which I hope the next Commission will carry out. Your opponent, in the end, is a bit of a popular expression, and as you have said yourself, there can be no democratic choice against the European treaties. We think the exact opposite. There must be no European treaties without a democratic choice. At the end of your mandate, Mr Juncker, you have finally served the markets and you will not be missed by many of our European peoples and fellow citizens. But since we are committed to social rights, we wish you a great retirement and for that we have a small gift for you. To return to your tax haven, your friends, the multinationals you helped during the LuxLeaks, wish you a happy retirement with this gift.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, your mandate and that of your Commission are coming to an end, and it is therefore time for budgets and reports. Unfortunately, the time available to me does not allow me to give you a vote on each matter, because there are many shortcomings. I shall therefore focus on one of the most important legacies: the investment plan named after you: the Junker plan. A plan that, instead of focusing on renewables and energy efficiency, still finances fossil fuels today. Just look at projects of common interest in the field of energy: of the 195 projects approved in 2017, 77 concern gas and 7 oil. The same thing for 2019, the draft of the new projects has in fact 55 related to fossil sources. Is that how we really want to start an energy transition?  At a historic time of climate emergency, you have therefore dramatically delayed the actions needed to combat climate change, and this will have to explain this to young people protesting on the streets of Europe and to future generations.  These days, we are discussing, as you know, a new investment plan, this time sustainable, hopefully, proposed by President von der Leyen: a trillion euros to deal with the climate emergency. I hope, however, that this Parliament will not once again be deceived by the lark mirrors and the supposed leverage effects such as those promoted by your plan and for which, moreover, the Court of Auditors has also raised and raises doubts and joins me in asking for concrete guarantees from President von der Leyen that there should be real resources in this Green New Deal.
