In order to save the planet, we need an extraordinary plan of green investments and not of accountant fictions at Juncker.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank all those who took part in this debate, especially those who have spoken in a laudatory way, and invite Mr Zanni to study his files better. This will prevent him from quoting figures that are completely false.

text: Mr Juncker, members of the College, I thank you once again for being here, for your commitment and for defending the European ideal and, on behalf of Parliament, I present to you our respect and gratitude for the work you have done and for the dedication you have shown for Europe. name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: in writing. – Five years ago we didn’t have DSM in the EU. Instead to have DSM with more than 500 million healthy customers, we had 28 relatively small markets and cost of this fragmentation was huge – 415 billion euros in a year. To create DSM we launched 30 legislative proposals. We agreed in new telecom rules, we agreed in GDPR to protect privacy of our people. And we agreed in allowing free flow of data to support our industries. We abolished roaming surcharges and unjustified geoblocking. We agreed in allowing portability of digital content. We reached an agreement with 28 proposals out of 30 and we are now much closer to have DSM in the EU. Thank you, Jean Claude, for your great leadership.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Dear President of the Commission, colleagues, we are discussing the Commission's work and achievements today, and this debate is a good opportunity to assess the progress made in the European Union in general over the last five years. Indeed, the Commission has begun work in a difficult and tense period when Europe has experienced the refugee crisis, and in a difficult and tense economic and political period. Many decisive decisions had to be taken to manage the situation and this was done. Indeed, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his active role in contributing to the creation of a social Europe. The adopted pillar of social rights was one of the most anticipated and important work done in the social field. As far as my area is concerned, i.e. employment and social affairs and equal opportunities policies, we will still have to do a great deal before we create a truly socially sustainable and secure Europe for our citizens. a Europe that guarantees equal opportunities for all, which is equally rewarded for the same work, a Europe where there is no place for discrimination and hatred. I very much hope that the new Commission will resolutely continue the work that has begun, and that we will build a socially responsible and sustainable Europe over the next five years.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – In 2014, the Juncker Commission presented itself as a ‘political’ Commission, there to guide events and not to submit to them or simply function as an administrator. The irony has been that while trying to reach this goal, the Juncker Commission became a prisoner of the political emergencies it encountered without being able to resolve: the Greek crisis; the ongoing stand-off with Russia over Ukraine; the populist challenge; the immigration crisis; the Brexit referendum and its aftermath; the arrival of President Trump and the collapse of trade and investment negotiations with the US; stalemate in eurozone reform; plus more... Possibly, the Commission can claim that despite these setbacks, it scored politically by keeping the EU cohesive, rendering the Union economically stronger than when it assumed office. Even so, the claim that the Juncker Fund significantly contributed to this situation appears inflated, as shown by the European Court of Auditors in their assessment of the Fund. Where the Juncker Commission shone was in its efforts to nail climate change at the top of the international agenda and in its strategy to push a progressive social agenda for the EU as a whole. On the latter too, though, matters have hardly progressed beyond declaratory texts and rhetoric.

name: Christine Schneider (PPE)
text: Writing. I can only agree with what our group chairman said: with the end of Jean-Claude Juncker as President of the Commission, a great Christian Democrat and a convinced European are leaving the European stage. I have great respect for his commitment to the FUNDAMENTAL values of the EU, his commitment to the EU as an economic power worldwide, his fight against the populists of the right and the left, and his inexhaustible crisis management on Brexit, the migration crisis, the fight against terror and unemployment in the EU.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, tomorrow we are going to vote on a budget of EUR 171 billion in this House. It may seem like a lot, but it is only 1% of European wealth, and it is still a budget that allows us to finance the European policies which we have all decided and which, after reading this Parliament, will reinforce some of them which we have regarded as priorities. And we are going to strengthen them with 3 billion euros, as much as this narrow financial framework allows us.  And of these 3 billion, almost 2,000 will go towards strengthening the fight against climate change, demonstrating a clear commitment and commitment of this institution to what represents one of the biggest challenges we face. We have strengthened all budget lines related to climate change, from supporting infrastructure projects needed to achieve a decarbonization target to boosting research in future-oriented technologies. As I said, our biggest priority has been to give that impetus to programmes that have to do with climate change, but it has obviously not been the only one. And one more year, we call on unemployed young people to keep alive the Youth Guarantee programme, which neither the Council nor the Commission has deemed worthy of European funds. And we also continue to improve the Erasmus programme so that more students can benefit from it.   Nor have we forgotten our farmers and ranchers, who are victims of a meaningless trade war and are the target of tariffs which we will try to alleviate, if necessary, with the European budget.  And, of course, we also continue to demand more support for the reception of refugees on European territory, but also for countries which, despite their delicate situation, give us an example of daily solidarity with new refugees; and also for those who have been for sixty years, like the Palestinians, who need to survive from the United Nations Agency, UNRAW, which also needs European funding.  In short, we reinforce all the policies that help to design a modern Europe and which have a real impact on the lives of the citizens of the Union. But, as rapporteur on other institutions, I would like to take this time on the floor to value the work they do, because all the policies we put in place from the European Union are not done only because of the work of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. European construction has key allies in these other institutions so that all policies are planned rigorously, with control and taking into account the views of all sectors. It is therefore essential that all institutions have the necessary human, material and economic means, because we would do the European Union a weak favour if we were to defend that cutting its budgets is an example of good economic management, because nothing further from reality. We must continue to support the Committee of the Regions, where our municipalities and regions defend their interests and participate in the development of European legislation with a much closer look.  We need an Economic and Social Committee involved, so that workers' and employers' organisations continue to examine European policies from an economic and social point of view.  We need an agile and effective European Court of Justice, because in the end it is the guarantor of the European rule of law, having the task of interpreting Union legislation, ensuring its application and sanctioning in the event of non-compliance.  And we must continue to provide the necessary means to the European External Action Service, which is not only responsible for the European Union acting in a much more coherent way, but aims at consolidating peace in the world, combating climate change or policies of development and humanitarian aid. And I left the European Parliament for the end. This institution represents more than 500 million Europeans and Europeans and which is the institution with the greatest responsibility. Not only are we a House with legislative and budgetary powers, but we also have responsibility for the supervision and control of other institutions, the European budget and the implementation of Union legislation.  And all the work we do from these institutions is also not possible under the false slogan of "doing more with less". We cannot afford to jeopardize your work by cutting your operating budgets, and I will do my best in the forthcoming negotiations with the Council. I look forward to the cooperation of the Council and the Commission in achieving this objective and that it will not happen to us as a every year, we leave it for the last point and we no longer have room for manoeuvre.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Finnish Presidency has just been in the Conference of Committee Presidencies, so that we – both the chairman of the Committee on Budgets and I – were still firmly attached to it. I apologise for this and may now move on to the budget. The 2020 budget: the European Parliament will set clear priorities. Firstly, we want to tackle the issue of climate in an offensive and clear way. The budget proposal focuses on modern research, innovation and new technologies, particularly in the field of science and research, in order to meet challenges that we are still unable to cope with. At the same time, we want to create new jobs, to be competitive in this world and for others not simply to hang on to us or to develop things in a way that we may not want from our point of view either in terms of environmental, economic or social policy. Secondly, we want to give young people the security and support they need, throughout the European continent and throughout the European Union. In other words, support those who live in countries where there is up to 40%, 50% youth unemployment, and, as the European Union, send out a signal that we are not only continuing yEI – strengthening the youth employment initiative – but are formulating clear objectives. We also want to promote the exchange of young people with Erasmus+ and also with interrail tickets for 18-year-old san, because they can then learn from each other, benefit from each other and pursue education with each other. However, we also want to address important issues affecting small businesses that affect digitisation, which concern cancer research and research into the most serious diseases. As a consequence, this means that, in addition to major issues that are currently being formulated in public, we will not forget the issues that are essential for the people of the European Union and for the further development of our Member States. We remain focused on security. Safety is an important signal for people – as we have just seen again in the last two or three weeks. Security cannot be the home of individuals – whether they have money or not in order to be able to afford security. Security must be established by the Member States and by the European Union in cooperation between the Member States and through coordination in the field of cross-border crime. We want to strengthen the common protection of external borders. And what is particularly important to me is that the EEA should be properly equipped. In our view, the plans to set up the EEA to date are not sufficient and need to be significantly strengthened. If the EAA is really to tackle VAT fraud effectively, for example, it means that it must also have the means to do so, and Laura Kövesi should be given the means to finally put an end to the EUR 50 to 100 billion vat evasion or money laundering of a cross-border nature and at least greater successes than we are currently doing. Another item on the agenda is that you are asking us to be careful. I do not know where the Council's caution was when it cut EUR 200 million in AMIF. We must also address the issue of refugees and migrants in such a way that we have sufficient financial resources available in this budget, both within the European Union and outside. Development aid is a very important concern to us. We want to give people opportunities and perspectives. We want to have the opportunity to be able to provide humanitarian aid where it is necessary. If we now look again at the situation in northern Syria, it is imperative that we intervene in a stabilising and supportive manner. The resources you want to give us are not enough for this. And development aid consists not only of humanitarian aid or not only of humanitarian aspects, but also of the climate and the environment, and of the fact that people also want to have a reasonably perspective in their homeland in order to be able to survive. This means that there, too, the focus is on the fact that we care about the environment and the climate. Because people who have no chance to grow up in an orderly home will not stay there either. I would like to be very pleased, dear Advice, that you will finally start talking to us, dear Finnish Presidency: it does not help if we drink coffee with each other but do not actually exchange ideas in terms of content. My wish would be - I join Eider Gardiazabal Rubial as a matter of urgency: Please finally talk we have not yet seen that in terms of content with us. We will not be able to do all this until the last evening of the conciliation procedure, because the time is then far too short to go through things in a truly orderly and careful manner as the citizens of our countries expect.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it’s an honour for me to attend today the European Parliament’s debate on the draft budget of the European Union for 2020. We have already had an opportunity to exchange views on this important topic, on 18 September when I presented to you the Council’s position on the draft budget. On that occasion, I emphasised that we have to establish a budget that brings European added value and delivers tangible results for our citizens. But, at the same time, we need to prioritise the areas of expenditure that are pivotal for reaching our common goals. I am pleased to say that the European Parliament and the Council share the same priorities for next year’s budget. At the heart of these priorities are growth, employment and innovation, the need to rise to the climate challenge, to tackle the key areas of migration and security, and to help young people invest in their future. Where we differ is on what should be considered an appropriate level of funding for these important priorities. It is the art of budgeting to balance priorities. It’s true that citizens highly appreciate the public goods financed by the EU budget. However, we shouldn’t forget that these same citizens are also taxpayers, who want the budgetary authority to be careful with the global level of expenditure. In this context, I note that if the European Parliament’s amendments were to be integrated in the final budget for next year this would lead to an increase in the GNI contributions of 9.9% in relation to 2019. In its actions, the Council is always guided by considerations of prudence and strict budgetary discipline. Both from an internal and an international perspective, the times we are living in are challenging and uncertain. We are witnessing a number of climate challenges, disruptions in trade patterns, economic uncertainties, international tensions and technological changes. That is why the Council wants the budget for 2020 to be realistic but with sufficient margins to cater for unforeseen needs. Let me stress once again, however, that, according to the Council’s position, the budget for 2020 represents an increase of EUR 1 billion against the 2019 budget. Allow me now to make some preliminary remarks on the amendments to the Council’s position that Parliament intends to vote on tomorrow. In several headings, Parliament has proposed significant increases, which are meant to boost a number of programmes and projects. Some of these proposals go beyond not only the draft budget but also beyond the ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. We should be careful to avoid over—budgeting. As co-legislators, we have to take into account actual needs and absorption capacities, and take decisions grounded in reality. This year, the overall gap between our respective positions is bigger than in previous years: EUR 4.2 billion in commitments and EUR 6 billion in payments. Nonetheless, I’m convinced that, working together, we will be able to bridge this gap and reach a balanced and reasonable agreement on the budget for 2020.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by conveying to the two rapporteurs, Mrs Hohlmeier and Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial, the Commission's thanks for the valuable work done by hand and in terms of content, and also the respect for the quality of their work – as they have summarised here the various expectations from the political groups, from the committees in their report.  The priorities of the Council, Parliament and the Commission are the same. Firstly, growth for jobs and jobs and for the EU's competitiveness, strengthening the protection of our climate and environmental policy, promoting young people and managing migration with respect for human dignity. We have differences in the level of equipment of the programmes. While Parliament wants to deviate from the Commission's proposal by EUR 2.7 billion upwards, in other words, proposes a stronger budget, the Council wants to reduce the appropriations for commitments by EUR 1.5 billion. I could say now that I feel very comfortable in this centre, and I am happy to have a matter-of-fact discussion with you in the coming weeks about the usefulness of overspending or cuts along programmes and projects. We see ourselves here as a fair broker and service provider for the two budgetary authorities, the Council and Parliament. At EUR 4.2 billion, the difference is relatively large compared to previous years. It was lower in previous years. This does not necessarily have to lead to more difficulties in the conciliation phase, but it may be that it will be more difficult for you and us in November. It would be even more difficult if the UK were to go without an agreement. As of today, the probability of this is not too high. We are prepared for this, but only if there is agreement – which we all do not hope – if there is no orderly exit or an extension of membership, would it come immediately after parliament and the rapporteurs. I welcome the aforementioned willingness to compromise and cooperate, and we will all be ambitious in reaching an agreement as juncker commission in the phase by mid-November. It is a sign of European action. What could be the most difficult issues and points of contention? In some programmes and measures, Parliament goes well beyond the Commission's proposal. This can be fully understood in some programmes. Nevertheless, we should exercise a certain degree of caution, because if the margins are now fully exploited, there would not be enough flexibility in the implementation of the budget in the course of next year to respond financially appropriately to surprising, unforeseeable events – the new task of migration. We can certainly reduce the margins that we have proposed somewhat, but to make full use of them would mean that Parliament next year in particular does not have any current responsiveness in the budget. The Council has cut funding for programmes such as Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility and COSME, and I think there are good arguments against this. I would like to talk to you in the Council about whether, in these three programmes, cuts are appropriate in the first place, especially in the digital age, when we have a dip in the European economy, where a number of Member States are stagnating, where we tend to fall behind the United States and China in terms of innovation, where we should do more together in the field of research and development, especially in the digital age. The red pencil for research, infrastructure and SMEs – small and medium-sized enterprises – seems to me to be in the wrong place. We will analyse the proposed increases and then report back if we believe that increases are not feasible in implementation, so that they are basically more likely to remain theory and cannot be implemented in practice. A sensitive point could be the application of Article 15(3) of the Financial Regulation. We remember that, during the budget discussions, during the conciliation period as the Commission, we made the proposal – in order to realise some of Parliament's requests for additional expenditure – to allow for a moderate level of redeployment in the field of research. The Council was surprised at the time – true, it was surprising – this time we proposed it publicly back in May. I know from national and regional budgetary policy for many years the instrument of transferability of funds from the previous year to next year – that is, unused funds of the past for meaningful measures of the future. It is recognised in the Financial Regulation as an instrument, and the The legal basis for this was created a few years ago by the Council and Parliament. My request to the Council would be: let us argue about the amount that the instrument would generally reject, I believe, make it much more difficult this time to reach an agreement between the two Houses.  Parliament is proposing a significant increase of EUR 363 million in the Youth Employment Initiative. We will look into this; We can tell you that the measures to get young people into work are now running smoothly, our administrations have gained enough experience, have been successful. Nevertheless, we believe that this amount does not meet the necessary needs, but rather is set a little too high. We will then demonstrate this in the course of the discussions, Member State by Member State, on demand. Migration management is another priority: we must ensure that the Commission can continue to finance actions in the Member States at the external borders. The funds are therefore needed directly. Every artificial reserve makes us less able to act. It is precisely the difficult events of the last few days in Turkey and Syria that show that the EU should be able to act very, very quickly, even with budgetary resources. Another point of discussion will be pre-accession aid to Turkey. We all agree on what we are very critical of the Ankara government policy and the work and rhetoric of the President of Turkey. That is why I want to make a proposal to you once again: let us only discuss – but then finance – projects that fit the European order of values that are in civil society, those in non-governmental institutions that make sense for democracy and the rule of law. It would be good to implement the programmes, which are in our common sense – as far as they are still possible – with the people of Turkey – not with the government – next year also financially– no more and no less. This should be a strategic interest of the European Union. Again, if we put large amounts in reserve, this makes activation and rapid implementation much more difficult. I would like to mention once again that, in the context of conciliation, we must also respond to the letter of amendment to the 2020 draft adopted by the Commission last week. We are talking about an increase of EUR 16.4 million in commitment appropriations and a reduction of EUR 5.4 million in payment appropriations. It is a question of having a now-current condition for agricultural expenditure, which has taken account of market developments, but also of new legal decisions – laws – in the agricultural sector. Secondly, there are some adjustments following recent developments concerning the new Innovation Fund, Parliament's establishment plan, the security of the European External Action Service and the needs of the eu-LISA agency. I think that, in the current situation, with the likely withdrawal of the United Kingdom, in the last weeks of the Juncker Commission and with a new Parliament, it would be a shining sign if we could get along within the time provided for by law and present an agreement on a 2020 budget to our citizens in mid-November. This presupposes a willingness on the part of all sides, including the Commission – which I can offer you – but also the Council and Parliament. With this in mind, I look forward to the discussions in November, which I would have liked to have transferred to my colleague Mr Hahn, but now that we have to sit down, you must once again make do with me.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, when it comes to international trade, the implementation of trade agreements is key, and that goes in particular for the sustainable development chapter within the trade agreements. Without sufficient resources to monitor the commitments, we risk leaving with empty words, and that is absolutely not what we intend as a parliament. When we think about these commitments, it’s about eradication of child labour, freedom of association, fighting climate change, commitments on gender equality and, of course, human rights. Sufficient funding is also needed to draft impact assessments on a regular basis. And let’s not forget that civil society is also key in the implementation of this trade and sustainable development (TSD) chapter, and enforcing these domestic advisory groups is also very important. A final point of the Committee on International Trade (INTA). At times when multilateralism and the WTO is under very firm attack, we as a Union should do everything within our power to strengthen that, and in that sense the WTO Parliamentary Conference is a very useful tool in discussions on shaping global trade policy. Therefore, the Committee regrets that the amendments for INTA, both on the domestic Advisory Group and on the WTO Parliamentary Conference, were not taken into account. We deeply regret that.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, Commissioner, the budget for the financial year 2020 is the last in the current financial framework, being a budget of both transition and continuity. The main aim, of course, is to continue the ongoing programmes, but also to prepare a solid framework for those to be implemented from 2021. With regard to the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have suggested some amendments relating to financial management, programme sheets for operational expenditure, performance reports, timely absorption of European funds, migration, financial instruments and structural funds, and the provision of resources to the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I want to take this opportunity, Madam President, perhaps allow me an extra second, to thank Commissioner Oettinger for the good cooperation of late times in the development of the Multiannual Financial Framework and the 2021-2027 budget which unfortunately stagnates and endangers hundreds of thousands of projects in Europe, Erasmus scholarships, security programmes. I call on the Finnish Presidency to speed up the negotiation of this budget, which has been tabled since 2 May 2018 with Parliament and the Council. Thank you very much, Madam President, for your time.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Madam President, the year 2020 is the last year of the current Multiannual Financial Framework, and so we have to make sure that we equip the budget with enough resources in order for the European Union to deliver towards all the beneficiaries. There is no worse signal that we can give to the beneficiaries than a European Union not capable of paying its bills. We have all seen at the European elections that people come out and vote in large numbers. They want jobs, growth and security. Students and researchers expect support, farmers expect support, and cities and villages expect support through cohesion policy. We have, of course, to listen to them. I am speaking here on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). On behalf of the Committee, we expect three things: firstly, enough resources for investments in the EU economy; second, the completion of the capital markets union; and thirdly, completion of the economic and monetary union. That’s why of the utmost importance for us are the resources for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the Juncker Investment Plan. Minister, I cannot understand why the Council is proposing to cut the financing by EUR 90 million to this successful project which we, the Parliament, are defending. This is why I am telling you, very clearly and openly, that the European Parliament will not vote a budget for the EU 2020 with any cuts to the Juncker EFSI Investment Plan.

name: Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová
text: The rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs , Madam President, in my report on next year's budget for the EMPL Committee, I focused on two priorities. The first is that we really need to start with Eu-fund projects, to measure results, and not just outputs. The other is that we need to start focusing on value for money. If we have a problem with youth unemployment in our Member States, we must not only address this by creating a fund into which we will now permanently 'put' money into, but we must focus on starting to eliminate the causes of youth unemployment in individual Member States. We should also start using data more, because if, for example, 300 people take part in a 'fast-growing' project in Eurofund retraining projects, that does not mean that these people are employed. And practice shows us that they will not be employed, but will return to the oysters, for example. I am now talking about socially excluded Roma communities. And that's the last thing I want to say. We really need to start doing social inclusion not just on paper. I consider it a huge luxury at the moment to leave socially excluded communities, such as Roma communities, without including them in an open labour market, which we can no longer afford.

name: Pascal Canfin
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, it has not escaped your attention that the European Union made a commitment to spend 20% of its climate budget years and years ago.  We are not keeping that commitment, and the budget you are proposing is no exception. It takes billions more to reach this goal. It is said everywhere that there is a climate emergency, that young people are mobilizing in the streets. However, the draft budget that you are proposing is below the commitment you made years ago. That is why the European Parliament is on a position that requires an additional EUR 2 billion for climate in this budget, so that we are getting as close as possible to the commitment we made. Two billion euros for 500 million Europeans, that's four euros per European.  When we look at the climate emergency, when we look at the mobilization of young people, I would be really desperate that, on the Commission's side and on the Council side, we would not listen to this voice, that we do not listen to the voice of Parliament and that we have to fight for the two billion euros more for the climate that should be self-evident. , in the context we know.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, as Chair of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), I would like to express my support for the compromise package, which includes many of the priorities brought forward by our committee. This is the last budget under the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MMF) and we have to maximise allocations for research, for infrastructure, for digitalisation and for small and medium-sized enterprises in order to set an ambitious framework for the new financial period. I want to thank Commissioner Oettinger for making the case for us, because it’s absolutely obvious that if we want to succeed in the future we need the research programmes well financed, and we have, at this stage, Horizon 2020 and COSME oversubscribed. We have the Flexibility Instrument to reallocate unused funds on this programme, so we need to make the best of that. Last but not least, the Connecting Europe Facility is a very successful programme needed for infrastructure. It goes very well with the Investment Plan, creating added value from private resources to public funds, so we also need to see the Connecting Europe Facility well financed for the next year.

name: Svenja Hahn
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As draftsman of the opinion, I am pleased that the Committee on Budgets has largely followed the recommendations of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection for the 2020 budget, because the internal market is at the heart of the European Union. We all benefit as consumers if we can rely on common standards. And it is above all our small and medium-sized enterprises for which the internal market is a recipe for success and an elixir of life. Therefore, if we build the internal market, let us break down barriers from national protectionism and ensure fair competition! Get rid of bureaucratic barriers that hinder our free movement of goods, capital, services, labour, and invest boldly in the digital future! Let us turn the Digital Single Market from a buzzword to a priority in the budget! One thing is clear: investment in the internal market is investment in the future of the European Union.

name: Daniel Freund
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Some may have forgotten, but the EU has signed the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, CO2 emissions in the transport sector continue to rise, and I cannot at least take a real plan to stop this development from the 2020 draft budget. We have to ask ourselves: how do we find an alternative for diesel, for petrol and for kerosene? At least not by continuing to slash an already small transport budget and hoping for a miracle otherwise. If we want to comply with the Paris Agreement without a total traffic collapse, we need a complete overhaul of our transport. We should actually set the course for this now, invest now, change laws now. We need safe and fast cycle lanes, we need better public transport, we need Europe-wide night train networks, we need electric car charging stations. Unfortunately, all this is much, far too little in this draft budget and unfortunately does not meet the challenge, particularly in the transport sector.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the next budget has the ambitious objective of acting as a bridge with the future of the Union, providing concrete added value and responding to the demands of citizens, businesses, workers and consumers.  Parliament calls for a qualitative leap to achieve this objective and to provide a solid starting point for the launch of the new generation of priority programmes and policies for the Union. Among these priorities, Commissioner, we cannot forget the extraordinary role played by the common agricultural policy in the process of European integration. We will therefore not accept cuts in the agricultural policy budget, on the contrary, we are asking you to stand shoulder to shoulder with our agricultural and food businesses which, once again, are the victims of trade reprisals decided by others, as our rapporteur, Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, has already mentioned.  We therefore call for a commitment to ensure that in the next conciliation period all measures, such as the promotion of our products on foreign markets, are financed and strengthened, which are necessary to mitigate the impact of the very heavy duties imposed by the United States on our companies.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Mr President, Commissioner, with regard to the Committee on Fisheries, we know that, for the next budget in 2020, the necessary measures, in terms of the fisheries sector, we want them to be sustainable. We know that for a common fisheries policy to be effectively achieved we will have to have a sufficient budget to be able to implement it. Thus, we believe it is necessary to strike a balance between environmental priorities, between the viability of the fishing sector and also the livelihood of coastal communities.  Effective fisheries management only exists if we have concrete, solid and also reliable data. Union funds should be increased from the point of view of data collection, scientific research. What's the point? In addition to improving the assessment of fish stocks and enabling a study of the impact of climate change and pollution on these stocks.  We need to take into account partnership agreements in the field of sustainable policy and, in general terms, the external dimension of fisheries policy so that there are adequate budgetary provisions for 2020. Finally, a note only for the European aquaculture sector whose good performance can be key to reducing the Union's dependence on imports of fishery products.

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At the end of this week, the Council will meet in Luxembourg to adopt conclusions on the so-called economy of well-being. The draft states that people and their well-being should be placed more at the centre of policy. It is essential that well-being is taken into account in all policy areas, that people can reach their full potential and enjoy their fundamental rights. In particular, the aim is to ensure access for all to public services, including education, training and lifelong learning. Dear Council! If you adopt these conclusions on Thursday, you will then be able to demonstrate how serious you are about putting people's well-being at the centre of your life: show coherence and take back your planned cuts in policies that are so important for the well-being of citizens! Clear the way for investment in people and social cohesion! Follow Parliament's position: more money for Erasmus+, more money for Creative Europe and more money for the Europe for Citizens programme.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President, in the LIBE committee, the work was particularly effective and relatively consensual. The various political groups and shadow rapporteurs have all made efforts to reach a balanced opinion. So we thank you for taking that into account.  In particular, I urge you to follow the vote which took place in the LIBE committee and then in the BUDG committee in favour of a budget line for rescue operations at sea. Europe has a humanitarian responsibility and a moral duty to rescue those at risk, rather than criminalising NGOs which are currently replacing the European Union and states in this role. This would be the first time that such a budget line would be adopted in plenary.  The Member States of the European Union must take responsibility for preventing people from dying in the Mediterranean, as we have often said in this Chamber since I was elected last May. So I think this budget should be followed without any problems. This includes preventing this responsibility from weighing solely, from a financial and logistical point of view, on the states that are the places of arrival of migrants. It is therefore also a measure of justice between the different Member States.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Mr Günther, for the work you have done and for the cooperation we have had over the last ten years.  We are pleased with the Commission's attempts to increase investment to inform citizens in the 2020 budget, we are not satisfied with the Council's attempts to cut funding. Once again, the Council is backing down and not allowing us to cut the distances that exist between us and the citizens, between the European institutions and the citizens. It is essential, for example, to finance the transparency register, so that there can be more interinstitutional cooperation, just as it is right to finance all the programmes that help citizens to learn more about what the European institutions are doing.  In conclusion, I believe that it should also be decided to give substantial funding to the Conference on the Future of Europe, which cannot be something that concerns only the European Commission, but something that concerns all the Community institutions. If we want to be ambitious and want to give Europe a political role in the world, we must ensure that this conference is a real success.

name: Frances Fitzgerald
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, let me thank the rapporteurs for the work that they have both done. I think it’s been very intensive and very interesting. We’ve heard very broad macro points, both from the Commissioner and the Minister here today, that are important. Rather than thinking of gender equality as the last in the committees (which is somewhat stereotyped, I have to say), but rather than thinking of it in that manner, let us think about how gender equality can be mainstreamed across all of the committees and how that lens needs to be seen within each of the committees here. That’s very important. Clearly, this is the last year of the current Multiannual Financial Framework, and we are preparing for the transition to an inclusive Europe and dealing with sustainable development goals on the 2030 agenda. As the rapporteur for the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), I put in various amendments. I have to say I would like to see, for example, the pilot project on gender equality being accepted, because I think that’s very important – that we look at all of these financial instruments with a gender lens and really analyse what is happening in the different programmes from that perspective. I think that’s really important. The amendments we put in were agreed across the FEMM Committee, and they deal with very important issues in relation to gender violence and particularly, for example, in relation to women in IT, because what we do know is that there is a huge gender gap emerging there, and we need to consider that very seriously. So I would ask that we look again at some of these amendments and make sure that they are incorporated, because they are markers of how seriously we take equality. I’ve always been inspired by the way the European Union, the European Parliament and Council deal with equality. But let’s make sure we continue.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, I have a few questions to address in this debate to the Council, a Council which cuts EUR 1 500 million from the Commission's proposal; 413 million is at Horizon 2020.  My first question: do you think Horizon 2020, a research programme, is not important? Do you think this program has no absorption capacity? The Commission's figures benumber any difficulty in absorbing this programme. How is it acceptable to cut into the Connecting Europe Facility, cut into important funds for integration? How can you also cut back on a successful programme such as the Juncker Plan, EFSI? A posture you don't understand. Another question for the Council: there are EUR 280 million that have not been used, which has not been given authorisation and which can be used for research. It is flexibility, it is 15.3 and the question is: is the Council available to use this flexibility, to use the possibility that what has not been used could be used in the field of research?  The European Union budget has enormous added value. It's small, but it's very important. All citizens should know that only 7% is for operating expenses. 93% of this budget is for investment, an investment that is essential, where all Member States benefit from the budget.  I expect the Council's readiness for an agreement. But with this attitude, I see that there will be a great difficulty for Parliament to reach an agreement with the Council which it always seeks to reduce and which then says it needs margins. And the last question is, what do you want so many margins for? Are you predicting some hecatombe, some catastrophe for next year, of unpredictable consequences and with a huge dimension? These questions remain and I also hope answers and that the negotiations can continue. On our side there is always loyalty and good faith.

name: Pierre Larrouturou
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, my friends, what is our ambition for Europe? If we had a great ambition, we would have a big budget today. When Kennedy says, "We choose to go to the moon," he really decided. And Kennedy will multiply NASA's budget by 15- by 15! - create 400,000 jobs and the United States wins the moon.  Today, it is not a question of winning the moon, it is about saving the earth or saving humanity on earth. Why are we not more ambitious in our budget? We're talking about Green New Deal, in reference to Roosevelt's New Deal. Very well. But Roosevelt gave himself the means of his New Deal, which created millions of jobs. When he came to power, Roosevelt tripled the federal budget in four years. Then, a few years later, to win the war, he multiplied the U.S. budget fourfold. Roosevelt is old and paralyzed, but he will multiply the federal budget by 12 by financing it through fair taxation and intelligent use of central bank money. There was no disaster. Were Kennedy and Roosevelt crazy? Did Kennedy and Roosevelt ruin their country? No, of course not. We all remember that they were visionary and courageous leaders.  And we, Europe, what are we waiting for, my friends? What are we waiting for? Building a real budget is not that complicated. I remember what Jacques Delors said to find new resources. It is possible to have a more ambitious budget without asking member states for their efforts, without asking citizens for their efforts. When I was a kid, the income tax was 45%! Now, because of European tax competition, it has fallen to 20%. Jacques Delors said that a European tax on profits was needed. Even with a tax of only 5% on average, and without affecting small businesses, we could have an additional $100 billion budget to save the climate and create massive jobs in all of our territories. So, of course, the Social Democratic Group will vote for this budget. It is a very good compromise, there is no doubt about it. Thank you Monika, thank you Eider, thank you Rasmus, thank you Clotilde, with whom we negotiated. We will vote on this budget, we will fight for the Council to accept this increase in appropriations, but I hope that this is the last year that we will vote on such a small budget. The Social Democratic Group will do everything in its way to find new resources for a more ambitious budget for human dignity and the protection of the planet.

name: Clotilde Armand
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will not talk today about the figures behind the 2020 budget. I will talk about the policy that every European budget must defend. Too often i have heard in Brussels interpretations of the budget in the sense of contributor and beneficiary. Too often we reduce all budget discussions to who pays and who receives. It is an approach that lacks economic reality and, in particular, the objective for which a European budget has been created.  We are committed to building a unified, prosperous continent with convergent and environmentally friendly economies. Indeed, the countries in the east are favoured for some investments of European public money, but the common market offers many other advantages to the net contributing states. Let's look at trade balances, capital flows. These advantages are much more important than budget lines. It's not only unfair to always talk about contributors and beneficiaries, but it's really dangerous for our future.  Let's take Britain's example. Its leaders have been talking for decades in terms of gain and loss in relation to the European budget. They did not send a strong message highlighting the economic benefits of membership of the common market, the volume of private financial flows. They didn't want to look at the whole economic picture. It's sad when a part of the population knows only what they offer and not what they get.  I wish that through the 2020 budget we would send a clear message. Yes, we want a more ambitious budget. Yes, we want to respect environmental commitments, to strengthen (words that are not understood) technical assistance and not to leave, for example, a newly created institution such as the European Public Prosecutor's Office without sufficient funds. I hope to find the same ambitions for all European decision-makers. The citizens who voted for us need to know that we have well-defined objectives. We cannot have a strong Europe and always argue about the budget.

name: Rasmus Andresen
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We in the European Parliament are ready to invest in our future. We are ready to give the European Union a very concrete future with this budget. Specifically, for example, for young adults such as 26-year-old Greek Vasili, who, after completing her studies in Athens, was in danger of becoming unemployed, but was made fit for the labour market by youth jobless initiatives and other programmes by the European Union. We are therefore pleased that, in a compromise with many other groups, we have succeeded in providing EUR 500 million more for the fight against youth unemployment and for more youth exchanges. We believe that this is a very important sign. We Greens are also pleased that we have succeeded among The Members in agreeing EUR 2.1 billion more for climate and environmental investment, because this money is also urgently needed, and it helps in a very concrete way, for example in the fight for clean air. In Bulgaria alone, there are more than two million people who suffer from bad air, such as children who have breathing problems. That is precisely why it is important that we act and that we have a budget that meets the demands of our time. We should also assume this responsibility in the case of sea rescue. We have twice voted by a narrow majority in the Committee on Budgets in favour of a European maritime rescue programme. We Greens hope that our motion will also be adopted here tomorrow. We as a Parliament are ready. And now it is up to the Council to let this eternal obstructionist attitude and these eternal Sunday speeches be and also to be willing to invest with us. After all, just talking about climate protection, just talking about doing something about youth unemployment, is no longer enough. Come on our boat and fight with us!

name: Hélène Laporte
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, EUR 170.9 billion is the amount of the 2020 European budget proposed by the two EPP and Socialist co-workers. How do you justify a 3% increase in the European budget compared to 2019, when the inflation rate and GDP growth rate in the European Union do not exceed 2%? Why is the European Union not applying the same budgetary rigour that it imposes on its Member States and, above all, why do you not anticipate Brexit now, which will result in a shortfall of EUR 5 billion for the European Union? These are all questions that will remain unanswered because, in your mind, everything is a pretext for the endless increase in the European budget. MEPs from the National Rally will vote against this budgetary inflation.  The way in which European money is spent remains highly critical. For example, I will mention, in particular, aid to Turkey for border protection, with EUR 5.6 billion already paid, and we see the result, the pre-accession aid instrument to help the countries applying for entry into the European Union, the European External Action Service, as if the European Union had any diplomatic legitimacy, but also an explosion of communication spending.  Finally, I would like to draw the attention of our compatriots to a very specific point, namely the future reform of Dublin IV, which will give every migrant the opportunity to apply for asylum in the country of their choice. Faced with the blocking of the Member States, the Council has proposed to transfer to the reserve the EUR 400 million initially allocated for this purpose, a transfer which you opposed in this budget resolution. I will just remind my colleagues that the Council embodies the voices of national interests and that it would be good to give it its rightful place.

name: Bogdan Rzońca
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The prepared budget is intended to increase the number and creation of jobs, to boost economic growth, to support private investment. The 2020 budget should support EU cohesion, agriculture and competitiveness. Migration and security are key to the Union budget. The draft budget for 2020 includes improving the management of the internal and external dimensions of migration and the protection of the external borders. It also aims to strengthen the global dimension of Europe by addressing the root causes of migration in countries of origin and transit. The promotion of sustainable development will also guide activities carried out within the european Union budget outside the Union, in neighbouring countries. We support such actions. It is a transition and continuity budget supporting the achievements of the Union in recent years and the priorities of the current programmes. We believe that this is also a good budget for the start of the new Multiannual Financial Framework.  The ECR considers that the results of the vote in the Committee on Budgets have been good and the budget is worth supporting. Our priorities, namely the ECR, i.e. increased allocations to the draft budget for the Connecting Europe Facility (transport and energy) and greater allocations for Frontex and Europol, as well as an increase in erasmus funding, make it possible for us to support this budget. As an ECR, we support all cases of reallocation in relation to the draft budget presented by the European Commission. This compromise has a good place to support agriculture.  We would just like this budget to be fixed in time and to avoid the mistakes of the past years, when financial dedications were not allocated in time and there were all sorts of backlogs that caused difficulties for beneficiaries.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Tiliikainen, Mr Oettinger, last time we spoke a month ago about the 2020 budget, of the 53 speakers who spoke here in plenary, from the European Parliament, not one supported the Council's proposals cutting critical funds, causing disagreement not only from the European Parliament, but also from the Commission. We cannot accept cuts in the funds for regional and social cohesion, for the creation of youth employment, for technological renewal, for Horizon 2020, to tackle the climate crisis.  And today we had a development: they applauded the cuts proposed by the extreme right and the supporters of Brexit, those who want the break-up of the European Union. Does that satisfy you? A weak budget that constantly cuts, reinforces inequalities, reinforces divergences and serves the political plans of those who want the break-up of the European Union. But those who voted in the European elections, especially the young people with their increased participation, who want a better and better Europe, with better jobs, with technological renewal, with a response to the environmental crisis, want a Europe that is a pioneer in technology, in the environment, but that supports both the farmer and the countries from the East that have entered the European Union and the countries of the European South, do not want any more austerity and further cuts. Therefore, you have before you a large majority in the European Parliament asking you to finally understand that the European Parliament is a co-legislator and that, if the European Parliament does not say 'yes', no agreement will be found. And in order for there to be an agreement, the Council - instead of finding it between you - must move even further than the Commission's proposals in order to get closer to the European Parliament's proposals.

name: Rupert Lowe (NI).
text: – Madam President, ‘He who does not economise has to agonise’ – so said Confucius. In my short time in this Parliament, I have experienced a new sensation – not having to worry about how much anything costs. Offices, equipment, travel, chauffeurs, public relations, every possible trapping of power, provided with no expense spared. We even run not two but three separate Parliament buildings. The carbon footprint is staggering, avoidable and flies in the face of wisdom. Our 500 million constituents fund this largesse, while they are ground into poverty by the unsustainable euro experiment. Quantitative easing supports the unsupportable. It results in negative interest rates, undermining the very foundation of capitalism. It also creates a massive contingent risk as pensioners are forced to chase higher income. Those who try to leave the club or reform it are punished. Catalans, Gilets Jaunes and UK Brexiteers are sacrificed on the undemocratic altar of the post-war plan to create a European super-state. As the digital revolution releases the individual, Confucius is proven right: Europe will agonise at leisure unless logic triumphs over largesse.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. This is the last year of this perspective, and for the European Parliament, the last year of this perspective is important because it sets the direction for the next perspective. What we will get from 2020 will have a major impact on the way we operate after 2020.  Today we have three proposals on the table: the European Commission, the Council and Parliament. They are fundamentally different, not only in terms of numbers, because we do not want to talk only about the amount of the budget. We want to talk about its content – what we want to spend money on, how much it will cost – so we are making a proposal that relates to specific actions, not numbers.  We have the impression that the Council's action is rather accounting, technical, financial. Parliament, on the other hand, is wondering what we want to spend the money on, what is needed, which will not only be needed in 2020, but what we will need in 2021 and beyond. That is why this discussion is of great importance to us, because it concerns many years, not just 2020. And in this case, as co-decision-making in the codecision process, we will be very tough.

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there are two pillars of the general budget that we are about to approve, on the one hand, work, growth, the social dimension, and on the other, the environment, the fight against climate change.  Here, the red thread that unites these two great goals are certainly the younger generation. It is they who have asked us to take exceptional measures for climate change and it is they who need measures and tools to enter the labour market, to grow, to train, to be able to see their talents and skills satisfied.  So, as Socialists, we welcome the fact that an additional EUR 363 million has been allocated by Parliament to guarantee young people, a very important instrument which makes it possible to provide training and to give access to the labour market. Five million young people in Europe are included in this tool every year. Three and a half million find an opportunity to access their future. Let's go on like this, look at a balance sheet that is the photography of the younger generation and they are the ones who look up there, who can really have a real hope for their future.

name: Olivier Chastel (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we want an ambitious budget for the Union, we must be united behind the draft report of our two rapporteurs, whose work I welcome here, of course, and vote overwhelmingly for the european Union's draft general budget for 2020. In view of last week's events and its negative impact on the negotiations on the European Union budget, the use of the provisional twelfths should not be excluded, which implies the reproduction of the current budget in monthly increments, and which would further delay the realisation of our ambitions, our priorities, whether climatic, social or economic. I am thinking here of the Horizon 2020 programme, the mechanism for interconnection in Europe, Erasmus, youth employment and especially the youth employment initiative. Similarly, the Council, in rejecting all our proposals at the moment, does not seem to want to seek the ambitious compromise.  By voting overwhelmingly tomorrow, we are sending a strong political signal of unity for a large budget to respond quickly to today's emergencies and to meet the concerns of our citizens for the climate, the youth, the new economy. This increase of 2.7 billion is a tangible sign of our desire to implement a new generation of policies and programmes for the European Union.

name: Alexandra Geese (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With this budgetary position for 2020, we are starting to make our continent fit for the future. More money for the much-needed protection of our climate, more money to combat youth unemployment, more money for research and science, but also more money for European values and thus also for saving people fleeing war and persecution across the Mediterranean. If Europe wants to stand up for human rights in the world, we need at least the maritime rescue programme, for which we are laying a first financial basis in this budget. Our citizens – and I say this in particular to the Christian Democrat Group in this House – Christians no longer want to see desperate people drown ingesly in the Mediterranean, like the children who died a few days ago off Lampedusa. Europe can do more! Support our motion on maritime rescue, which has already twice won a majority in the Committee on Budgets.

name: Ivan David (ID).
text: – Madam President, I want to express here my fundamental dissatisfaction with the fall in agricultural expenditure, without at the same time adjusting the disproportionality in support for farmers in individual countries. On the contrary, according to the forthcoming adjustment, the differences risk deepening. The European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has clearly defined the decline in agricultural and rural expenditure. Support for agriculture and rural areas has declined by 10% to EUR 560 million in favour of growing support for immigration. It is proposed to increase payments to Turkey for the support of immigrants on Turkish territory, at a time when Turkey is illegally driving out the population in the north of Syria through illegal military activity and declaring that it wants to place a proportion of immigrants in such conquered territories that lack the necessary infrastructure. These are some of the reasons why we cannot support the European Union's draft budget for 2020.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt (ECR).
text: – Mr President, 2020 is the last year of the current multiannual budget, a multiannual budget that was adopted in 2013. Negotiations for the new multianne financial framework are in full swing. That is why Parliament sees the 2020 budget as a bridge to the next planning period. The agreement reached by the Committee on Budgets for 2020 looks ahead. I would very much like to thank rapporteurs Gardiazabal Rubial and Hohlmeier for the wonderful work they have done. The agreement seeks to respond to the many challenges ahead. This means that more needs to be done in terms of climate change. The EU's budgetary efforts must also be made in the field of research and development of sustainable technologies to improve competitiveness. The agreement also calls for greater attention to be paid to digitisation and support for young people. Furthermore, the challenges of security and migration and so many other challenges are also really at stake. I look forward to the parliamentary approval of the European Parliament's position for the 2020 budget. As a member of the European Parliament's negotiating team, I will do everything in my power to consistently defend the positions adopted here.  I promise you that I will work as a member of that team to achieve an outcome that addresses the concerns of this Parliament, and especially of the citizens of Europe.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, if, as the resolution we are voting on tomorrow, this budget should be a starting point for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, then we can say that we are getting off to a bad start.  It is true that this budget is determined by a Multiannual Financial Framework, the current, extremely short, the lowest ever and fundamentally wrong in relation to its priorities, a problem that will tend to worsen from 2021. If the budget is only 1% of the Gross National Income of all Member States, it should be stressed that only just over a third of this value is earmarked for economic, social and territorial cohesion, while gaining space and financing security policies, militarism, external interventionism, among others. Despite the overall negative assessment we make of this budget, we have not given up on proposals to which I want to draw your attention and, if approved, will represent improvements, one-off of course, but important: strengthening the Youth Employment initiative, disaster assistance, supporting the productive sectors and SMEs, among others, in addition to the creation of pilot projects in the field of climate change , adaptation to drought, in the field of maternal and child health, among others.

name: Milan Uhrík (NI).
text: – Madam President, I have studied the draft budget very carefully. What struck me the most is that, from the EUR 154 billion budget, EUR 10 billion goes again to bureaucracy, to administration. When you think about it, it's a huge make-up for people, especially from small countries. After all, such Slovaks have to work for ten years and pay membership fees to the Union to feed the entire bureaucratic apparatus for one year. I also do not understand why twice as much money goes to the Asylum and Migration Fund as to frontex border guards. And on the other, 300 million for the aforementioned Turkey. It really does look like you don't want to solve the immigration crisis, but on the contrary. And you also probably want to feed on those regional differences, because again we have EUR 43 billion in subsidies for agriculture, most of which will go back to the big countries. Farmers from countries as small as those in Central Europe simply do not have a chance to compete with those Western farmers in such unfair conditions. They are going bankrupt and our shops have to import food from abroad. Please note, then, that the mood towards the European Union is deteriorating.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab By participating in the annual budgetary procedure, you have a strong impression of déjà vu, and this is because the annual procedure abounds in something called in the football language – my name entitles me to do so – 'fixed fragments of the game'. The Commission's initial proposal does not come from the ceiling, it is a recognition of next year's needs. Then the Council cuts – rather automatically, rather across the board, sometimes or often denying its own statements. Parliament is restoring the draft budget, but it goes further, this year highlighting the climate priorities – EUR 2.7 billion above the Commission's initial proposal. It promises to be an interesting concivion, but i have the impression – because I have participated in conciving on several occasions – that if this concige lengthens excessively, it does not work well for the image of all the European institutions, because the beneficiaries want consensus, not an interinstitutional quarrel, they want predictability.  This is the last annual budget of this financial perspective, which I have been fortunate and pleased to design for 2014-2020, so everyone is watching today's annual struggles in terms of a much more important battle over multiannual budgets, and even more so the opportunities of the Financial Regulation such as Article 15(3) must be exploited to ensure maximum flexibility on the eve of the great budget battle.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, Commissioner Oettinger, Ministers, the budget proposal we are debating is less than necessary and requires modifications. Meanwhile, in the next hundred days, the Commission will present the Climate Law. It is a priority for the European Union to finance a fair transition to a carbon-neutral economy on the basis of the highest social justice criteria. My point is simple and I put it because I think we always have to learn. For the next Financial Framework 2021-2027, what we have on the table on the Commission's side, and now the Council, is translated into annual budgets even lower than this year 2020 and this will make it truly unrealistic to meet expectations and commitments. The European Commission and the Council, on the one hand, in view of the political commitments made and, on the other hand, the necessary changes to the 2020 budget proposal to be adopted by this House, should adjust their positions to the next Multiannual Financial Framework and bring it closer to the real needs and position of Parliament.

name: Valerie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, tomorrow Parliament will defend the obvious: the fulfily of our commitments. While the European Union has set a target of allocating 20% of its budget to climate protection between 2014 and 2020, the Council, for the last year, is cutting the funding needed to meet this target. Let me raise an unfortunately recurring contradiction here. Every year, states assign great responsibilities to Europe, which must enable us to fight climate change, develop a knowledge-based economy, strengthen the competitiveness of our businesses or help our young people. But every year, the same game, the same acts. The Council refrains from supporting climate-related spending, cuts research, cuts aid for access to SME financing, and hits the programme to improve youth employment head-on.  Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this tartufferie has only lasted too long. It is the result of the control of the states over our budget. Let us put an end to this, let us no longer expect the States to finance almost the Union's budget on their own, let us finally provide new resources!

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We need a strong EU budget for the challenges of the future: the implementation of the Paris climate agreement, the construction of a European social union and the fight against youth unemployment. We can no longer solve global problems at national level, and we cannot get more Europe with less money. That is why we are also calling for an urgent call for a system of own resources to be switched to and against the national haggling of the Member States. The resolution on the 2020 budget contains massive improvements. We have already heard it: EUR 2 billion more for climate protection, EUR 500 million more for young people, a fund for maritime rescue. However, there are also serious omissions in this budget. For example, there is a lack of implementation of gender mainstreaming and gender budgeting, even though all the EU institutions are committed to this. In other words, we need much more action here than words.  As a Member of parliament from a military-neutral country, it is also very regrettable to me that, especially at a time when social policy priorities are being cut, the arms sector receives massive financial injections. We need disarmament instead of armament and climate and social billions instead of arms billions.

name: Joachim Kuhs (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Are we aware that the 2020 budget is worth a total of almost EUR 170 billion? That is taxpayers' money, and we must use this money sparingly and economically. That is our mission, which is why we were elected. And, of course, it makes sense for us to spend money on education, on research, and also on combating abuse, but if we do not save on the very large items that we have in the budget, if we do not cut back, then we have no room for manoeuvre to have money for the sensible programmes. That is why I would simply like to remind you and ask you to remember the responsibility you have as elected representatives, as elected representatives, who spend the money on their citizens, on taxpayers.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In the next stage of the budgetary procedure, following the votes in the Committee on Budgets on more than 1300 amendments, commitment appropriations are expected to increase by almost €2.7 billion compared to the Commission's proposal, amounting to €170 billion, with payment appropriations expected to amount to around €160 billion. In particular, the proposal to significantly increase funding for the Youth Initiative by €360 million, as well as Horizon 2020, the proposal to eliminate cuts to agricultural producer organisations and the proposal to increase funding for Europol and Frontex should be highlighted in particular.  Once again, however, I would like to emphasise that, although payment appropriations have increased by more than EUR 5 billion compared to this year, as the 2020 budget is the last year of the seven-year financial perspective, these measures may prove too small, as the implementation of projects under both cohesion and rural development will be accelerated. The draft budget was based on conservative assumptions. By contrast, the margin of free payment appropriations is more than €20 billion. The backlog of payments that we have had and which amounted to more than EUR 30 billion at its peak may therefore be repeated.

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, the European market creates inequalities, as we know. Capital goes where it can make the most profit in the least amount of time, and behind that there are economic deserts, industrial deserts. There is a gap between countries, between regions and between workers.  In recent years, some countries such as Lithuania, Latvia, Bulgaria and Romania have lost between 15 and 25% of their population. It's huge! In Belgium, we saw what happened with the steel industry, with Caterpillar, with ArcelorMittal, with the automotive industry - I am thinking of Ford Genk.  In the face of all this, the European budget could be, at least, a sparadrap that helps a little. And there's money! We see today that we have budget margins. On the one hand, we have budgetary margins and, on the other hand, we have a social emergency. And you say we don't want to use them? There, as the other would say, "the calculations are not good, Kevin, the calculations are not good". We want glitter. Where are they? And we want a lot more.

name: Annunziata Mary Rees-Mogg (NI).
text: – Madam President, since the 1700s it has been argued that there should be no taxation without representation. I very much hope that this will be my final opportunity to speak in this democratic façade of a Chamber. I also hope that this historic principle will be respected. If the United Kingdom leaves this technocracy in the near future, it is entirely unreasonable to expect British taxpayers to continue to fund initiatives over which they have no say. In 1990, a former British Prime Minister said to the Commission President, Monsieur Delors, ‘No, no, no’. She was right then, on further integration, and I say the same with regard to budget contributions after we leave. The oft-ignored voters of the nation states that make up the European Union, and those that leave, cannot and should not be plundered. The electors of the East Midlands asked for respect. I demand it. Democracy must be respected.

name: Niclas Herbst (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I find it somewhat humorous to have someone who thinks it is good that a Parliament should be placed on compulsory leave for five weeks, to describe this Chamber as non-democratic. But that is only marginally, because it is supposed to be about the budget. We must also say to those who say 'this is just a matter of distributing money in some way': no, it is about European added value. This must be said time and again to the Member States. There are so many examples that have already been mentioned here, from the Connecting Europe Facility to Horizon 2020, where it is not just a question of who is spending the money, but of the fact that it is better if we do it together than if the nation states do it.
