Let me give another example, very striking: Galileo. I do not believe that Finland alone would be able to set up such a satellite system. And even after Brexit, the British want to continue to participate. So we see that it makes sense. And then, unfortunately, it makes no sense for, on the other hand, after billions have already been invested, to be cut there in small parts of the millions in order to destroy this added value. I appeal to everyone: let us see this added value together. There are many other examples. And a second principle, which we as a Parliament must also respect here, is very important: we must not speak differently on Mondays than we speak on Tuesdays in the budget debate. Last night, for example, we discussed anti-Semitism very intensively, and it is good that we, as the European Union, also promote textbooks in Palestine, but please do not promote those in which anti-Semitic acts and demands are made. We need to get better at that. Next time we have the chance to do so. We must not speak differently on Mondays than we did on Tuesdays, and we as a Parliament must take our own noses.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The 513 million citizens and citizens of the European Union are once again looking forward to the new EU budget and once again counting on the Values of the European Union, which my speaker spoke about, but also some of the principles on which we have agreed, to be implemented. That we politicians who decide the future of the European Union will stick to our priorities. Once again, unfortunately, they will be disappointed. Once again, the priorities that we have chosen, the values that we were supposed to defend, will unfortunately not be achieved.  I regret to say that in this budget we will once again run out of money to fight climate catastrophe – not climate change, but climate catastrophe. In Poland, the country I represent, 45,000 people die every year from a climate catastrophe. It is as if a medium-sized city disappears every year in the European Union. Once again, this budget will run out of money to level the playing field for young people. There are regions in Europe where there is a shortage of jobs for 40-50% of young people. Yesterday we had a debate about radicalism. When someone asks where radicalism comes from, it is from such omissions. I therefore call for us to make a budget in the future that will level the playing field and not leave people behind.

name: Nils Torvalds (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for First, a small comment on what we just heard from Mrs Rees-Mogg. In 1761, a citizen in the 14 colonies expressed his disgust by the words 'no taxation without representation'. Why did he say it? He said it because the British Parliament taxed him. So you should just check your history. It's not... (Shouting by some Members) They have a chequered history, that's right. Then back to my Swedish tongue. When I came to Parliament seven years ago and tried to understand this strange budget, we had a system where promises are made and then eventually create a deficit that we will now have to deal with in the last budget for the period.  That is the main point of the negotiation we are trying to conduct with the Finnish Presidency. I hope that Secretary of State Tiilikainen also understands the complex EU budget we have and understands that now it has to be some money. Tiilikainen has understood this before, so it does not also make it this time.

name: n/a
text: "Thank you very much, Fellow Member. You would like to receive an immediate blue card question from Congresswoman Rees-Mogg. Accept? Ok. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that there are 30 seconds available.

name: Nils Torvalds (Renew).
text: – Madam President, as an exception I will accept a blue card from those.

name: Annunziata Mary Rees-Mogg (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting, and thank you for the history lesson, that we did know our own country’s history, and we recall that in 1776 the Americans decided we were so unrepresentative of their best interests and real democracy of any description, that we did tax without... that... (Interruption by the President)

name: President. –
text: The question – the blue card is a question.

name: Annunziata Mary Rees-Mogg (NI)
text: blue-card question. – ...they decided to leave. Can you dispute the concept that America has thrived since leaving an undemocratic union?

name: Nils Torvalds (Renew)
text: blue-card answer. – Lately I have been having fun reading Mr Trump’s tweets, and I’m not very sure that they are thriving.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in today's debate we are dealing with the budget lines and how European taxpayers' money will be used in the coming years.  The European Commission is, in words, showing solidarity and attentive to the social inclusion of people with disabilities. Well, the figures say something else. For example, for the Erasmus programme, attention must be paid to percentages and not to figures per se. For the period 2014-2020, the Erasmus programme has a budget of 14.7 billion, with 264.6 million euros for the social inclusion of disabled people through sport, that is, a percentage of 1.8% of the global budget. Let us now turn to the analysis of the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework: the Erasmus budget provides for a budget of EUR 30 billion, with EUR 550 million for sport. Now, taking a brief calculation, it turns out that the percentage dedicated to sport and the social inclusion of disabled people through sport remains 1.8% of the total budget.  Let the citizens of Europe know, therefore, that the European Commission only sympathises with words and not with deeds. This is not funding, it is just alms.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I have been working with two agencies within the ITRE Committee for a long time. The Galileo satellite navigation project is approaching full constellation and it is imperative to maintain a high level of security. And that's not going to happen without more people and resources for the GSA. In addition, the Agency must prepare for the extension of competences under the European Union's space programme.  The second agency is the BEREC Office. It is the smallest agency that has been undersized for a long time. In the light of new tasks for telecommunications regulators, the introduction of 5G, etc., this agency also needs to be strengthened.   Commissioner, Mr Oettinger, I personally thank you very much for your many years of cooperation and I believe that these small budget increases will be enforced in the framework of negotiations with the Council and the Commission.

name: Jonathan Bullock (NI).
text: – Madam President, the EU budget for the next year assumes a full contribution from the UK of around GBP 13 billion for 2020, yet it is now over three years since Britain voted to leave the EU. Boris Johnson has reheated Theresa May’s deal and would commit the UK to paying full budget contributions, without proper representations, in 2020. The Treaty would also sign us up to the liabilities of the European Investment Bank, which could amount to hundreds of billions if it were ever to collapse. The proposed treaty also divides the UK with a customs boundary in the Irish Sea. This is a clear breach of the UK government commitment to a joint report in 2017 to allow unfettered access to the market in Great Britain for Northern Ireland businesses. The UK’s fed up with paying billions to the EU. We voted to leave, and it is becoming clear that a deal, whether it be Theresa May’s or Boris’s, is not going to get through Parliament. So it’s time to shake hands on a clean-break Brexit. Only then will the decision of 17.4 million people be implemented and democracy respected.

name: Karlo Ressler (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, the budget is a kind of magical ingredient that turns all declared political goals into a real reality. Therefore, in addition to investing in the modernisation of Europe, we must not in any way ignore the balanced regional development of all corners of the European Union as one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union. The last budget of the Multiannual Framework must respond to the expectations of our voters. Policies that respond to the demographic, technological and climate change we are witnessing are needed. More funding is needed for Erasmus+, as one of Europe's most successful programmes, further support is needed for both entrepreneurship and innovation and research, but also to increase security and cope with migration. With next year's budget, we must continue to build a modern, but also a solidarity-like Europe, a next-generation Europe, but at the same time a Europe that does not neglect its traditional successful policies and reduces regional disparities.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I look forward to a budget negotiation where the Commission acts as a genuine honest broker, and we come out at the end of the deal with a clearly documented agreement this year that makes it absolutely clear what that agreement is, because it’s essential that the budget authority works together well. But let’s be clear about what we’re talking about in this budget. Over the period of this Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the European Union budget has reduced by 3.5% in real terms. It is equivalent to slightly less than one percent of GNI. The rest of public expenditure in the United Kingdom, above that 1%, is 39%. This is one 40th of the UK’s public expenditure. Because we achieve a great deal more together than we will ever achieve as individual Member States. We need to ramp up research, we need to ramp up innovation, and we need to ramp up investment in the areas which will gear us to a modern green economy that can address the future and address climate change adequately. Ten cents more per person per week might well be worth that.

name: Elsi Katainen (Renew).
text: – Mr President, we are all well aware of these severe budgetary pressures on next year or the longer multiannual frameworks for the future. However, it is our duty to ensure that Brexit and other budgetary pressures do not fall on agriculture and food production alone. Europeans deserve locally produced, safe, sustainable and high-quality food in the future too, and therefore the operating conditions of European farmers must continue to be safeguarded. It is therefore very important that the European Parliament does not start cutting back on agriculture in this budget, which will be the last before the forthcoming financial period. This, in turn, requires us to honestly assess whether we can avoid a fine increase in membership fees. I think 1.3% is too much, but not raising is equally unrealistic.

name: Maximilian Krah (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for What we are seeing is that, in the long term, Europe is losing touch with other prosperous areas of the world. Once again, we have a budget whose biggest item is agriculture, and where we, as a Parliament, are arguing about whether we should spend more on supporting illegal smuggling in the Mediterranean and climate measures, the effectiveness of which is controversial at best, in fact not there. It is a question of asking ourselves what we are doing for the people of Europe, and this is certainly not a debate on how we can put money into favourite ideological projects, and even less so are agricultural subsidies that only prove that more Europe is not a better life, but more bureaucracy and more alienation from producers and consumers. Ultimately, this is a lesson in the fact that something is fundamentally wrong here in this institution and that we can only regain our legitimacy if we are prepared to fundamentally rethink, not only focused on our ideologies and any left-wing firlefanz, but on common sense, respect for sovereignty and the responsibility of local communities. The draft budget does not reflect this, but I must admit that the Council is at least closer than this Parliament. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claudia Gamon (Renew)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Could you possibly specify which measures in the fight against climate change do not, in your opinion, have proven effectiveness and should therefore not be relevant to our budget?

name: Maximilian Krah (ID)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The question of climate change is the one that Europe alone cannot answer. If we in Europe were to stop emitting even a single gram of CO2 tomorrow, it would not be relevant to global warming, even on the basis of the man-made climate change hypothesis. In other words, the question is: why are we doing something that, even if we do, will not have any effect, because it is precisely the United States, because China, because India and all the other areas of the world that are prospering worldwide, will not participate in it? It is symbolic politics at the expense of workers, families and commuters, and we do not stand for this anti-social, ideology-driven policy.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Ministers, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Many of my forewcomings called confucius here, some called for a return to the logic of Aristotle, reference was made to Christianity, the fight against anti-Semitism, the fight for clean air, the climate were mentioned, and in fact we should be talking about returning to the feast of Dionysus. We're dealing with one big theater. The Commission has proposed, the Council has trimmed, the European Parliament has restored. I think the key word here should be 'compromise'. And we really should just pay attention to one aspect – my ECR colleagues have said this – so that in this theatre we do not exceed the time frame that will cause the same financial losses in the budgets and portfolios of the citizens of the European Union as we did last year. We must fit in this Feast of Dionysus so that, in the run-up to the next Multiannual Financial Framework, we can maintain the right regime and that the citizens of the European Union feel that we represent their interests well.

name: Mario Furore (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, more cuts in waste, more investment for citizens.  These are the watchwords for a 2020 budget that uses European resources effectively. The 5-Star Movement strongly supports the restoration of funds for our farmers, for research and for small and medium-sized enterprises. We must therefore look to the future. That is why we would have preferred more courage in identifying those programmes that work and those that do not benefit citizens. Those who bring added value in economic, environmental and social terms, those that must be safeguarded. I am often asked: where do we find the money? So, let us start cutting administrative expenditure, renegotiate the rents of the premises and reduce the salaries of Members and Commissioners.  Finally, I say this with reference to what is happening in Turkey: let us block the pre-accession funds in response to the aggression against the Kurdish people. I remember, the citizens outside of here are looking at us.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, we belong to those who truly, consciously, believe in a strong European Union. We believe in and support this European Union. We envision a European Union, which will have a social, developmental character, but also strong defence and security. However, in order to create a truly strong and proud European Union, we need a strong budget and a strong European budget cannot exist if the European Council continues to cut - short-sighted, blind - funds that strengthen the social face, development and security of the European Union.  We want a strong Europe, a Europe that can resist all those who attack and undermine it, because we cannot imagine our planet without a European Union for one day. Strong is the Europe that supports Horizon 2020 funds, the one that supports Erasmus+, the one that supports our small and medium-sized farmers, the one that supports all those in real need, ordinary citizens; , Cyprus. On the other hand, however, the European Union and the European budget should not give either euros to countries or those who violate the rule of law and human rights or become invaders in the 21st century; This European Union cannot, in 2019, discuss gender equality, which should be a prerequisite and a prerequisite. We must send a message from the budget that anyone who violates gender equality from the Member States must also pay a price. Finally, I would like to thank the Commissioner, Mr President-in-Chief, for his work. Oettinger, for the really substantial and impressive work he has done to have a strong budget and I hope it will also be heard by the European Council.

name: Claudia Gamon (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The 2020 budget is about nothing less than essential and essential projects for the future of Europe. Next year will be a crucial one for our community. It is about education and European cohesion, which is represented by the Erasmus programme. Every euro here is well invested in our future. It is about digitisation, it is about cancer research. These are all issues that affect Europeans in their daily lives. It is about greater cooperation on security and justice, and it is about combating climate change and the existential threat it poses. Last, but not least: what will also be an essential project for next year is the Conference on the Future of the European Union. Every week we feel more strongly that we urgently need to reform and question the institutional structure of the Union. After all, it has fallen out of time. And if we want Europe not to fall out of time, then we must change it. If the Member States were to make substantial investments impossible, it would send a fatal signal to Europeans, to young people, to the future. Europe must be able to deliver, and that requires resources.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Parliament has many drawbacks, but it certainly has the undoubted advantage that it is always in favour of a larger budget. The Council has many advantages, but it has the disadvantage of always behaving like a miser, always wanting to cut this budget. I think that a compromise is needed here, but the countries that presidency the European Union, often rich countries, should show more empathy to those countries that, for historical reasons, have not been able to find themselves in European structures early enough to build this wealth. We are in favour of this compromise as an ECR Group. We want the most important policy from our point of view to function: cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy. This debate today is a fore taste of what awaits us in this, and especially next year, when it comes to the seven-year budget for 2021-2027.

name: Martin Edward Daubney (NI).
text: – Madam President, earlier this month, at a meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Brexit Party learned that the EU had misspent EUR 4 billion of its 2018 budget – an eye-watering increase of EUR 700 million in lost funds against the previous year. Even worse – the EU had absolutely no way of detailing where its EUR 885 million in foreign aid had gone. Shockingly, I have also learned that the authority auditing the EU budget is filled with former MEPs loyal to the cause – a clear recipe for disaster and corruption. Now we have the 2020 budget before us today and we see that, despite a looming Brexit where we deal out gruel to the British, spending is set to balloon to EUR 168.3 billion – an increase of EUR 2.5 billion on 2019. With all this in mind, surely Brussels should now try to win some respect and get the shattered trust of the public back. Surely it is time for the budget to be audited externally with full transparency – because at present we cannot trust the EU with our income tax nor our VAT. With the EU, there’s no money back, no guarantee. I put it to you that ‘only fools and horses’ would sign off the 2020 budget. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – Well done, colleague, thank you for your courage in accepting the Blue Card from me. Great speech. I'm really into you.  But do you know what your speech is? You absolutely don't know the facts. Show me and tell me specifically now, answer the question: where are the 80 million that have been lost to the European budget because of corruption? Show me exactly where it is. Otherwise, colleague, I would say rather such election statements to your constituents.

name: Martin Edward Daubney (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – The money was unaccounted for, and this was fully detailed in the EU Auditors’ – Commissioner’s – report. If you haven’t got that link I can send it to you, or perhaps we could have a drink in the bar and talk about it later – in the interests of European entente cordiale?

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, thank you very much to the rapporteur, Mr Hohlmeier, and to Commissioner Oettinger for their work on this budget. The EU budget is about its added value to the Member States and citizens of the European Union. Every euro we put into the EU budget and spend at European level comes back many times over to the citizens, and that is a fact. Now it is very difficult for me to understand the Council once again. The Presidency of the Council has introduced a proposal to cut the Commission's draft budget by around EUR 1.5 billion. What is most incomprehensible is to cut horizon research and science by more than EUR 400 million and then, moreover, not to use flexibility, which will bring almost 300 million more cuts. This is precisely the money that is being used to build the future of Europe.  And while I must also remember that the Presidency has just today received a warning from the Commission about breaches of EU budgetary discipline and breaches of the rules, I would now like to say – although it would, of course, be populistly easier to defend this cut in the EU budget – that look after its own budget. Namely, this budget of ours here in the EU is being used sensibly, and I would therefore like to ask the Presidency and the Council why on earth are you cutting so much from Horizon.

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the world is changing and the budget does not allow us, it does not equip us to fight these changes. Unfortunately, the Council cuts some of the things that are crucial in order to be able to deal with these changes.  At Ciudadanos we believe that these changes go through the fight against climate change, equip our citizens to fight in a increasingly digitized and globalized world and also equip our companies in a world where research and development are increasingly important.  That is why the budget which this Parliament presents — and which calls on the Council to consider, and the Commission, when we start negotiating; and to reconsider their position — means greater investment in Erasmus, greater investment in Horizon 2020 , which is one of the key programmes for research in the European Union – much more spending on climate change — 2 billion more.  We believe that more money is needed for Europol, which reflects the priorities of our citizens in justice... In short, a budget is needed that explicitly incorporates citizens' demands. And in Renew Europe, that is why we will vote in favour of this proposal from Parliament.

name: Henrik Overgaard Nielsen (NI).
text: – Madam President, as I’m hopefully soon to be an ex—MEP, allow me to offer this House some advice. The EU is seen by many as closed, bureaucratic and opaque, a place where citizens have no influence over the decisions being made. The EU is perceived as an institution that spends vast amounts of taxpayers’ money – as we can see in this budget – on things of little interest to ordinary people. But, for this House, more is never enough. As sure as the turning seasons, the European Parliament proposes a budget which will see more money than ever before flow into the EU coffer. However, democracy is about people feeling that they have influence over decisions that affect their lives, and I believe this was the original intention of the principle of subsidiarity. May I therefore suggest that this House switch off the auto-pilot, stop the ever-increasing centralisation, respect the principle of subsidiarity and let national governments decide whether decisions are better taken by them or whether to refer it to Brussels. This way you might find that the popularity of the central government and the engagement of the citizens improves dramatically, as I expect will happen in the UK after we have left this institution.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I may not be a member of the Brexit Party and, perhaps unlike members of the Brexit Party, I go after European agencies. So I know their work and I know the work of the European Union. And while I am in support of reforming the European Union, I can imagine that this budget had to be created with some consensus. And this consensus had to be created on the basis of a draft by the European Commission, based on comments from the Member States and the European Parliament.  And since I do not live in any bubble like some members of this Parliament who think that the European Parliament and the European institutions are detached from reality, but many of us, unlike them, travel and, unlike them, read, for example, the European Union budget and read the auditors' reports, then perhaps we know that there is a need to increase the programme or money for the GSA by EUR 2.43 million. Because if the transformation of this agency, which is currently providing Galileo and providing additional services, is to be completed, then we need to put that money into this agency in order to ensure the new tasks that are ahead of us, and that is, first and foremost, the security of citizens, secondly, it is actually replacing the navigation signal and other capabilities.  I therefore believe that money will eventually be found and that, after consulting the Council, the Finnish Presidency will prove to be the best and we can find a good consensus that is good for both the Commission and Parliament and the Council.   (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague Zdechovský, you mentioned our colleagues from the Brexit party and my question to you is: Why do you think they are so dissatisfied?  If it were not for the European Union and this electoral system, we would remain in political obscurity and never get a chance to come on the public stage and express their views so visprenoly. So, why do you think they are so dissatisfied, why they spread lies, disinformation so much, especially in the context when it really was their country that had all the possible discounts, special rules, and again they are not satisfied. So, I ask you, why are they dissatisfied? I really don't understand that.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. - I don't think I'm going to need 30 seconds. Before I became an MEP, I studied psychology in Austria and we had cases of frustrated people there. And we have had cases of frustates case report, and I think that rarely does any diagnosis apply as much to some members of this Parliament as what I saw in those diagnoses at the time, so that is my answer.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. It is believed that there is no good budget, only an adopted or rejected budget. Well, dear Colleagues, I respectfully recommend that the proposal on our table in tomorrow's vote – the European Parliament's position on the EU budget for 2020 – should be an adopted budget proposal.  I also recommend to you that we support this budget proposal, no matter how many objections we make to it, because Parliament's proposal contains a motion on which I took the initiative in my amendment, namely to increase the size of cohesion funds in the 2020 budget by EUR 3 billion. This progress is an opportunity to avoid a situation that we encountered in the last year of the last 7-year financial framework. I therefore propose to support Parliament's budgetary position.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Madam President, I wanted to tell our British friends not to worry about the level of financial management in the European Union, because we have a rule based on the Stability Pact, the budget deficit does not exceed 3 % of Gross Domestic Product. In the United Kingdom, the budget deficit is between 4-5 % of Gross Domestic Product and indeed the Prime Minister, Mr. Johnson, he gave instructions to increase public spending to address popular discontent with Brexit. Therefore, they have the budgetary problem in terms of efficiency, we do not have it. However effective we may be in financial management and as much as we have all been trained in it over the last ten years, it is clear that an additional funding effort is needed and the European Council must help the European Parliament to reach the desired objective.

name: Adam Jarubas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to start by congratulating the reporting for reaching a difficult compromise. welcomes the consensus that the Union must be more active in key areas in 2020 and, consequently, agree in the European Parliament to increase the budget by more than EUR 2.7 billion compared to the European Commission's proposals. Agree that the more than 171 billion we have proposed in the next year's budget should more actively fund environmental protection, including climate care, the fight against youth unemployment, the Erasmus programme or support for small and medium-sized enterprises, but also research, including very important research to support cancer treatment. It is also important to help combat African swine fever (ASF), an epidemic that is destroying the well-being of many agricultural families in the European Union, including Poland.  I would also like to thank everyone involved for including EUR 2 million for the innovative darknet monitoring project I have proposed, in cooperation with experts. Developed and coordinated at EU level, it will support the services responsible for the security of Europeans in combating crimes based on hidden internet communication, drug smuggling, human smuggling, the exploitation of minors, illicit arms trafficking or the fight against terrorist threats. I hope that tomorrow this compromise will be adopted by an overwhelming majority.

name: Mircea-Gheorghe Hava (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak and I tell you honestly, as a new Member, that I had such a little fear of being alone in this great chamber because I see that everyone is talking and then leaving. I think the democratic exercise is to sit here and listen; maybe that's how we teach each other what hurts each other, because we are talking about solidarity, we are talking about Europe. I don't want to argue with anyone, but the power to sit here and listen to others I think they have to be part of who we are.  I want to tell you that I do not agree with any reduction and I will never vote for any funding cuts, especially for the harmonious development of what local communities mean. We can't ask for much action and results, but we can pay less money. We want Europe to be a world leader in combating climate change. We want young people to be better prepared. We want European regions to be the leaders of competitive development. We want smart and digital cities. We want more inclusion and social balance. That's why we need a responsible budget, that's what... (The President interrupted the speaker)... we need first of all to sit and listen and be able to negotiate.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, representatives of the Finnish Presidency, the Council proposes cuts amounting to EUR 1.5 billion from committed funds for the 2020 budget. These cuts essentially limit job creation, limit research funds, limit the youth guarantee programme, even limit the ability of the Strategic Investment Fund, EFSI, to leverage further funds and give jobs.  Instead of cuts and even at the end of this financial framework, we would expect for the next budget, 2021 - 2027, a sample of writing that exudes bravery, courage and political will. We would expect funds to tackle climate change with additional funding for the Fair Transition Fund needed by the 41 coal-dependent regions and western Macedonia in my home country, Greece. Instead of cuts to committed funds, we need to do a lot in the new economy: tackle climate change effectively, boost technology through research, create more jobs. You need to reconsider the issue of cuts, especially when there is the issue of flexibility.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am Tudor Ciuhodaru, emergency physician in Iasi, Romania, at the Emergency Clinical Hospital "Nicolae Oblu" - a collective, a city, a hospital where the exact time is made in European neurosurgery. That is why I am extremely surprised that very little has been said today about health, especially since many lives will now be saved.  The new Rescue programme that I supported both as a doctor and as an MP, which will receive EUR 156.2 million tomorrow, is precisely meant to intervene effectively at European level in emergency situations, and I am talking here about fires, floods, natural disasters. I ask you to support this tomorrow. I also note that effective measures are needed in terms of intervention, but also prevention.  That is why I call today, in the plenary of the European Parliament, on behalf of all European patients or potential patients, the Commission and the European Council, to consider the development of the European Civil Protection Mechanism, which facilitates, through medical, logistical and informational capacities, therapeutic intervention in the case of critical patients − here I am talking about burns and polytraumatized – especially since this needs to be developed in all Member States.  In addition, I ask you today that the Emergency Hospital in Iaşi, which will be built from European funds, be included in this endeavour. In addition, I am talking about budgetary allocations for the budget needed to develop and develop a programme to fight cancer at European level, and there is a need for... (The President interrupted the speaker)... health education. Thank you, I will still be talking about health and I am convinced that you all want this because unity in diversity is health and I ask you to support this.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Commission talks about prioritising growth and competitiveness. It also talks about the importance of climate action, young people and human rights. But perpetual growth is not compatible with climate action. Growth is increasing, emissions are increasing, but climate action is not even running at a standstill. It’s an emergency, but it’s more talk than action. We’re not getting the action. I also believe that more budgetary margins should be mobilised. It’s not as if everything is okay. It’s okay to put money away for a rainy day if things are grand. But they’re not grand. We have poverty; we have working poverty; small businesses right across Europe are struggling. Why aren’t we using some of this money that you are putting aside to deal with inequality? You talk about human rights. Well yes, human rights is a huge issue: the right to a liveable wage; the right to housing; the right to health care. Why aren’t we putting more into that? You talk about European values and helping NGOs – that that would underpin democracy and the rule of law. Rule of law! What about the imprisonment of the Catalonians? What about the imprisonment of Julian Assange? There are too many inconsistencies in your approach.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, climate change, technology development, migration, new geopolitical challenges - are all things that stand before the European Union. I am very pleased that it is Parliament in this triangle between the Commission, Parliament and the Council that proposes major breakthroughs in this regard. Of course, without neglecting those traditional policies, namely the Common Agricultural Policy and Cohesion Policy, which are based on the principle of solidarity on which the European Union is founded, at the forefront of solidarity with those less developed, such as my country the Republic of Croatia.  I would like to mention in particular the Horizon or the proposal for an increase for Horizon. This is where Parliament goes a long way, proposing an overall increase, all in all, of over €1 billion. However, what I would specifically point out in the motion for a resolution, which is a fair geographical distribution.  We know that, unfortunately, in the tenders for horizon program, to this day, a disproportionate amount of funds go to those more developed countries that have the resources for a large scientific infrastructure developed and which can really pay for it all, which in this sense have a comparative advantage over the less developed.  So, I think it is very important to take this into account, to equalize these starting opportunities between different countries and institutions from different countries, to work on synergies with cohesion policy so that indeed those less developed can catch up with these most developed and compete equally to get projects from horizon.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Madam President, those who want a strong Europe, we would have expected the appropriate financial support. I will not talk about numbers, I am addressing the Commissioner. I have heard his call for programmes on Turkey that have added value for the European Union. Commissioner, if we were at the beginning of last term, you and I, and we were discussing the budget, would understand the targeting of such European funds within Turkey. This method has been tried; what have we had? Crushing democracy and human rights within Turkey, Turkey's invasion of Afrin, Turkey's invasion of northern Syria, illegal interference in the Cypriot EEZ and crimes against humanity. It's 2019. I ask you directly, explain to us how the same method will bring a different result with reference to Turkey.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, while we are talking about this debate, there are chambers across the European Union that will also have a major impact on the decisions we make here – i.e. national governments – in the context of the constraints that are being placed on them by the Stability and Growth Pact. So I think if we are to be honest with ourselves, if we are to talk about the challenges facing Europe: demographics, aging population, environment, the lack of research and development and innovation in the European Union, and the many other areas that we have failed to invest in – not necessarily the European Union itself, but national governments – there must be an obligation on us to revisit how we assess future investment, how we assess investment in infrastructure and in development and in areas of the economy for long-term development.  The Stability and Growth Pact is an impediment to investment in the future. I genuinely believe that the European Union budget is a small aspect of an overall challenge that we have to face. So I would call on others to look at this particular issue and for us to revisit that particular Pact to unshackle governments in terms of long-term investment in environment, education and infrastructure and the other critical areas that will make this European Union more dynamic.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for I have listened intensively with my staff to all their suggestions, concerns, critical arguments and suggestions and expectations and will look at them again in the next few hours and days through a comprehensive evaluation. This will form the basis for a letter of feasibility that we will present to you in a few days' time, which will then, as I said, include and evaluate both Parliament's amendments following your decision tomorrow in this House and the Amendments proposed by the Council, which we have already received. We will also provide you with the information requested by Parliament on reserves, on the conditions we attach to these reserves, and we hope to achieve that the 2020 budget can be implemented as far as possible without reserves. I found Mr Wallace's speech very exciting and I will shortly mention it. The question is: is economic growth inherently bad for climate protection and environmental protection? I deny that. I can imagine growth in the European economy that cannot be achieved against climate protection, but even for climate protection or at least in a climate-neutral manner. I have only two thoughts on this: the entire service sector in which we care for people; if we strengthen education and training, if we strengthen child-rearing and care, this can create growth, but it has absolutely nothing to do with emissions, with chimneys, with CO2 greenhouse gases. That is why the question of where the economy and the world of work should grow is always important. Secondly, if we take the issue of energy and advocate more wind power – including in Ireland – and want even more: wind turbines need steel, aluminium, copper and concrete. The question now is how steel, copper, aluminium and concrete are produced: in modern steel mills, highly efficient, environmentally friendly or through imports from overseas from old steel mills, with price dumping and more emissions. I would therefore ask you to accept that economic growth, GDP growth, is not one-to-one with increases in CO2 emissions. Let me remind you that the European Union has grown significantly in recent decades, and yet CO2 emissions have fallen significantly – not enough, but have fallen significantly. The decoupling of emissions and the growth of the economy is possible. We can prove this. Finally, we must want growth, at least where regions of Europe are still significantly underdeveloped. I wish regions in the rural areas of Bulgaria, in the eastern part of Croatia, the same social prosperity as the citizens of Dublin or Stuttgart. Anything else would be unsolicited. That is why growth policy remains part of our cohesion, infrastructure and research policy. The decoupling of climate-damaging emissions is nevertheless associated and possible.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I listened carefully to the arguments raised during this lively debate and took note of our differing views. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, their shadows, the chairs of the committees and group speakers for your clear argumentation.  The debate has certainly helped to clarify the European Parliament’s position and your priorities, and I will inform my colleagues in the Council accordingly. As someone mentioned here during the debate, it takes two to agree. That’s very true; the Council will do its utmost to engage in constructive dialogue, allowing us to come to an agreement on the budget for 2020 within the deadlines foreseen by the Treaty.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to refer to the words of Mr Krah, who has stressed national competence so much that Europe does nothing and that there is alienation from the citizen. Have you ever looked at the budget headings that we are strengthening? Have you ever looked at the fact that concrete cancer research of an interdisciplinary nature is involved with cross-border work by universities and corresponding higher education institutions? Have you ever looked at the research of fuel cells? Have you dealt with the interoperability of energy systems, with the steel industry, to which the Commissioner referred, which is now researching the fact that the CO2 emitted in the steel industry is used for the production of raw materials within the chemical industry, so that there can be a carbon-neutral steel industry? All this is concrete, and if you believe that the climate impacts are not then, then I can only tell you that if we carry out such research, then they will benefit others and then it will have an impact on the whole world and not just on Europe.  That is our goal, that we are modern, competitive, that we are climate-oriented, that we are environmentally friendly, that we carry out research with which we are globally competitive. That is the goal we want to achieve together, that we can combine things in a meaningful way. And, frankly, I would like to see a little less stoic response of an even nature, and I would like to see a joint commitment. Of course, we as a Parliament know that we must also be willing to compromise, but somehow the Council's movement must move a little more towards a forward movement of at least millimetres. And I would like us to talk to each other before 15 November, because I believe that the objectives that Parliament has chosen are really worth discussing and that we should try to send a strong signal together to the rulers who, as British people up there, have, so to speak, particularly emphasised the negative side.  I can only say to my British colleagues that the European Court of Auditors is also targeting the United Kingdom, there are national audit authorities where, frankly, there are serious concerns, for example in Wales, that you are not meeting the standards. I do not want us to deal with each other in this way. If we have mistakes, we want to correct them, whether in the Uk or wherever, including in Germany, but we want to have a reasonable budget and respect each other and have a budget that takes us forward. That is what matters to me.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Mrs Hohlmeier has made a good conclusion to this debate. I would also like to reinforce the idea that, if there is any flexible institution when negotiating the European budget, of course that is Parliament, and that we will continue to demonstrate that flexibility.  So, a few seconds alone, because we are also too late in the debate, to thank Mrs Hohlmeier for her work on the general budget and also to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have been involved in drawing up our position.  And, above all, and almost as a farewell — although we do not yet know whether we will negotiate this budget with him or his successor, Mr Hahn , a very special thanks to Commissioner Oettinger, because we have shared many very long nights of negotiations, he has always had a very constructive spirit and, above all, he has set out to defend the European budget and to explain it in very concrete data; sometimes we have to go down much further to the realities of the damage that can be caused by cuts in the programme budget that we consider fundamental. So, thank you very much and I hope we'll see you very soon.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Poll: tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the process of drawing up the general budget for the financial year 2020, Parliament has played and must continue to play a decisive role in ensuring that the European Union is able to face increasingly complex challenges. Among these, I would like to highlight in particular the need to provide adequate resources, staff and the necessary training, the JHA agencies and the European Public Prosecutor's Office so that they can carry out the tasks assigned to them effectively. 2020, like previous years, is particularly challenging from the point of view of security, migration, the protection of fundamental rights and respect for the rule of law. JHA agencies have so far been at the forefront of addressing these crises, demonstrating a great capacity to adapt to the evolution of the European context.  Europol and Eurojust also make an important contribution to the fight against organised and transnational crime, drug trafficking and financial crime. And the European Public Prosecutor's Office must have the necessary means to conduct in-depth investigations and prosecute cross-border criminal activities. Guaranteeing rights, legality, security and the protection of the Union's financial interests are objectives that we must ensure when approving the budget.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – I would like to draw attention to a number of problems that I have noticed in the general budget of the European Union for the 2020 budget year. The first concerns under-spending on youth programmes and should be replaced in the future. After all, it is young people who will be responsible for our states and the Union in the future. The priority of each budget must be to increase funding for good education for young people and for the creation of new jobs. It's a pity that this is not always the case. Erasmus+, for example, remains highly valued and highly popular; the number of applications submitted under it far exceeds the available funds. This should be replaced by more funding so that more people can benefit from this programme. Another very important matter is the need to increase the funding of the European Labour Authority (EDI). This should become a priority for the Union, as the youth unemployment rate reached 14.2% in April 2019 and remains unacceptably high and is particularly serious in most of the new EU Member States. Of course, more EU funding is needed to increase young people's employability and entrepreneurship and to combat unemployment. These clearly defined priorities are missing from the general budget for next year.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The following item is the report submitted by Petri Sarvamaa on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control: Discharge 2017: European Asylum Support Office (EASO) (COM(2018)0521 - C8-0359/2018 - 2018/2208(DEC)) (A9-0011/2019).

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first I would like also to thank the Court of Auditors, the Commission, the Agencies Network and Parliament’s staff for their valuable work during the 2017 discharge procedure. We are today discussing the last discharges from that year.  The decentralised agencies are highly visible in the Member States and have a direct impact on the daily lives of the Union’s citizens. This is especially the case for the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The refugee crisis has shaken Europe from 2015 and even though, in the light of statistics, the crisis seems to be under control we still have to ensure the durability of our asylum system to avoid new crises from being born in the future.  That is exactly why the money spent from the EU budget has to be used efficiently and any fraud in the use of public money has to be prevented. Unfortunately, in the case of EASO, this was not the fact for the financial year 2017. The European Court of Auditors issued an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and on the legality and regularity of the revenue and the payments underlying the accounts for all agencies in 2017 except for the payments of EASO. We do regret that the Court issued an adverse opinion for EASO’s payments. The matters which led the Court to issue this opinion were mainly related to non-compliance of payments on public procurement and recruitment procedures. Therefore, in March 2019, the European Parliament decided to postpone granting discharge to the Executive Director of EASO for the financial year in question and to postpone the closure of the accounts for that year. As the discharge authority, the Committee on Budgetary Control proposes, after an almost unanimous vote, to finally refuse the discharge of EASO for the financial year 2017. The following issues were taken into consideration: first, the findings of OLAF regarding irregularities surrounding the breach of procurement procedures, misappropriation of union funds, mismanagement, abuse of position in human resources issues, breaches of data protection rules, harassment and inappropriate behaviour towards staff; second, the systematic nature of non—compliance has demonstrated an inadequate internal control system; and third, the combined error from non—compliant payments amounted to at least EUR 7.7 million, corresponding to 10.3% of the total payments made by EASO in 2017.  In addition, we must highlight that the budget for the financial year 2017 was implemented under the supervision of the Office’s previous management and that this report concerns the discharge procedure for that year. However, we do acknowledge EASO’s new management’s commitment to ambitious reforms. We recognise the progress made on the implementation of internal control systems. All in all, we cannot compromise good governance and sound financial management of the EU budget. I hope that this Parliament will not do that. With such grave findings as the case of EASO in 2017, refusing to grant discharge is the only way forward.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking Mr Sarvamaa, who was rapporteur, for his valuable work. I believe that he has fully examined and dealt with the EASO issue and the 2017 financial year. Firstly, EASO plays a key role in our European migration policy and in the area of advising Member States on their migration policy. EASO makes a very valuable contribution to the construction of a European asylum system. And we are in the middle of it and we want to take further steps in which EASO will play a more ascending role. And in doing so, we must rely on trust and solidarity on the ground. EASO is a partner of the Member States, supporting their asylum systems, which are faced with a high number of asylum applications. EASO is also an important service provider for the rapid relocation of migrants who voluntarily accept Member States. In order to ensure the convergence of national asylum systems, EASO has developed standards for reception conditions that should apply throughout Europe. Member States have the right and are also taking advantage of EASO's expertise, for example on the situation in the countries of origin, where EASO can provide comprehensive information. The importance of this agency's work is one of the reasons why the Commission takes the issue of EASO governance and past problems very seriously. It is about the authority of EASO, which is necessary. We, as the Commission, have been following eASO's situation very closely since 2016 and support efforts to improve the governance and functioning of the Agency, to learn from mistakes and to remedy them, with particular emphasis on recruitment, procurement, budgeting and auditing procedures, as well as on internal governance. We have actively supported and advised the management of EASO to address past shortcomings, in particular on the issue of the budget, budget implementation, procurement and recruitment. We will continue to do so. However, one thing must be clear to all of us: we have two types of agencies in the European Union. One is an executive agency, which is ultimately part of the Commission's role, where supervision is clarified. And we have decentralized agencies, which are exactly the same as european secondary law. The legal structure is just as wanted, and the Commission is only very, very limited in its responsibility here. The main responsibility is the Management Board, which includes representatives of all Member States – the Commission has only two seats in it – and the management itself is primarily responsible. Basically, these decentralised agencies are somewhere in the triangle between the Council, Parliament and the Commission, and there is no clear supervision, clear supervision, a clear supervisory role, a clear legal oversight. In view of my experience over the last ten years and just before I left the House, I also want to propose to the Council: I believe that we should learn from this case of a wrong development in these decentralised agencies – especially since they have become enormously important in recent years – and that we should come to clear technical supervision, clear supervision of the service, and clear legal supervision. Whether that will then have to be the Commission remains to be seen. But in case of doubt, you need an authority that operates 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and takes over this task, and thus also the guarantee of regularity and guarantee. If it is primarily the responsibility of the Agency itself to remedy shortcomings, then there is basically a certain bias. I think that thinking about this, detached from the individual case, should be our common mandate, ladies and gentlemen, as a lesson from this case. Back to the case, we welcome the fact that the joint work with the Management Board and the Interim Director has led to considerable progress. Forty-eight of the 61 measures foreseen in the Action Plan have already been completed in order to remedy the shortcomings identified by the European Court of Auditors. This is about strengthening procurement procedures, it is about internal controls, and it is also about speeding up recruitment. Progress was made in recruitment in 2019, with 100 out of 175 recruitments carried out this year and nine management posts filled, with only six remaining vacant. We trust that the new Executive Director, Nina Gregori, who took office a few months ago, will consolidate the work and complete the implementation of all recommendations and thus fully restore the credibility of EASO. The Commission will continue to monitor the implementation of all measures. Following the report by OLAF, our anti-fraud authority, the Commission supports the implementation of the recommendations relating to the competences of the Management Board as the appointing authority with regard to the Agency in this capacity. Our common objective must be to introduce measures to prevent incidents of this kind from reoccurring in the first place. The Commission is counting on the management of EASO in order to guarantee the proper functioning of the Agency. We are ready to continue to provide our expertise here. In order to help meet the challenges of asylum, three years ago we made a proposal to transform EASO into a fully-fledged European asylum agency so that the mandate can be better fulfilled. In this respect, we also call on Parliament and the Member States to deal with our proposed amendments as a matter of priority and as a matter of priority, so that this legislation can be adopted quickly.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, let me also thank the rapporteur, Mr Sarvamaa, for the work he has done, because indeed today's presentation was excellent and that is where he described easo's problems. I visit EASO in Malta every year in Valletta. I was there in 2017. In 2017, I remember the presentation of this agency, which showed me how it should grow, how it should carry out new tasks and how it is really going to be one of the most important agencies in the European Union. And this scandal, what did he do? He trampled this agency into the ground. What has happened at the Agency is scandalous and it must be said, it must be said here in plenary that we will never accept anything like this.  And I would like to thank the European Court of Auditors and OLAF, who worked together to investigate the case. Unfortunately, it was not fully investigated due to the capacity of the people who worked on it. However, from what has been shown there, I can say that I was shocked and that I firmly believe that this discussion will be a memento of mori for all the directors of the agencies, so that such things that have happened there will not happen again.

name: Lara Wolters
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the European Asylum Support Office is a key EU partner for dealing with migration challenges. Increasing instability at EU borders has made migration one of the most pressing political issues and unfortunately, much too often, a human tragedy. EASO’s assignment is a hefty one. It has to coordinate policies of EU Member States on asylum. It has to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System, and it has to support Member States under pressure, such as Greece and Italy. In order for EASO to perform all of these important tasks, it needs our support and, indeed, it has the support of the S&D. But regrettably, from a budgetary control point of view, there have, during 2017 and previously, been a number of irregularities. Those irregularities occurred both in the management of staff and in the expenditure of payments, and they were such that S&D tomorrow cannot vote in favour of granting discharge over 2017. That said, we also note the improvements made at EASO after the change of management in 2018, and the new director, Ms Gregori, has made considerable progress in tackling past problems, as well as presenting a coherent set of corrective actions for the future. She deserves all the support she can get in implementing those actions. Therefore, I’m pleased that the resolution, which will be put to the vote tomorrow, emphasises these positive developments. With the current pace of progress at EASO, it should be able to leave past problems behind and fully focus on the tough assignment that it has – that of supporting the EU’s asylum policies. I hope that will mean that we can now move forward because, ultimately, we need EASO as a key ally in addressing our common migration challenges and avoiding further human tragedy at our borders.

name: Ramona Strugariu
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Commissioner, colleagues, factually and as a minimum we owe to European citizens, the European Asylum Support Office cannot receive discharge from Parliament for the 2017 financial year. In short, at least EUR 7.7 million of the pockets of European citizens have been spent without complying with the legal procedures for budgetary implementation.  The biggest problems, also identified by the OLAF investigation, concern the organisation of public tenders, the irresponsible spending of European money, the abusive behaviour of the former management towards the employees of the Bureau, cases of harassment and non-compliance with the rules on the protection of personal data.  Commissioner, whether decentralised or not, the Union institutions must be a model of good practice and responsibly manage the money from the more than 500 million citizens of the Union. With these data and figures on the table, the former Executive Director of EASO was removed from office last year, but at the same time it is a direct and personal request that this man never again be a European official and no longer hold a position of responsibility in the European Union.  The new director of the institution presented an ambitious restructuring plan with concrete actions. I assure her of my full support for the work she is putting in place with her colleagues, given the major importance that EASO has in implementing asylum policy.  That is why I believe that we must strictly monitor this plan and ensure that it is implemented to the end. Discharge is not a formality, it is a major responsibility assumed by this Parliament. Irresponsible management policies, abuse and contempt for public money cannot be practices either acceptable or repeatable, both at EASO and anywhere else in the institutions of the European Union.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the EU needs a fully-functional and effective European Asylum Support Office. The citizens and we, Members of the European Parliament, expect that all institutions follow the ethical, financial and other rules of our Union, and I have to congratulate the new Director of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), Nina Gregori, and her team and management for their hard work. In their work, they follow the action plan and they have achieved considerable success, as my colleagues already have mentioned. At the moment, they are going through a period of significant growth as well, both in size of budget and number of staff employed. They need the support of the other institutions in order to become the agency we need: an agency which fulfils its tasks and duties and supports the Member States, the authorities, third countries, and those asylum seekers who come to Europe for help. If we keep in mind what kind of EASO we would like to have, indeed we should not grant discharge for the year 2017. But I am looking forward to March 2020 to grant discharge for EASO.

name: Joachim Kuhs
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to remind you that the issue is: discharge 2017 from EASO, the support office. It is not about the well-being and woes of existence, it is not about us wanting to close EASO or something like that. So the threatening nature of the messages here is somewhat surprising to me, because it is really only a question of discharge, and if I understand the Financial Regulation correctly, discharge concerns financial circumstances, revenue and expenditure and so on. And that is where 2017 is clearly burdened. The rapporteur has already said that more than 10% of the money here has been misappropriated or not properly handled. And the very fact that these funds have not been handled properly entitles us not to grant discharge, and in this respect the issue is easily resolved.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Firstly, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work, for his cooperation with us. You are a personality, you can agree or you cannot, but you have always had your own opinion, and I think that must be valued at a time when many politicians do not have their own opinion.  I am moving on to the substance: this is a truly incredible situation, because it is rare for the head of a key institution to be dismissed immediately from the point of view of the issues that citizens of the Member States of the European Union live on, and the issue of asylum seekers, refugees, is an issue that cares a lot of people who are not interested in politics at all. Not surprisingly, this issue has also appalled many MEPs. I would like to say that the 2018 budget has been implemented, but this case shows that those who have spoken most loudly about how individual countries are supposed to deal with asylum issues often have a lot to complain about themselves.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I have just returned from the Moria refugee camp in Lesbos to learn precisely about the difficulties in applying for asylum and the human rights violation situation that is being lived there.  One of the issues highlighted by social organisations is the role played by the European Asylum Support Office: non-payment, lack of administrative capacity, questionable staff training and, since the increase in the agency's functions, the worrying and systematic denial of applications to persons of specific nationalities such as Syrian or Iraqi nationality, a practice that indicates discrimination against certain nationalities and which we consider to be part of the European border outsourcing strategy, in which the Office acts as an executor of the 'shame agreement' with Turkey, thus continuing the 'necropolitical' towards migrants.  We need, ladies and gentlemen, an Asylum Office based on human rights, and not at the service of the securitarian objectives of the European Union's foreign policy.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Mr President, the issue that has arisen with the European Asylum Service is important and shows the fact of the large operation that has been set up on the issue of refugees and illegal immigrants. Because the reality is that there are too many funds, too much money given in this direction and some people have set up a business on this issue.  So here we must attribute responsibilities and not give forgiveness to all those who have lost some money, and we are talking about several million euros, because here it turns out that together with the NGOs a group has been created which is really stealing from the back of European citizens all the money that is being given and it is no coincidence that, about a month ago , I had also filed a complaint with the Greek authorities, the public prosecutor's office, to see where the money is found by various NGOs that have really taken on the issue of illegal immigration in Greece. Why would you know, because I am from Greece and I see the problem that prevails, in my country the state has no jurisdiction over the illegal immigration issue, it does what every NGO wants, so justice must be done and those who do these things punished.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs which I have the honour to chair has reasonably supported the launch of the European Asylum Support Office as a part of the common European asylum system, because it provides training and practical tools based on knowledge of data and facts, which is extremely important in distinguishing truth from lies in the problem of common asylum management and asylum seekers.  But, at the same time, we say that we find it regrettable that the Council's updating of the Office's Rules of Procedure is regrettable because it is unable to unblock the whole reform of the European asylum system; and we urge the Commission to always support the unblocking of this asylum package.  And finally, the Court of Auditors has pointed to irregularities in the management of the Office's accounts in 2016 and 2017, but above all 2018, in public tendering operations that do not admit any irregularities and, therefore, we hope that from the action plan for the governance of the Office will arise the commitment to transparency and accountability that the Committee on Civil Liberties always expects in exchange for the support that we have so far Lent.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU's asylum policy is a single disaster, and EASO is a money-destroying machine. As the report clearly shows, we do not need an asylum agency, but an agency for repatriation. Instead of wasting money on this, it is better to use it for the effective protection of the EU's external borders in order to finally set illegal migration at zero. Effective border protection must be ensured, particularly in the light of the current war in Syria. We must prevent the escaped terrorists from infiltrating the EU. In the past, the EU has clearly failed to defend against terrorists, as the numerous attacks show. The protection of one's own citizens must finally take precedence over the protection of so-called refugees. Let us finally do our duty! Let's finally turn the faucet on and wipe it thoroughly!

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. There is a Polish saying: "Darkest under the lantern". In recent months, the people of the Member States of the European Union have repeatedly been the victims of a kind of blackmail – moral, sometimes religious, emotional – related to the issue of helping refugees. As far as the Asylum Agency, one of the most important EU agencies, is concerned, I will re-use my experience as Minister of the Interior and Administration of the Polish Government when we were discussing not to transfer the competences of the Member States to the Agency. And now I go back to the Polish saying "Darkest under the lantern". This particular example clearly shows how european taxpayers' money is often extremely irresponsibly wasted. Therefore, as an ECR group, we are absolutely opposed to discharge, because the abuses that have taken place in this particular agency are the best proof that sometimes the darkest under the lantern.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to state that we do not have a refugee crisis here in Europe. There is a refugee crisis in Jordan, Lebanon and in many countries in Africa, but here in Europe we have a crisis of solidarity, which means that some Member States have had to bear more responsibility than others. I want to thank those that have shown compassion, moral compass and leadership by shouldering this responsibility when others have shrugged their shoulders, turned their back and forgotten true European values. We do need to have a better common European asylum system by facilitating, coordinating and strengthening practical cooperation among Member States on the many aspects of asylum – and I include my country, the UK, in that list, due to the hostile environment created by Theresa May when she was Home Secretary and which continues today. Contrast Salvini’s cruel policies of turning away migrant vessels in Italy and criminalising those who gave aid and assistance with the brave actions of Pedro Sánchez, who opened the Spanish ports to refugees just a few days after taking office.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is once again clear that a fantastic idea, a good idea, in favour of the people, can be hijacked. Unfortunately, these frauds call into question what European emergency response means. Know that in the Romanian Parliament we have proposed an extremely drastic law whereby all those guilty of such acts of corruption pay and can never again occupy the public office in which they were placed or to which they had access, because it is abnormal to give the key and lock to the one who put everyone's money in his pocket , the money of Romanians or European citizens.  That is why I am asking you for firm measures to ensure that such things do not happen again and an agency similar to the National Anti-Corruption Directorate in Romania - as is done today by that European Prosecutor - to be in office in this case and to have new results in this area. I look forward to what will be investigated, the results of this investigation, and I hope that, once again, confidence in the European institutions will be restored by condemning the guilty.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we could of course run through the litany of wrongdoings at the European Asylum Support Office (EASO): breaches of procurement rules, human resources breaches, data protection breaches, harassment and bullying of staff, and a general climate of irresponsibility. However, I actually think that it’s more important to remind ourselves of what EASO is supposed to do and how it is failing in that mandate. You only have to look at the role being played in Greece in order to verify that point: thousands of innocent people, desperate to just have a life, are crammed into facilities like the detention facility at Moria, already vastly overcapacity, in hellish conditions. It’s their fundamental right to apply for asylum, but instead many are given a pre-interview with EASO to see if they’re eligible for a fundamental human right. If they’re not, they are handed back under the EU-Turkey agreement where, as we’re being told, Turkey is sending them over the border into Syria, where they’re facing war by the Turkish authorities. This is a stain on all of our consciences.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Once again, I would like to thank Mr Sarvamaa, who has shed light on the matter very thoroughly. We certainly agree: migration will remain a major challenge for Europe in the coming years and decades. That is why, on the one hand, we need a sustainable, common European asylum system for the future. Progress has been made here, but not all the proposals from the Commission and other competent services have yet to be implemented. The home affairs agencies that Europe has to deal with migration and refugee tasks were set up in a different context at a different time. Reforming them has therefore been our task for a number of years, and this includes, in a central role, the EASO agency, the Support Office EASO, which must be developed into an independent, efficient, full-fledged agency. EASO plays a key role in our European migration policy. Firstly, disciplinary action is being taken on the question of the further investigation of the specific case: on the basis of the reports by OLAF and the Court of Auditors, disciplinary measures are being taken. It is the responsibility of the supervisory authorities to take action against the director and against employees under the law of service law. That is what we are doing. Secondly, it concerns legal proceedings, be they administrative, civil or criminal proceedings, which must follow suit. Thirdly, it is a question of examining and exethecising possible financial recoveries. This, too, includes procedures. We are happy to report this to the House. As much as this case can be called a scandal in this agency, the good thing is that in a democracy where there are supervisory bodies such as OLAF, such as the Court of Auditors, like Parliament, the Commission, clarification is possible. And I believe that this shows that the rule of law and democracy also work in transparency. Thank you very much for your speeches.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, as already mentioned also by Commissioner Oettinger, there has been significant improvement in the governance of EASO under the new management. Their commitment to reform has shown results at both financial and human resources level.
