This is why we call on the new management to continue its determined and transparent efforts to develop a more accountable, trustworthy and efficient governance structure and related procedures. However when taxpayers’ money is lost, or spent without fair procurement and competition, the European Parliament must point out such cases so that they can be prevented in the future. We are now looking forward to cooperation with the new EASO management with the aim to monitor closely how the ambitious 2019 EASO Governance Action Plan will be implemented.  Lastly, while recognising all efforts made to remedy the shortcomings of the past, we cannot assume political responsibility for approving the budgetary and financial management of the agency in 2017. If we want to remain serious about the discharge granted by the European Parliament, we cannot arrive at a different conclusion following the adverse opinion issued by the Court of Auditors and the issues identified by the OLAF investigation. This is why discharge for EASO for the financial year 2017 should be refused.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 23 October 2019.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the second report by Isabel Garcia Muoz on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control on the discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, Section II - European Council and Council (COM(2018)0521 - C8-0320/2018 - 2018/2168(DEC)) (A9-0010/2019). I would like to inform you that we have a new possibility for speeches, namely electronic registration for the blue card and for the procedure for spontaneous speeches. You can also use the blue card instead. Electronic registration is now possible, you do not have to wait until the end of the debate.

name: Isabel García Muñoz
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you in particular to Mrs Tuppurainen of the Finnish Presidency for appearing in this debate.  Since 2009, Parliament has been unable to approve the Council's budgetary management because of its lack of cooperation so that Parliament can carry out its work to control the management of the Union's accounts. In the 2017 account-closing procedure , which is the one at hand now, the Council did not respond to the questionnaires sent and did not appear at the hearing of the secretaries-general of the institutions organised by the Committee on Budgetary Control.  Consequently, on 26 March, parliament's plenary deferred the adoption of the Council's accounts until this October, giving it once again the opportunity to amend the situation.  Unfortunately, the Council has not moved a token to date; so, once again, in the face of this lack of cooperation, our committee has had to refuse the discharge of the Council by 2017.  All political groups voted unanimously in the Committee on Budgetary Control, thus supporting the position that Parliament has been having over the years, as we believe that our role is to confirm that the budget has been spent in a legal, regular and in accordance with the principle of good financial management, thus exercising fundamental competence in the interests of all citizens and taxpayers of the Union , by ensuring the transparency and democratic accountability of the entire European budget. Indeed, the report calls on the Council to react and value Parliament's democratic role in this area.  The Council should adapt and accept the democratic scrutiny of its accounts, as the other institutions and bodies of the Union have done, and moreover: even if they did not, the Council should be the first to set an example of transparency and submit to the discharge procedure, providing the information required of it.  It is true that over the years there have been several attempts by both institutions to bring together positions, which unfortunately have not yielded any positive results to date. But I am optimistic and confident that the Council will be prepared to agree on how to cooperate as soon as possible. In this regard, I hope that the Finnish Presidency will play an important role in achieving it.  In addition, the report includes a section on private sponsorships which many Member States use when assuming the rotating presidency of the Council. We believe that the private financing of the Presidency can give an inadequate picture of the Union's accounts and therefore poses a significant risk not only to the reputation of the Council itself, but also to the whole of the European Union, especially in a context in which the institutions need to protect and strengthen the trust that citizens place in them.  And finally, precisely in the name of that trust and for the sake of the responsible exercise of transparency and democratic oversight that our citizens deserve, I call on the Council to join our efforts in finding a solution to this disagreement as soon as possible.  We owe European citizens transparent, reliable and comprehensive management of the entire budget of the European Union.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me first say something about the specific exercise of discharge for the 2017 budget and then comment on the state of play of our discussions on the cooperation between Parliament and the Council during the discharge procedure in general.  In relation to the implementation of the 2017 budget, you know of course that the Court of Auditors in its annual report, I quote: ‘did not identify any issues concerning the Council’. This is worth underlining. As for the more general discussion between our two institutions, after several years of deadlock both sides made an endeavour in 2018 to reach an understanding which would ensure pragmatic cooperation while maintaining certain positions of principle on both sides. The Council has always underlined that Article 319 of the Treaty provides for a single discharge procedure for the entire EU budget. Parliament has adopted a political practice providing for separate procedures for each institution or body. In spite of this disagreement in principle, we found that there was still scope for identifying a common set of good practices to facilitate cooperation in the discharge procedure. The Council revised its 2011 draft memorandum of understanding on the basis of a proposal of the European Parliament and sent an amendment text back to Parliament in May 2018. Further contacts and exchanges took place in summer 2018 and the Council took note of subsequent suggestions by the then—Chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), Ms Grässle.  Last summer, after the transition period around the European elections, the Council received a letter from the new CONT Chair, Ms Hohlmeier, asking for feedback on her predecessor’s suggestions.  The Presidency can confirm that the Council’s competent preparatory bodies are currently examining the way forward. It is very important for the Council to know whether Parliament still stands behind our common approach of the last year, in particular the clear delimitation of the scope of the discharge procedure. Discharge is about the implementation of the budget. It cannot be used as a means to make the Council politically accountable to the European Parliament. Another very important element for the Council is the equal and mutual exchange of information between our two institutions. The draft memorandum says ‘notwithstanding the difference between their respective roles in the discharge procedure, the Parliament and the Council need a similar factual basis’.  This seemed to be the common ground last year. I hope it still is, but it will also have to be ensured in concrete terms. As you will understand, I cannot anticipate today the Council’s reaction to Ms Hohlmeier’s letter. The Council is in the process of defining its position on the best way forward. Let me reassure, nonetheless, that the Presidency is doing all it can to conclude this process and to find a solution which is acceptable to both institutions. name: Lara Wolters
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I welcome this report and especially its critical stance on the private sponsorships of the rotating Presidency of the Council. name: Mikuláš Peksa
text: for the Verts/ALE group. – Madam President, I think that this discharge procedure for the Council and the European Council is a problem that we have been encountering for a long time. We are not here to harm each other, we are here to help each other, and that means helping each other with financial control.  It is European taxpayers' money that we manage together, and we must work together to ensure that it is spent efficiently. Demanding their control is not aggression on the part of Parliament, it is simply a natural part of the transparent conduct of the European institutions. We are responsible to our constituents for meeting these requirements, and I think we should meet them. For this reason, we cannot support granting discharge to the Council if it is unwilling to accommodate Parliament.

text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate the exchange of views we have had today. name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the horizontal anti-discrimination directive - making progress (2019/2877(RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is my pleasure to join you for this debate on this important file: the proposal for a horizontal equal treatment directive. We all agree on the importance of the principle of equal treatment, as well as of the fight against all forms of discrimination. However, Member States choose different ways of combating discrimination. The vital importance of this Directive stems from the fact that it would fill in the existing gaps in the EU legislation concerning the development and the implementation of measures in the field of equal treatment across Europe. The proposal covers four grounds for discrimination: religion and belief, disability, age and sexual orientation. The aim of the proposal is to extend the protection against discrimination on these grounds beyond employment and also to other areas such as access to goods and services. After the proposal was tabled in 2008, the European Parliament quickly agreed on a legislative resolution which would feed, through the consultation process, into the decision—making. On the Council side, in the 11 years since the proposal was published, each Presidency has had this file on their agenda. Due to its legal basis, in order to adopt it, unanimity in the Council is required and, unfortunately, this requirement is difficult to achieve. Remaining challenges concern the division of competences, legal certainty and the financial implications of the proposal, among other things. Thus, for the time being, the Council common position seems to remain out of reach. A lot of effort was invested in the discussions so far, as testified by the successive progress reports. We have understood that discussing the text further at this point would not do much to remove the existing deadlock. This is why we, under our Presidency, decided to launch a broader exchange of views on non-discrimination at different levels, the culmination of which will be the policy debate at the next EPSCO meeting on 24 October, actually just two days from now. We expect a fruitful and constructive debate. We hope it will also inspire and feed into the work and the future commitments of the incoming Commission in this policy field. The aim of the debate is twofold. Firstly, we will take stock of the current situation and challenges in non-discrimination in the EU in general, and second, we will explore possible ways forward in this area. In other words, we want to identify the types of measures and actions needed for ensuring the effective implementation of the principle of equal treatment in order to efficiently advance the EU’s fight against discrimination beyond the field of employment. We hope that, as a result of the policy debate, we will get a better feel of Member States’ vision for the future of anti-discrimination in the EU. Hopefully, it will also provide motivation for Member States to look at the proposal again from the new perspective. We are optimistic and ambitious but, at the same time, as the Presidency, we want to respect different national views and listen carefully to the concerns of all Member States concerning this key proposal. We consider that the upcoming policy debate is important and timely. Its outcome might serve as a basis for devising new steps towards progress. I would still like to emphasise that equal treatment is a principle enshrined in our Treaties and reiterated in the European Pillar of Social Rights and in several UN conventions ratified by the Union. All European citizens have the right to be treated equally and be free of discrimination. Apart from this inherent right, it is also economically and socially beneficial if everyone is provided with the opportunity to fully participate in society. It is clear that our work is not yet done in this area, and we still have a long way to go. I do not think any Member of the Council would contest this. The question is rather about the way we move ahead. In this regard, I am confident that our debate among EPSCO Ministers will prove to be a fruitful exchange. We commend the Parliament in its committed work in the fight against discrimination and the promotion of equal treatment. It was with great interest that we took note of Parliament’s several valuable contributions concerning this issue, including your resolutions on fundamental rights, on protection of minorities, and more recently, on women’s rights and gender equality, to name just a few. I’m looking forward to hearing your views on this important matter.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, discrimination has no place in our Union, regardless of whether it takes place within or outside the employment sphere, and regardless of whether it is based on racial origin, sex, disability, religion or beliefs, age or sexual orientation. This is why the adoption of a Horizontal Equal Treatment Directive is so crucial. It would ensure that equality applies to everyone and in all aspects of life. For many years, the European Parliament has been expressing its support for the proposal and I want to use this opportunity to thank the Parliament for your determination and your sustained cooperation.  We have some new figures from the Eurobarometer on discrimination, which will be released in two days on 24 October. We notice very little progress at EU level when it comes to perceptions and attitudes on discrimination compared with the figures we have from 2015. According to the existing figures, 53% of Europeans say that discrimination is widespread on the ground of sexual orientation in their country. For people of Roma origin, the figure is even worse – 61% of Europeans say that there is discrimination on those grounds. For those who identify as gay, lesbians, bisexual, transgender or intersex, 58% say they have felt discriminated against in the last 12 months.  There is thus enough evidence of discrimination being widespread. This is not only harmful for the affected individuals and groups; it is also costly for our societies. A 2018 report shows that the gap in equality legislation leads to costs and losses in terms of GDP and tax revenue. To use a single example, individual impacts in the area of race and ethnicity include lost earnings of up to EUR 8 billion and demonstrably higher risks of economic hardship. To address this situation, the Commission has been striving since 2008 for the adoption of its proposal for a Horizontal Equal Treatment Directive, and we will not give up on it. We are working hard with the Council to overcome the political blockage and to start real work on the remaining technical issues. At the Social Affairs Council meeting on Thursday, we are going to hold a political debate on this issue and, as we heard from the Presidency, this file requires unanimity. However, we must not give up and we will try again and again. We will spare no effort to have the current proposal adopted and settle the issues in relation to its implementation and costs, in light of advances such as the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with a Disability and the adoption of the European Accessibility Act.  I want to thank the Finnish Presidency for organising a policy debate on enhancing non-discrimination. I will participate in the Council debate this Thursday, and the outputs of the Council will be key for our further efforts to overcome the current impasse. The debate will have a clear mission for me: to urge the Council for progress on the file and express my wish for an agreement to be reached.

name: Maria Walsh
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let me begin by saying that I was delighted to hear that both the Finnish Presidency and the Commissioner—designate for Equality, Helena Dalli, have made firm commitments over the past number of weeks to prioritise either improvements on, or the revision of, this file. It is incredibly important that both the Presidency and the Commission recognise the urgent need for movement on this directive. It is imperative that we come up with a roadmap, not only on how to get this file off the ground, but also on how to close the legislative gap against discrimination covered by the proposed directive. These gaps leave substantial numbers of our citizens vulnerable to discrimination based on inherently personal qualities like their age, their disability, sexual orientation or religious beliefs. In the past 11 years, the world has moved on. Many EU countries have adopted more progressive equality laws and improved non—discrimination protection for their citizens. EU legislation in this area is lagging behind – and hearing the previous speakers, I think we’re all in agreement of that. We cannot continue to be world leaders when it comes to the protection of human rights if we fail as an institution to enshrine these rights in this directive. The twin principles of equality and non—discrimination are the bedrock of the international human rights framework. The prohibition of discrimination is the only right set out in all nine core international human rights treaties. Discrimination is frequently identified by international and regional human rights bodies as one of the greatest human rights challenges facing EU Member States. We need to change that. We must send a clear message that human rights are non—negotiable, and the best way of doing that is to start right here at home.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, in March 2009, more than ten years ago, we voted in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the terms of a directive to combat discrimination based on religion, disability, age and sexual orientation in all areas of life. However, since that vote, nothing has really changed.  Ten years ago, I imagine that our predecessors thought that a progressive text like this, intended to find solutions, would reach a consensus in the Council and be adopted quickly. Naivety! The representatives of the Member States were unable to agree and, once again, for many of them, were camouflaged behind arguments of financial cost.  So, seriously, have conditions improved radically in the area of discrimination? Have attacks on certain minority groups stopped abruptly and their living conditions have improved? Can people with disabilities say that education, work, housing, transportation are open to them equally to able-bodied people? Seriously, of course not! And it is this kind of blocking behaviour that undermines the reputation of the European Union and its representatives, and gives the impression that we are not interested in the concrete and serious problems faced by democracies.  Because the European Union is the best level of action and has a framework to combat discrimination and protect those who are victims of discrimination, we need to get out of the way. That is why, Madam- I have heard you well, I take this opportunity, which comes with the arrival of a new Commission, but also a Finnish Presidency, to challenge you.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the Directive has been waiting at the Council table for ten years — we want to support Commissioner Jourová — and that the prohibition of discrimination is the only right laid down in all international treaties and Article 2 of the Treaty on Union.  There are specific people, with names and surnames, who are denied rights linked to human dignity. Some discriminations are clearly identified, but not well addressed; others are less well known. In these times we know fanatics organized with hate speeches to prevent others from thinking and living without being harassed. Freedom of conscience is the basis of democratic societies.  For example, in my country, in Catalonia, in order to build an identity state, discrimination practices have been reached from the government of the region. Families have been prevented from choosing that children be able to make their first letters in the family language, as Unesco advises, if the family language is Spanish. E later this year, a teacher injured a ten-year-old girl because she painted a flag that wasn't the one the teacher wanted: she didn't want a national flag. And there are children harassed by their parents' trade. It's ideological phobia discrimination. We have a lot to learn.  Discriminatory fanaticism is a risk of our time. We cannot allow fundamentalist or fanatical 'tsunamis' to be imposed anywhere in Europe. We fervently need this directive; they'll have our full support to get it.

name: Magid Magid
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, there are times when politics and politicians show great courage and make difficult, painful, agonising, challenging and torturous decisions. Fellow MEPs and European governments: on the question of the Horizontal Anti-Discrimination Directive, this is simply not one of those times. It is easy – the European public is ahead of you. They are frustrated by you; they are confused by your objections. They understand non-discrimination with greater sophistication and greater urgency than any EU institution. We cannot accept for our people a hierarchy of discrimination, criteria, or the fact that the moment you leave the workplace, the law is no longer an ally.  What the public do need is for a self-evident fact to be enshrined in law. From the shores of Lampedusa to the Arctic Circle, from the coast of Portugal to the beaches of the Black Sea. What is fair treatment for one European should be fair treatment for another. For 11 years we have waited, and for 11 years the Council has stalled. On this, the Parliament and the Commission have been united. If  the weight of unanimity from the European Council is for reducing Europeans citizens to second-class status, then – as the rapporteur for the European Parliament – I ask as firmly as is polite that the Council activists the passerelle clause provided in Article 48, paragraph 7, of the Treaty on European Union in order to move from unanimity to qualified majority voting. Let us be uncompromising for justice, and let us create a union of consistency, human dignity, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights.

text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the principle of non-discrimination is laid down in European Union law and is expressly mentioned in many provisions of the Treaties.  In spite of this, we have been waiting for more than ten years for a horizontal directive to be adopted prohibiting forms of discrimination, even outside the working environment. Discrimination based on religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation and affecting access to public goods and services, including housing, education and social protection. This issue is therefore closely linked not only to the enjoyment of fundamental rights affecting millions of European citizens, but also to the full development of the human person. How, then, can we consider combating inequalities and unequal treatment that are still widespread in the Member States if, at European level, we do not manage to provide ourselves with minimum standards to ensure more effective uniform protection against discriminatory acts? name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Commissioner's initiative to return to the proposal for an anti-discrimination directive that has been in the Council for 10 years, I think it is time to reopen the debate. name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, how long? Not how long I’m going to be here in the European Union, but for how long to speak? One minute? Somebody got the joke. I want to leave these two messages for colleagues today. This is the prospect that we have here, and I hope we take this opportunity in hand.

name: Michal Šimečka (Renew).
text: – Mr President, equality must be and is at the heart of what defines the European Union as a political project. Yet, we have millions of European citizens suffering every day with discrimination in terms of access to public services, or in other aspects of social life. The European Union is failing those citizens because of the blockage of this horizontal directive for the past 10 years. In my own country, in Slovakia, deep prejudice and discrimination, often multiple, persist against the Roma minority, and especially against Roma women. Likewise, the LGBTI community still lacks full legal and political recognition. More importantly, the situation of minorities is getting more and more fragile, given the more hostile political climate in some Member States, where minorities are often targeted and scapegoated by xenophobic and extremist political forces. This is why it is all the more important that this horizontal initiative is again given a try, and that the European Union pushes back against discrimination.

name: Alice Kuhnke (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr How is it possible that, after so long, we have achieved so little? Eleven years have passed since the proposal was drafted. Eleven years without progress, eleven years of continued blockages by some Member States, eleven years without success. We can do better, we have to be better able than this.  We must do so for all those who suffer discrimination every day because of who they are, what they believe in, because of their physical or mental abilities, because of their sexual orientation. We Greens demand that we move from words to deeds. That is why we are calling for a list of concrete proposals to be presented after the Luxembourg Council on 24 October on how we can ensure that the principle of equal treatment applies in all EU countries.

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen (ID).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tuppurainen, equal treatment in some areas of life can be very problematic. For example, if a violent Islamic extremist or religion is born, or if one already exists, that entity or its representatives can take advantage of equality in many ways – even in such a way that their violent worldview and its implementation can be difficult to prevent. When considering and dealing with equality and equality, common practical sense should always form the basis of everything. There would be no way to implement such a directive equally. In addition, it violates the national competences of the Member States. That is why the motion will not succeed now or in the future.  At the heart of racism is the inability to see people as individuals. Instead, people are seen through group identity.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this directive, which has been blocked in the Council for ten years, has already been openly exceeded in many countries. So today in the European Union we are not all the same, even in the minimum sense posed by the Directive. You can be a first or second citizen, depending on the country you live in. To this we must add fragmented treatment of the causes of discrimination, which is why in practice there are those who suffer segregation, crimes motivated by hatred and social exclusion. There is the Roma population, for example, the LGTBIQ collective or people with disabilities.  The Directive is also insufficient. Sexual identity is not mentioned, so transphobia is ignored. Harassment is defined on a limited basis. No reference to data disaggregation or multiple discrimination appears. Equality is not crossed. And the scope of its application is very narrow.  Does Europe really deserve to be called the One which considers a Directive which sets standards of equality that no longer exceed even the minimum filters required? If equality is not Europe's thing, what can we expect from the European Union?

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, indeed, in 2008, the Commission introduces the Directive against discrimination against religious minorities — in the case of religion — and in the case of disability, age or sexual orientation.  There are many groups which are subject to discrimination and, eleven years later - I have been here ten years - we continue in the debate for two thousand, after thousands of Parliament resolutions calling on the Council to stop blocking this directive. It is a directive that speaks of coexistence; it is a directive that speaks of tolerance; is a Directive that speaks of fundamental rights; is a directive that speaks of equality. That is the heart of Europe; that's the heart of why we're here. That is the DNA of this Parliament and it is the DNA of the Commission and the Council.  And the Council is against it because of a misunderstood principle of subsidiarity, because we are talking about equality in education, social protection, access to goods and services or in health care.  We have adopted a social pillar because Europe lacked a social soul, and we have a blocked equality directive in the Council; eighty million disabled people are waiting for us to be consistent. If we have adopted the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, how can we have that Directive in a drawer eleven years, because some Member State believes that it violates the principle of I do not know what? I therefore call on the Council and the Commission: either we do a qualified majority procedure or the Council reflects and truly believes what equality is.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This is an important debate tonight. The groups that are currently discriminated against on grounds of age, disability, religion and belief, and sexual orientation do not have the same protection as other groups. It's deeply serious. We are writing in 2019, and the fact that legislation has been blocked for 11 years means that the Member States are sending completely the wrong signals. It is the case that a certain type of discrimination is considered more accepted than another. That is totally unacceptable. It is deeply unfair to those groups of people who really need this support and feel this benefit most. Persons who are exposed because of their age, religion or sexual orientation have the right to protection. I want the European Union to act and I want to see the horizontal anti-discrimination protection now.

name: Sylvie Brunet (Renew).
text: Mr President, it is important that we have this debate today, in the context of a growing number of discriminatory acts, particularly homophobic ones, in all our countries. Our Europe is based on values; we want to protect the most vulnerable groups in our society and fight all forms of discrimination. Women, people with disabilities, LGBTI people and ethnic minorities are often most at risk of discrimination.  In its time, the Commission launched a wider proposal because equal treatment was covered only in the areas of employment and work. In 2009, Parliament did its part. I would like to reiterate in particular his concern to broaden the scope covered by the text in order to effectively combat multiple discrimination or discrimination by association, because many people are exposed to the risk of double discrimination.  The problem is that the text has since been blocked in the Council since then. It is important that this directive is released because we need to talk about concrete and effective rights. The text concerns access to social protection, education, goods and services, such as housing, for example. I hope that the signal from our Parliament has been heard today.

name: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, it is unacceptable that the cross-cutting directive has been blocked for eleven years. It calls into question the social compact and denies the value of equality between individuals. Instead of improving the protection of citizens in Europe, we have a system that reinforces the idea of a hierarchy of oppression. It is imperative that the Council act and unblock this directive by sending a strong message that discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, disability, religion or age will not be tolerated in the European Union.  It is more important than ever, given the intensification of discrimination and violence based on hatred of the other, that the extreme right spreads, to introduce a policy of anti-discrimination that protects us all. This is a challenge that we face. The European Union must be the spearhead in respecting diversity and human dignity, which are the leaven of our societies.

name: Christine Anderson (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It's really incredible! We are talking about the horizontal discrimination directive. This means that all people who are affected by multiple discrimination must now also be protected from discrimination. Is that really your seriousness? Europe must be a single pit of discrimination. The question arises as to why millions of people are fleeing to Europe in this state of discrimination.  But no matter, it was a rhetorical question. Do you not really notice that, in order to identify your groups of oppressed people, you are using the very criteria that you claim should no longer play a role at all? They classify the allegedly discriminated: by skin color, by religion, by gender, by sexual orientation. It is your ideology that lives on the fact that these characteristics exist. They celebrate them and invent new ones every day. They call themselves human friends. For me, this is nothing more than a false goodness.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I think it is an indictment on all of our institutions that we have just celebrated the 11th anniversary of the failure of the Horizontal Anti-Discrimination Directive – a directive which is clearly long overdue. I just want to give an example of a woman friend of mine, a person with a disability, who relies on using straws for the basic necessities of her daily life and whose life is going to be affected by the Single-Use Plastics Directive. She’s obviously very happy to help the environment, but her problem is that the Irish Government are giving a derogation for medical use. People with disabilities are not sick; disability is a social problem. They’re disabled by society, by customs, institutions, and laws, and you couldn’t have a better example, as far as I am concerned, of a law that medicalises her, that says there’s something wrong with her, even when they are trying to help her. This type of discrimination is rampant, but it’s not a technical problem. It won’t be sorted by a quick-fix, qualified majority vote to circumvent Member States’ vetos. We need real, meaningful dialogue that addresses the root causes of discrimination.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Minister Tuppurainen, Commissioner Vera Jourová, future Vice-President of Securities and Transparency of the Commission.  Ten years ago, the Lisbon Treaty, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and, within the Treaty on European Union, according to the Lisbon Treaty, entered into force, mandated that the European Union accede to the European Convention on Human Rights.  And you know what? It is also ten years since this Parliament voted for the first time on its position in favour of the Commission's initiative to adopt a horizontal directive against all forms of discrimination, particularly for particularly odious reasons which are not indicated by its name in the constitutions, which predated the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union , such as age discrimination, on the reason of disability, sexual orientation or belief— beyond religious freedom.  This horizontal directive is systematically blocked by the Council and this new mandate from the European Commission and the European Parliament can be a fresh start with energy and a commitment to unlock it – as the European Parliament voted in 2010 – in 2019 and how the Finnish Presidency has committed itself to the advisory committee of the Economic and Social Council.

name: Karin Karlsbro (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Not being discriminated against is about freedom in real life. A matter of course for most people, but far from everyone. In fact, gender, sexual orientation or a disability determine your life chances. In society as well as on the market. It has now been more than ten years since the European Commission put the proposal to prevent discrimination outside the labour market, but the directive is still not in place. That is unacceptable. The European Parliament is still waiting for the Member States. What are you waiting for? It is time to take responsibility for the citizens and get the directive in place. The fact that, in 2019, we do not guarantee protection against discrimination on grounds of age, disability, sexual orientation or religion that extends beyond the labour market is simply not worthy of a Union that is supposed to safeguard the freedom and rights of all citizens.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. No one in Europe should be discriminated against on the basis of age, impairment, sexual orientation, religion or gender, even outside the workplace. Allowing discrimination only because it is so difficult to combat it, because we need unanimity, does not mean that we can give up doing the right thing. I would therefore like to express my thanks to the Finnish Presidency for getting the issue out of the drawers after eleven years.  The world has evolved. We have all these discrimination cases, and we know from the Fundamental Rights Agency that one in four people has already been discriminated against – in Austria, one in two – and we are aware of new discrimination cases. Actually, this catalogue should be extended to include social status. We know that people are discriminated against because they are poor. Then they do not get a lease, perhaps because they are women, because they are gay, because something else does not fit, but often also because they are poor, and therefore this ground of discrimination should also be dealt with in the future.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Mr President, some people have to go over more hurdles in life than others do, and I think it’s shocking that one in five Europeans have been subject to discrimination in their lives. It’s our task to create equal opportunities for all, regardless of the colour of your skin, your age, your gender or whether or not you have a disability. I therefore think that it’s very good that we are working to deblock the Anti—Discrimination Directive – deblock it in the Council and deblock it with the Member States.  I think it’s also high time that, when we point our finger at someone else, we also look at ourselves. I’d like to know from the Commission how many people with a disability work in the European institutions, and how more job opportunities can be created for all of them, because I think it’s important that Europe works for all.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I come from Poland, from a Member State that has very low standards of protection against discrimination. Poland has some laws – only because of EU legislation. If the EU does not have a law in some regard, Poles in their own country are not protected against discrimination based on age, disability, gender identity or sexual orientation. The results are terrible. Just to recall the physical violence and assault during the last Pride in Poland.  The EU has to have comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation. Countries like Poland need such EU legislation. We need a horizontal anti-discrimination directive. We cannot be a little bit equal: either there is equality or there is not. As a former Deputy Ombudsperson of the Republic of Poland, I wish there were more MEPs in such an important debate that concerns human rights.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Sur President, mhux a大大ettabbli li direttiva li kellha tintroduikei livell minill minimu ta' protezzjoni kontra d-diskriminazzjoni baqgħet imblukkata għal għaxar snin saħ - u dan l-argument smajnieh - imma, għaliex huwa importanti li jiġi żblukkat?
