name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yes, surely, there can be no place in the European Union for discrimination. But why has the anti-discrimination directive not moved forward for eleven years?  I remember two thousand and fourteen years later, President Barroso, Mr President-in-President Barroso, said: Juncker indicated that one of the Commission's priorities would be to persuade Member States to agree on a directive implementing equal treatment between individuals irrespective of religion, or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. Unfortunately, but so far, the directive has not moved from the point of death. The Council was not persuaded. We therefore very much hope, especially from the new Commission, much more active cooperation with the Member States in order to find a more rapid agreement on the adoption of this directive. And I truly sincerely thank the Finnish Presidency, which is determined to sit at the common table and discuss more broadly the possibilities for moving this directive forward.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, human rights are universal and human rights are subjective. There’s no legal international interpretation that they should be under the subsidiarity principle. This is the interpretation that international lawyers have about the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and that the Venice Commission and the European Council have. So, with due respect – or without that – I am just appalled, and it is a disgrace to the Council that it has been stuck for 11 years with this Anti—Discrimination Directive, hiding behind technicalities, subsidiarity and everybody else’s back. We have heard – and we can see every day – millions of testimonies about what the situation is. We owe this to European citizens. We owe them the right not to be discriminated against. I would like to thank the Presidency for taking the initiative.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it's just a rhetorical question: 11 years? And the great pyramids were made faster. Meanwhile, the world has changed. Take a look, too, that in addition to those barriers that discriminate, such as age, sexual orientation, religious beliefs, disabilities, new things have also emerged. From my point of view it is appalling that two barriers have emerged: education and economic. Here we should be very careful and ensure the necessary measures, because access to health, access to education make Europe different from today to tomorrow.  Indeed, human rights, the issue of human rights remains the problem of the 21st century. I ask the Commissioner, and I hope that the Finnish Presidency will work with all of us, with the European Parliament, with suggestions from our countries, because I remind you that, in Romania, the issue of minorities has been largely resolved and that we have a guide to good practice, which takes place in schools, in universities, in the national Parliament, not just because this right is specified in the legislation. We must come up with clear legislative solutions, be universal, be applicable to all European countries and, obviously, there must also be sanctions for those who do not respect these rights.

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Mr President, this debate may be about discrimination outside the workplace, but nothing will change until discrimination is ended at work. Money, respect, social mobility start there and nothing will change until the EU recognises and addresses the fact that this entity is institutionally racist. Ten percent of Europeans come from racial and ethnic communities, yet the European Union directly employs less than one percent from a minority background. There has never been a black Commissioner, Afro—Belgians living in the home of the EU are twice as likely to have a degree than the average population but four times more likely to be unemployed. The EU’s motto is ‘united in diversity’. It should be ‘united in diversity, as long as you are white’. If, after eleven years, the EU wants to end discrimination, it must start with itself. Will the Commissioner commit tonight to making the next hire a person of colour.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, you have all seen that the next Commission will have the ambition to strongly combat discrimination. In her political guidelines, the President—elect, Ms Ursula von der Leyen, put unprecedented emphasis on promoting equality and assigned this new created portfolio to Ms Dalli, who was mentioned here several times. You heard in her recent hearing Ms Dalli making a strong personal commitment, in front of your institution, to do everything to advance key legislation in the equality area. Maybe you remember I also made a strong commitment and promise in 2014, when I started my mandate in this area. I didn’t expect that the legislation which was already proposed in 2008 would not be adopted over the whole time of my mandate. I regret that, and I find this a failure which is still to be solved. I only want to tell you that we did from the side of the Commission everything possible to unblock it, but with all that effort of course we could not guarantee adoption in the Council.  I heard from Member States over the Council meetings – of course it was in 2014 back then when we were discussing the progress, rather non-progress, reports in the next years – a lot of different arguments. It was the money, competences, subsidiarity – you mentioned some of them.  I remember in 2014 when we started to speak about the possibility to go through enhanced cooperation, which might be the solution, because this requires unanimity so this is an option. This is an option which is procedurally okay but this is an option which is morally absolutely wrong. I was happy that I heard this, also from the Member States who did not want to adopt the legislation, that this would be a wrong signal – that some of the Member States would be out of such a principle thing.  I had maybe hundreds of individual talks with the relevant ministers in the Member States. But the relevant minister is another issue, because not in all the Member States is there one minister who works for it, who works full—time against discrimination, because the competences are shared and the picture of who is responsible for what is rather blurred also at the Member States level.  Let’s be honest, it requires courage these days in many Member States to fight against discrimination and not all politicians are willing to undertake such a risk, because we live in an era of hate—speech online which is turning not only against discriminated people – and this is another fight we are running and we do a lot against hate—speech online – but this is also turning against politicians and journalists who have the courage to write about discrimination. So this is the Europe where we live now and we have to work on all these fronts.  You also mentioned the difficulty with the implementation of the anti—discrimination legislation because we have legislation in place already. I can give you the example of the gender pay gap. A big portion of the gender pay gap – meaning differences in salaries between men and women – is caused by direct discrimination. A man and a woman, same job, different money. It’s prohibited by the law. Where is the enforcement? In many cases, the women are not aware of the gap. So that’s why we wanted to strengthen the ability of the equality bodies in all the Member States to act, and to be the helping hand in the Member States for these kind of cases so that the victims of such discrimination can go and ask for support and use access to justice, because it’s not a privilege, it’s another guaranteed right which should be used here. The pension gap: we speak here about 40% of the difference, so it’s another shameful story and we have the legislation in place, so we have a gap in the implementation. On discrimination and what to do, I spoke about our efforts to decrease or eliminate hate—speech online, which is fuelling discrimination and vice—versa as these two phenomena are fertilising each other. We already started to work on artificial intelligence and there are still ethical rather than legislative, but still ethical rules, so that not to copy paste the discriminatory behaviour and attitudes to the artificial intelligence sphere.  So we are working on many different things, but the thing we speak about here today is a core one. Without the legislation we will always be weakened and we will have to find different ways how to achieve the possible and feasible results.  So in this context I have big expectations that on Thursday I will hear from the relevant ministers from the Member States whether the 11—year—old directive is still fit for purpose or whether they see some room for improvements. Let’s look at it freshly and newly, without damaging the main purpose. Maybe I will hear again the same arguments which I was listening to over the five years, but I am sure that this debate will be very useful and it will give fresh impulse for the new Commission and for the Council to continue working on it. I want to thank finally again the Finnish Presidency for bringing this back on the table of the EPSCO Council.  Let me finish by thanking the Parliament for the sustained determination and for the continuous support, because it is absolutely crucial that we remain strong on this together.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, thank you once again for this opportunity to discuss this very important dossier with you. I have listened with great interest to your ideas, including Ms Jourová. Thank you very much, Madam Commissioner. I couldn’t agree with you more that equality and non-discrimination are at the heart of our common European values. We must enhance it. We must work together on this. I would also like to thank you for your efforts to keep this important topic high on the political agenda. Allow me to say that the Council has repeatedly and continuously recognised the importance of this file. However, you know that reaching the required unanimity has proven to be difficult despite the efforts and different attempts of each and every Presidency since the proposal was tabled more than 10 years ago.  The Finnish Presidency is launching a high-level discussion on the overarching topic of anti-discrimination, hoping to gain insight into the current situation and achieve much—needed new momentum for progress. As I said earlier, as the Commissioner also said, and many of you referred to, on Thursday, the Ministers in the EPSCO Council will discuss how to enhance anti—discrimination in the European Union. I personally remain available to exchange with you on any outcomes and next steps. So let’s work together for a sustainable Europe and a sustainable future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – The legislative resolution on the Council Directive on the application of the principle of equal treatment regardless of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation was adopted by the European Parliament on 2 April 2009. It's been over 10 years. Under the Treaty of Lisbon, unanimity is required in the European Council, but member states cannot reach an agreement for a number of reasons.  In the case of persons with disabilities, the UN CRPD Convention was ratified by the EU in 2010 and a new time has now begun: the obligation under Article 5 of the Convention must be fulfilled by the EU as soon as possible. It is therefore time to see that new approaches to the horizontal directive need to be applied. It is impermissible that the prohibition of discrimination against certain groups, in which there is a common compromise between Member States and even where there is a legal obligation on the EU, cannot be legissated because of dilemmas relating to other groups. Progress will only be made if we learn from mistakes and do not want to force everything into a directive. I therefore call on the European Commission to treat the group of people with disabilities separately so that they do not suffer any further disadvantages.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I consider it a priority to complete the legislative work on the anti-discrimination directive. All the more so because the discussion on it in the Council has been going on for a decade. In the Union, we continue to see numerous cases of discrimination against individuals and certain social groups, both on grounds of age and other grounds for unacceptable exclusion. Unfortunately, national law tackles this problem in a variety of ways. Therefore, the Directive would harmonise anti-discrimination rules at an appropriate level of protection.  The lack of unanimity of the Member States somewhat compensates EU citizens for the Court of Justice, which has given the principle of non-discrimination on grounds of age the value of the principle of general EU law (Mangold) and confirmed its direct effect (Kücükdeveci). The entry into force of the Anti-Discrimination Directive would avoid many human dramas resulting, for example, from the arbitrary and collective deprivation of thousands of officers and soldiers serving Poland, even one day before 31 July 1990, pension rights resulting from seniority, as well as benefits related to taking up any other work after leaving the service. The absurdity and repressive nature of such a practice were recognised by the national courts, referring questions for a preliminary ruling to the CJEU or adjudicating in favour of the victims without a national rule. However, until a directive prohibiting any discrimination on any grounds has been adopted, the national practice of applying blind collective responsibility, without proving guilt, will remain outside the scope of Union law.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EC proposed in 2008 an important new anti-discrimination law, which could ban discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief, disability, age in all areas of social life, including education, housing, and access to goods and services. Nevertheless, 11 years on, the draft directive remains stuck at the EU Council. This means that in 2019, in many Member States, people can still be refused when they ask to open bank accounts because they are considered ‘too old’. We know children that are kept apart from their friends and sent to ‘special schools’ because they have a disability. Discrimination must have no place in our Union. However, several EU countries have adopted more progressive equality laws and stepped up non-discrimination protection for their citizens on a country-by-country basis. I strongly support both the EC and the Member States to come up with a roadmap on how to close the legislative gaps against discrimination on all grounds. We must turn the legislative silence into a clear affirmation of the fact that the provision of these rights must not be politicised and earn the trust of our citizens that the EU can live up to its key values of equality and non-discrimination.

name: Loránt Vincze (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the debate initiated to promote the horizontal directive on non-discrimination. The proposal for this EU legislation is more than 10 years old and was put on the negotiating table of the institutions before the Treaty of Lisbon entered into force. It's time to move forward. This is precisely why we should talk about it again, and at the same time about other groups of EU citizens who still cannot feel like equal citizens of the EU, for example because they cannot use their mother tongue without limits or are discriminated against in a hidden, indirect way because they belong to an indigenous national minority.  These EU citizens need different conditions to live out equality, and the mere prohibition of discrimination, we now know, is not enough. The work that EU legislators started in 2000 in the area of guaranteeing non-discrimination must be further developed and complemented today, making sure that we hear the groups that have been marginalised but have also been present in Europe for centuries. There is a need for the Union to pay more attention to its minorities, to fall within the scope of the horizontal directive or, in its entirey, to protect the UNION's values as set out in the Treaties.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council statement on the current state of play regarding the disclosure of income tax information by certain companies and branches – public country-by-country reporting (2019/2882(RSP)). Before i open the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to request spontaneous speeches, following the procedure of spontaneous speeches and blue cards, both the standard application and the use of the new system, which allows Members to register spontaneous requests for spontaneous speeches and blue cards electronically, is possible. I would therefore ask you to always bring your voting card. If you wish to register a spontaneous speech in the spontaneous speech procedure, you can do so from now on. You do not have to wait until the end of the debate.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, let me first thank you for giving me the opportunity to discuss this topic. This is an important topic indeed, and this proposal, presented by the Commission in 2016, is one of the numerous legislative proposals aimed at fighting base erosion and profit-shifting. We have had the opportunity on several occasions to exchange views on the progress the Council has made in the area of taxation, and indeed there has been significant progress. As far as this specific legislative proposal is concerned, the Council has worked a lot on the text of the proposal. The  competent working party has examined the proposal since April 2016 and further meetings are planned under our Presidency. I am very much aware of the importance of this file for the European Parliament, which adopted its first reading position in March this year. I am also aware that last year in February, Mr Svoboda and Mr Gualtieri inquired about the state of play of the Council’s deliberations and highlighted the Parliament’s willingness to progress swiftly on this file. However, there were – and still are – unsolved political issues which still prevent an agreement in the Council. I must emphasise that public disclosure of information does not automatically mean increased tax revenues. Solid tax laws and well-equipped tax authorities are key in this respect. Therefore, the Council continues its work in the area of base erosion and profit-shifting to further complement the toolbox of tax authorities. The toolbox already includes country-by-country reports by the largest multinational corporations, and these reports can be accessed by tax authorities. I would also like to recall the oral question put forward by Mr Svoboda last year regarding the legal basis of the proposal and Council’s answer in this context during an April 2018 plenary. Indeed, the question of the legal basis calls into question the very applicability of the ordinary legislative procedure in this file. Whereas the Parliament is in favour of keeping the legal basis proposed by the Commission, our legal service is of the opinion that the legal basis should be Article 115 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which is a taxation article and therefore requires unanimity, instead of Article 50, paragraph 1, which is a single-market article and requires qualified majority.  The Finnish Presidency is taking over the results of the technical work done so far. Work has advanced well under the successive Council presidencies that preceded us, and we intend to move forward as much as possible. Consultations with delegations are ongoing with a view to achieving further progress on this file, but you will understand that I’m not in a position to make any specific commitments today. On the Council side, we will probably still need more time in order to clarify our position. I commit to keeping you informed of any further developments and I hope that we’ll be able to find a way to reach a Council position. Let me assure you that we are working on it.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I’m afraid that the Council has let down the expectations of the people and the expectations of sustainability very badly in this question too. This is another issue in the line where I think that a mirror could be of very good use to the Member States. One could ask why companies need to report income or expenditure in any way. Why does it matter for society? We have an overall understanding that it is a matter of public responsibility where you put your money, where you get your money, and whether you pay your taxes or not. This has not been, and is not, the case internationally. Therefore, we have a European legislation that concerns capital requirements, that concerns auditing, that concerns accounting, and that concerns reporting – how you report that information. And even though these reports are used for taxation purposes, they are normal legislation, and that is a clear issue of Article 50. And I’m afraid that the Council has a very fragile fig leaf under which it is trying to hide, claiming that this is a taxation issue when it is a reporting issue. This is the reason, even though we haven’t yet spent– and hopefully not – 11 years on sitting on the issue in the Council. We, in the Parliament wanted to bring up the motion for a resolution with a serious hope, wish and comment for the Council to move forward with that issue rapidly.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Incredibly important to social democracy for many years: we need this public corporate tax return, public country-by-country reporting. A few days after the Panama Papers came to light, the Commission acted very quickly. That has been a while now: in 2016, the Commission and the European Parliament knew immediately that the people of Europe have a right to be brought into the dark.  Employees pay their taxes nicely, many companies do this, huge corporations often do not tax their fat profits. They collude with national governments and create constructs that push down their tax contribution. So we in the European Parliament acted very quickly and decided that large corporations operating in the EU with more than EUR 750 million in turnover will have to publish in future where they make their profits, they tax how much they pay, and the big corporations simply owe it to the people that we know whether and how much tax they pay. The directive is on the table and what are the Member States doing? They are already taking an infinite amount of time, and the population is, of course, paying for it, because of course these funds are missing. For three years now, we in the European Parliament have been waiting for something to finally happen at Council level. Why is nothing more to do? Do the Member States want grass to grow over all the tax scandals, the scandals will fade and at some point tax goodies will once again be possible, as they have obviously always been possible? That is why I appeal to the Presidency to leap over its shadow here. Everyone is discussing the Sustainable Development Goals, stricter transparency obligations in the environmental field, in the area of human rights. Of course, we also need this in the case of tax transparency. Finally, to the co-initiator of this debate, Mr Ferber, I would ask you to talk to your party colleague at home, namely The Minister for Economic Affairs, Mr Altmaier; to my knowledge, he has not yet appeared.

name: Stéphane Séjourné
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, unfortunately, your introductory remarks are not necessarily acceptable.  It is still three years since the European Parliament gave its position, it seems to me, in July 2017. In the meantime, we have had the LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers, which have effectively made this subject a central topic in European political life. That is about $30 billion to $50 billion, apparently, of tax optimization per year. On this subject, in any case, since the debate is no longer on the substance - today it is for us to give the Commission a warning point - help us to put this proposal on the Commission's agenda and to have a real position, for the time being, of the Council. The Commission has submitted its proposal for a directive, Parliament has given its position, it is time to move forward. For a group, including pro-European like mine, we cannot say that we are pro-European and, at the same time, today we can see the impotence of a subject where we are in codecision.  Madam Minister, for the time being, I hope that your concluding remarks will in any case be more engaging than your introductory remarks.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the truth is that the scandals over tax avoidance in the European Union are multiplying. We have used the competition law tool – the Commission has used it effectively in the last mandate – but after the judgment of the Fiat and Starbucks cases we have also seen that this has a limit. And the only way to effectively combat circumvention is with new measures. And this measure of forcing large companies—I remember, only those that bill more than 750 million a year—is essential, to force them to tell us exactly what they produce, in which country and how many employees they have, in relation to their financial activity. It is essential to avoid tax avoidance. Moreover, the arguments when we negotiated this in Parliament, which were to tell us that this would create a disadvantage for competitive European companies... Look, nothing further from reality: banking has already been required to do so since that measure was introduced earlier in the Capital Requirements Directive. Therefore, that is not a valid argument. There is no reason not to take this measure forward.  And with regard to the Member States, I would like to say in a very clear way that it is not institutionally acceptable for them to have a dossier standing for three years, when this Parliament has already spoken out and already has a position, and that they hide behind the question of the legal basis. Look, you can't hide behind this issue so you don't move forward on the matter. This is absolutely unpresentable. I would therefore like to call on all Governments to really unlock this directive to get ahead. I would also like to address the Finnish Presidency — whom I would like to thank for reactivating the subject, because it is true that it was completely parked and the Finnish Presidency has reactivated it and I would like to thank it - to know what it expects from the forthcoming meetings. Give us some more details. I know that today you cannot give us any compromise because you are negotiating, but give us at least some perspective, because citizens really need to know if any of these measures will succeed once and for all.

name: Gunnar Beck
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has The Commission wants more transparency in tax planning by large companies and fair, growth-friendly corporate taxation. Existing disclosure requirements for banks and country-by-country reporting will therefore be tightened up and extended to multinational companies. The Commission has presented an amended EU directive on this subject. Profits should be taxed where they arise – lofty goals, for sure. But, as is so often the case in the EU, nothing, it seems, is as it should be. Firstly, the problem of tax avoidance itself is a consequence of the EU's uninhibited internal market policy. Flimsy legal constructs allow multinational companies to move profits almost at will. Secondly, according to experts from the OECD and the Council of Europe, tax avoidance and money laundering are also a vice of NGOs. George Soros saves billions in tax through his Open Society Foundation, thus financing his politically-desired lobbying. With an open society fortune of more than 20 billion dollars, this is as damaging as corporate tax planning. So why not a country-by-country disclosure requirement for NGOs? Thirdly, the Commission mentions Article 50 TFEU on freedom of establishment as the legal basis for its draft. However, Article 50 concerns only obstacles to the establishment of self-employed persons or the establishment of group branches. In accordance with Article 114(2), measures against tax avoidance – and we are talking about this here – do not apply to the principle of majority voting, but to unanimity. The Commission's proposal would be a breach of the EU Treaties and is illegal. Fourth, the eurozone, along with Japan, has the lowest growth and the highest personal taxes in the developed world. The Commission talks about growth-friendly taxation, but does nothing about it. The Commission's country-by-country reporting plans are selective, anti-growth and illegal. Not with us!

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, in our group we agree to combat tax evasion in the European Union, but whenever this is obviously based on a system of voluntary and free cooperation by the Member States.  We are concerned that the disclosure of sensitive corporate tax information means that companies see their strategies made public, which would obviously affect free competition and unfair competition.  We are also concerned that such information can be used for the theory of fiscal harmonisation, which is that word that is invented on the left to raise taxes on Europeans. Companies should be able to establish themselves freely where they consider, in accordance with their strategies, and should be able to freely maintain their decisions. The disclosure of such information should not go against these principles, and it should be the responsibility of each Member State autonomously and sovereignly to devise a fiscal scenario that favours the establishment of undertakings in its territory.  However, I do therefore want to point out that our panel did have a particular interest in achieving this safeguard clause for companies that might be affected by their sensitive decisions and, on the other hand, the fundamental limit of the EUR 750 million threshold so as not to harm small entrepreneurs and self-employed entrepreneurs.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, there is a key question: how much tax do Google, Amazon, LVMH or Total pay? And if they contribute to a fair share today, who is able to know? No one! In any case, not European citizens because, even after countless tax evasion scandals, companies still enjoy the greatest opacity.  Finally, to get the answer, nothing simpler, we have this proposal of tax transparency: to force companies to publish key information about their actual activities and the payment of their taxes in order to finally be able to detect tax arrangements. That is what makes all the difference with the BEPS proposal, it is making this information public to have the pressure of citizens and NGOs at our side.  Frankly, I have just been elected and what a strange feeling for me to find myself defending this measure of tax transparency after having defended it in the associative field for years and after its adoption, more than two years ago! And two years is a lot of time, time is short, and it's money lost in our coffers.  This essential measure of tax transparency already exists for banks, and they have not collapsed. So, ma'am, how long are we going to wait? How long will the Council wait before putting on the agenda the publication of this information country by country, unblocking the negotiations and shedding light on the tax arrangements of multinational companies of which all of us European citizens are paying the price?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in the case of this material, as in the previous debate, this is a matter where Parliament has a clear position, supports better tax transparency, but unfortunately the problem is in the Council.  I therefore welcome the work of the Finnish Presidency, which wants this material to be discussed at Coreper level. I wish we could find common ground between the Member States, because if there is no change in the Council, then here in Parliament we can talk about the importance of tax transparency, but nothing will change. Three years have passed, our position is clear, unfortunately the Council's position is quite the opposite in this respect. It would like to do its utmost to clarify, in particular, the legal problem of what is to be the legal basis for future legislation, whether it is to be freedom of establishment, which was a proposal from the Commission and Parliament, or whether it is to be tax harmonisation, which is a proposal from the Council. That is, if the Commission can contribute to the legal services sitting so invited together and solving this legal problem, which, if it is remedied, could perhaps lead to a political unblocking of the whole situation. In the meantime, I fear that rather a certain reluctance on the part of some Member States to adopt this regulation for greater tax transparency will lead to a search for proxy reasons precisely in, for example, what legal form the document is intended to take. So I call on everyone and the Finnish Presidency to do their utmost to legally unblock this issue.

name: Ibán García Del Blanco (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, a company or a large company operating in Europe, is at heart operating in the most stable market, the most legally stable market, the most politically stable market on Earth, so it seems logical that at the very least it tells us what it is doing here. What is your actual operation, what are the actual workers you have and what is the part of your business structure that actually belongs to the matrix of your activity.  We don't even know that. The opacity is getting higher. I say more: when one of these companies on top publishes some of the data they have, we put our hands on our heads even more. Last week, Netflix, to give an example, released its last year's operation, recognized a turnover of 5 billion euros, of which approximately 600 million corresponded to profits. In my country , to give an example – in Spain, which is one of the largest centres of its activity, they have declared approximately 3 000 euros of payment in taxation, of payment in taxes. I mean, they've probably paid less than the carnage in my neighborhood, and that's unsustainable from the model's point of view. When we talk about country-by-country reports at the bottom of what we are talking about is the sustainability of our model, of having enough tools to be able, in some way, to control that taxes are paid where the activity is being carried out. Some of these companies – many of them outside the European Union – behave in our common space, in our internal market, as the worst mineral extraction companies behave in some Third World countries, leaving behind little more than a handful of precarious jobs.  Madam Minister, when we talk about this issue, we are not talking about any issue, we are talking about the very support of our model and the very sustainability of democracy.  Faced with a change like the one being made globally, populations are increasingly looking at governments and governments are increasingly able, in the face of fiscal anaemia, to respond to the needs of citizens and, therefore, bewilderment grows and animadversion even towards the system itself grows.  I'm done now, Madam Minister... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, what this Parliament is asking for today is something simple which should be perfectly feasible: we want transparency; we want to know how much is paid and where it is paid. And if we do not even know the data on the degree of tax compliance of different companies in those in different countries, we cannot even begin to solve some more serious problems facing this Parliament.  Honestly, we cannot regain the trust of citizens in Europe, we cannot regain the trust of citizens in the European Union if we are not able to solve this problem: there are companies that do not pay their taxes and there are countries that are helping them.  In 2017, Parliament adopted a resolution: we have not managed to even start negotiating; and we have not managed to start negotiating because the resolution has not even been dealt with in the Council.  We must solve this problem — it is extremely urgent — to regain the trust of citizens in Europe.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I believe Ms Tuppurainen was there with the Greens when the following sentence was written into the government programme of Finland in the early summer: Finland will support solutions for combating and hindering the operation of tax havens, both within the European Union and throughout the world, to ensure that corporate profits and other income are taxed once in a transparent manner. I thank you for this change of policy, which now has made possible for Finland to propose to open the blockage that we have had for several years. I would like to say that this Friday, you, as the Presidency, have a golden opportunity to live up to these worthy words that were written into the government’s programme. The European Parliament puts its trust in you. Please break the deadlock in the Council and you will have a great many friends in this Parliament and elsewhere. I would like to say to those Member States who have been and who may still be against the proposal: shame on you! It is a disgrace that the European Parliament needs to remind the Council of its duty to conclude their first reading, so I wish you very good luck. Let me also say that, since Finland is a front—runner in transparency, it would be very important if you would publish the outcome of the working group on Friday, including the names of the Member States and their positions on this very important matter.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I find it somewhat regrettable that we have to have this debate today, because the Council is taking a position that really needs to be clearly questioned. We have already created public country-by-country reporting for certain financial entities, and it has become clear that the end of the world has not occurred. On the contrary, transparency has led to some business models being questioned and abandoned by the banks themselves. In the last parliamentary term in this Parliament, we did not make it very easy and really sought a balanced compromise in order to reconcile the legitimate interests of companies on the one hand and the legitimate interests of the public on the other. That is why, after all, our debate today has already produced one thing: a Council working group meets on Friday. However, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, if we always need a plenary debate so that you can start working again, then that is a very sad signal. That is why I really do ask you to deal with the Member States, to ensure that we can agree not only on the legal basis, but also on the content, so that we can finally contribute to drying up the tax havens in this European Union. We will not be credible in the OECD if we ourselves have tax havens in the European Union, and that is your responsibility as Presidency of the Council. We rely on you!

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: Mr President, Minister Tuppurainen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Tuppurainen, for the work she has done on this. You spoke of progress in the Council of the European Union. I can't see them. For three years, we have been waiting for a movement by the Member States on this very important dossier of public country-by-country reporting. Since then, nothing has happened, the Council is blocking progress, despite Luxleaks, despite the Panama Papers, despite The Paradise Papers. This must finally stop!  Transparency in the European Union on taxation is the key to combating tax evasion. And the citizens of the European Union have a right to know whether multinationals pay their taxes. And I am also explicitly in a different position from Mr Beck from the AfD, who once again wanted to prevent this and showed that he does not work for the people. Last year, however, the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats in the Committee on Legal Affairs prevented us from asking a question on this very important dossier.  So we could have had this debate earlier, and I believe it is time – and I am pleased that this House is so united – for us to say here in a united way that the Council must move! We in the SPD support this, we as S&D support this, but as my colleague Mrs Regner rightly said: in Germany in particular, the Union side is blocking the Federal Government, and that is why we should not be pursuing a shop window policy here, but, mr Ferber, talking to colleagues from the Union in the Federal Republic, so that Mr Altmaier will give his Go on Friday. The SPD side has done its homework, Olaf Scholz and the other SPD ministers are in favour of this finally continuing. Work on it a little bit!

name: Ondřej Kovařík (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, this proposal, related to large multinational global companies, aims to increase transparency and therefore discourage profit-shifting. This is not only beneficial for national tax authorities but also for local businesses, many of them SMEs, who compete at home against such companies yet do not have the advantage of being able to spread their tax as expenditures across multiple jurisdictions. Indeed, this reinforces the importance of revenues being taxed where profit is generated. It is also a tool to promote transparency when it comes to digital economy. There is a general consensus that the current taxation landscape is not fit for the global digital economy. It is important that our rules are modernised in order to reflect this. The EU can act most effectively to address concerns with aggressive tax planning when it is unified, not only within its single market but also at international level.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For me and for many citizens, it is one of the great mysteries as to why the majority of Member States can take some of their tax revenues away from some tax havens in Europe. The scandal is that the governments of the EU Member States have been able to put a stop to this tax dumping for years. However, they are not doing anything effective in this area. And that is not fair competition, nor is it the tax justice that is found in the election programmes of the Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Liberals and us Greens.  For three years now, a proposal for transparency in country-by-country tax reporting has been on the table. In 2016, the Commission proposed this, and in 2017 our Parliament adopted it by a large majority – and with small changes, of course. Since then, this has been the responsibility of the Council, the representation of the EU Member States. And it is governments that stand in the way of fair competition and tax justice. Unfortunately, not only some tax havens, but also the Federal Republic of Germany, were on the side of the blockers. Now Olaf Scholz for the SPD has recently declared in good clarity that he is now in favour of this measure. What that is worth will be revealed this Friday. Then the Member States will meet, and then we will see whether the grand coalition changes its position now, so that we can finally get a majority for this important measure of tax justice. That's what I'm counting on. We finally need action against tax dumping.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which This debate shows one thing that we have already heard from Jean-Claude Juncker today. We know what to do, but the blockades lie in the national, tactical, partisan games of the Member States, which want to stand out against Europe and do not want to profit from Europe and thus sell out the future.  This is unfair, it is irresponsible and it is unfair. And that is what this is all about. It is a question of increasing the public country-specific reporting obligation, because it is a way of focusing the spotlight on the tax tricksters. It is about transparency and it is about tax fairness. And we have proved that this is successful. We introduced so-called country-specific reporting in the banking sector and discovered in the first year that EUR 628 million in profits were generated in countries where there is not a single employee. And why do we not automatically extend this model of success to large corporations, to cross-border balance sheets? What do we really want to hide? We must ensure more justice, more responsibility, more speed, fewer blockades and more the European Union's ability to act, because that is what the citizens want.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the audiovisual content platform that an MP was talking about previously released this weekend a new film entitled The Laundromat , with Meryl Streep and Antonio Banderas, by the way. A formidable satire on evasion and avoidance tactics to directly avoid paying taxes with transfer prices and all kinds of trichinets. But it is also an example of the cynicism of those who produce such films and do not pay taxes in the respective countries.  In this House there are different opinions on the appropriate level of taxes in economies, but we all agree that taxes must be paid and that there can be no legal or illegal arguments to avoid them.  It has also been said that financial institutions are already publishing information on all these issues without any relevant problems and it is difficult to understand that, three years after the adoption of the Directive by this Parliament, the Council has been unable to move forward in the negotiations.  And it is also sad — as one colleague previously said - that Parliament has waited for this debate to organise this debate to at least have an tentative meeting to start negotiations. And I simply want to encourage the Finnish minister to start these negotiations with a certain result.

name: Karin Karlsbro (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Transparency and fair rules of the game are fundamental pillars of a well-functioning society, also essential for the functioning of the internal market. Public scrutiny both improves the rules of the game for businesses and strengthens public confidence in the system. Tax evasion and aggressive tax planning, on the other hand, damage trust, distort competition and disadvantage the person who actually behaves, which is particularly felt by SMEs.  That is why it is so important that we work towards sound transparency, because if we do not do so, we will in the long run damage both the basis for welfare and also democracy in the long run. We must show the citizens of Europe that Europe can deal with these problems. It is therefore high time that we put these rules in place, so that we ensured a level playing field for both large and small businesses in the internal market.

name: Marie Toussaint (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there will be no justice, no Europe without fiscal justice. Yes, tax evasion is a poison, a social poison because up to EUR 1 trillion in tax and social revenue is withdrawn from the European Union every year. EUR 1 trillion is the total health expenditure of the 28 Member States.  It is a poison for the environment because how can we dare to say that there is not enough money for the climate emergency, when tax havens are full of them? It is also a poison for our security because the opacity of tax havens allows the financing of terrorism and organized crime.  It is indecent to look away and pretend to fight against these organizations, against their attacks on populations without attacking their main resource. That's enough!  It is indeed time for Member States to finally adopt this directive, the first decisive step against impunity and towards justice.

name: Marek Belka (S&D).
text: – Mr President, so much has been said, but one thing that I would like to add is that the issue that we are discussing today is much more important than market transparency, competition and economics generally; it’s about regaining trust of our citizens. As a matter of fact, in the campaign to the European Parliament, we have maybe all pleaded to have this issue finally resolved, and it has been waiting since 2017, when we voted on it. So let me just say that, while we are preaching tax transparency as the European Union, we are far from it. The Council is blocking it; three or maybe more Presidencies in the past have blocked it. So let me call on the Finnish Presidency: you can be a true leader for a real change in the Council and in Europe’s stance on this dossier. We are expected to walk the talk that we preach.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for this discussion and for your different interventions. I have taken good note of your various concerns and will certainly inform my colleagues in the Council accordingly. Allow me to say a few words about what has been done. As regards tax transparency in the EU, the scope of automatic exchange of information between Member States’ tax authorities under the Directive on Administrative Cooperation was expanded on five occasions. For example, from 2018, tax authorities now receive access to country-by-country reports on certain financial information of the largest multinational corporation. This is good. Second, from 2020, information on potentially aggressive cross-border tax planning arrangements with tax consultants will now be required to disclose to tax authorities. This is also good. However, I wish to stress that Finland’s Presidency would like to take this particular file forward and is working towards this aim. You can be assured that we share the same interest in moving forward on this file as quickly as possible. We are determined. As the Presidency we will certainly do our best to achieve as much progress as possible. At the same time, and as already mentioned, I will personally definitely keep you informed on the progress on the file on the Council’s side. Thank you very much again for this very timely and very important discussion. Mr President, thank you.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, a joint motion for a resolution has been tabled by six political groups. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 October 2019. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Enikő Győri (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is clear that we all support the general objective of the draft, namely to combat tax evasion. However, I would like to draw attention to three of my concerns.  The first is that, in my opinion, the draft would cause an unjustified increase in administrative burden for the companies concerned. The information to be published under the draft must be sent by companies to the tax authorities of the Member States anyway, so this is just an extra obligation and we will not gain anything from it.  The second thing I would like to draw attention to is that the information to be published may include confidential data. It is therefore questionable to me whether the disclosure of such data will bring anything to the kitchen or whether it favours non-EU competition companies, since, of course, they will not be subject to this obligation. In other word, we're shooting ourselves in the foot again, we're hurting our own competitive.  The third thing I would like to point out is that the legal basis of the draft is also problematic. This is in line with the view of the Council Legal Service (CLS) that Article 50(1) of the TMS, as defined by the Commission, is not the correct legal basis and that the legal basis for the proposal can only be Article 115 TSI. Thus, the proposal should not be treated within the framework of company law, but should be seen as a tax proposal which requires unanimity. With the plan in its current form, we are therefore losing more on customs than we do on the ferry.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – The blockade of individual Member States in the directive on the publication of the acquisition tax information of large corporations must finally be brought to an end. We must ensure that we shed light on the tax constructs in order to achieve tax justice and fair competition. The aim of the directive is to increase the accountability of large companies with a turnover of EUR 750 million or more to the public. The European Parliament has also done its work in this area and adopted a position in April 2017. Unfortunately, progress in this important area is once again failing because of the negative attitude of individual Member States. We must not allow small and medium-sized enterprises to pay their taxes in good spirits, while large corporations, on the other hand, choose the way past the treasury through shifting tactics or letterbox companies. We must work to ensure that large companies also make a fair contribution to the prosperity of society through taxes, we must promote fair tax competition and increase transparency and accountability to the public. With the directive, we can play a part in drying up tax havens and tax swamps and getting a fairer and more transparent tax system in place. I therefore call on the Member States to abandon the blockade and to sit at the negotiating table with the European Parliament.
